DEBATE.TITLE: FIRST HOME OWNERS BILL 1983HOME DEPOSIT ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1983HOUSING LOANS INSURANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had an opportunity to survey the First Home Owners Bill 1983, the Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill 1983 and the Housing Loans Insurance Amendment Bill 1983 only briefly but it seems to me that, to a very large measure, they are unnecessary, because they intrude into an area in which legislation introduced only last year by the previous Government is clearly producing an excellent result. Perhaps this legislation is before us today more or less as evidence of the Government wanting to be seen to be doing something in the area of housing, an area about which it has spoken a lot. Quite clearly-this is evident from some of the material in the Bills-the Government is attempting to identify itself more closely with socialist philosophies in relation to home building.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that the Australian Labor Party, as a political entity, emphasises public housing very strongly. It does not take the view that the Opposition has basically taken and will continue to take that enormous importance has to be placed on the capacity of people to own their homes. Private home ownership is a very significant objective of the Liberal and National parties. Indeed, the difference in attitudes is borne out by the fact that in 1947 or 1948 the level of home ownership was some 58 per cent. In the following years to 1971, under Liberal-National Party government, the level of home ownership grew dramatically to 68 per cent. That figure rates very highly around the world in home ownership percentages. It is significant to note that in the three years of Labor administration in the 1970s-that short period from 1972 to 1975-the home ownership level fell by 2 per cent from 68 per cent to 66 per cent. By 1981 it had recovered to 68 per cent.

The new schemes we are examining today really add nothing to the situation. I think it is profitable in a debate such as this to look at the value of the concept of home ownership. In the first place, in an economic sense it is far better for people to involve themselves in payments which will gain for them a real measure of equity in the house, the unit or whatever type of accommodation they choose to live in. Of course, the constant inroads of rent do nothing for them in this sense. Rent is a negative payment and a disastrous load.

Of course, security is significant to the individual and is even more significant to families. If people are encouraged and are able to make payments which, in the longer term, enable them to own their homes that achieves a real measure of social security. They are establishing a real measure of equity. They are gaining security and the satisfaction that that security brings, a satisfaction that grows from the understanding, the knowledge and the feeling that that particular unit in which they are increasing their equity is one which they can operate, maintain and develop exactly as they seek. This is enormously important in the family life of this nation.

Mr Deputy President, I think it is important also to recall something of the previous Government's assistance in the area of home loans and housing development. It was an assistance which was very significant indeed and was bearing considerable fruit when this Australian Labor Party Government came to power in March of this year. The two incentives in the home building and home ownership area introduced by the Liberal-National Party Government last year-the tax rebate scheme and the matching grant on a dollar for dollar basis of up to $ 3,500-represented a contribution to housing of some $550m in a full year. Those incentives were very considerable indeed and they were to be added to by a sum of $400m provided by the former Government for banking finance for home building projects. We are looking at a sum altogether which is very close to $1 billion. Indeed, as I said a few moments ago, these incentives and moves were having considerable effect in the building industry and in the home ownership area. They were proving to be popular and widely accepted. Regrettably, from the statement made on 19 May-now known as the mini-Budget-these operations fell away because a vacuum was established, which we hopefully will move out of by 1 October, when the legislation we are discussing this morning is due to come into effect.

Of course, interest rates are the key to virtually all housing programs. Indeed , they are the key to a lot of programs. Fortunately at the moment there is a marginal reduction in interest rates in this country and that can be seen only as an advantage to people who are seeking to borrow money for purchasing or building houses of their own. The problem in the interest rate area is the longer term probability of socialist theory being implemented. One recognises that in the long term public expenditure, the financing of massive deficits and so forth, will almost without doubt bring a measure of competition into the finance market that will tend to drive these interest rates back up. One hopes that will not be the position but one must recognise that there is at least a probability that it will be the position. I seem to recall that the ALP, both during and before the actual 5 March election, undertook to retain the tax rebate scheme, but of course like quite a number of other promises, that one went by the board very rapidly. Indeed, it went by the board on 19 May, which was not much more than two months after the undertaking was given.

I mentioned that from 19 May to 1 October a vacuum clearly appeared in the home building and home ownership area. Thousands of people were significantly disadvantaged by the occurrence of 19 May, which involved an increase in interest payment of between 1 per cent and 2 per cent or, expressed in other terms, of some $300 a year.

I turn briefly to the first of the three Bills before us, the First Home Owners Bill, which comes into effect on 1 October. It seeks to provide a 5-year grant as a lump sum. That sum varies of course from $5,000 for persons with no dependent children to a maximum of $7,000 for persons who have two or more dependent children. The total taxable income of the two people involved at which the maximum grant may be obtained is $24,300. When combined taxable income exceeds $27,900 the grant is no longer available. It represents a replacement for the form of aid that was instituted by the previous Government, under which a grant of up to $3,500 was available on a dollar for dollar basis, it being necessary that the same sum be found by the purchaser or builder of the home in question.

The second Bill, the Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill, eliminates the saving requirement to which I have just referred. From some points of view an argument can be mounted to support the abolition of the saving requirement yet, on balance, I believe that there are very good grounds for requiring a saving element; in other words, that a contribution be made by the person receiving the grant to the actual funding required. In the first place, it does not seem to be an unreasonable amount to be required to be saved and it does seem referable to developing responsibility in the community that it should be seen to be necessary to provide at least something of one's own when receiving a grant of taxpayers' money. That sort of responsibility is reasonable and proper. Indeed, from the point of view of developing character it has a great deal to support it .

Mr Deputy President, the sudden turn around in activity that may occur overnight after 1 Oc- tober, because of the distinct vacuum that has obtained in the industry as the result of the failure to retain the circumstances which operated up to 19 May, presents the possibility that there will be a significant effect on costs. It may even be reflected in the price of houses that people will be seeking to own. One would hope that that would not be the case but certainly, as a result of the vaccuum that has occurred during the last four months, the probability of that happening is certainly present.

I move to the final Bill of the three which are before us this morning, that is , the Housing Loans Insurance Amendment Bill. This Bill seeks to do two things. Firstly, it repeals the authority to sell the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation to private interests and, secondly, it extends the charter of the Corporation to involve itself with commercial buildings as well as houses, home units and various other developmental projects for which it had a charter to involve itself in previously. In other words, the powers of the Corporation have been significantly extended when it was the purpose of the previous Government to seek to sell the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation to private interests, the reason being, that the Corporation was seen as an unnecessary area of expenditure of taxpayers' funds. It was seen as an area where its purpose could best be served by creating a maximum degree of competition. Consequently that was the purpose of the previous Government.

It is not surprising to find that a socialist government seeks to do exactly the opposite. The socialist government seeks to widen the charter of the Corporation. It seeks to enable it to become even more of a monopoly than it is today. As I understand it, the Corporation holds around 60 per cent of the business in its field. With a widening of its charter and with the various advantages which it has, such as the payment of contributions in the superannuation field from taxpayers' funds, it is quite possible that it will reach a virtual monopolistic situation. It is significantly possible also that that will not be ultimately to the advantage of people seeking to build houses, units or whatever.

I believe that the intention of the Government in the Housing Loans Insurance Amendment Bill is purely to further its own basic socialist theory. I do not believe that would be to the advantage of the home builder in Australia. It has not been to the advantage of any country of which I am aware around the world. Talking of socialist theories, I point out that the nationalisation of the health scheme, which is about to happen in this country, still remains a disaster in the United Kingdom and an even greater disaster in Canada. Yet we are continually confronted by the legislative implementation of this philosophy.

I can only say that the first two Bills carry considerable incentive to home builders. I do not believe that they carry the incentive that was already there in the legislation that the previous Government had in this area. They are not, of course, objectionable Bills. I believe there is an objection to the fact that there is no longer any incentive to save. There is no longer any incentive to provide at least part of the money required by the individual needing assistance . The final Bill in this package, the Housing Loans Insurance Amendment Bill, I believe, is an unfortunate piece of legislation. It merely takes that area of commerce into a more monopolistic proposal. I do not believe it has any contribution to make to the final capacity of young people and others to own their own homes. After all, that is the objective of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. It has come to my attention, from listening to Senator Scott's speech, that it was agreed that these three Bills be debated with the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 3), as listed on the Notice Paper today. Senator Scott did not address that Bill. I believe that it is sensible that these four Bills be debated together. Certainly, if Senator Scott wants to speak to the fourth Bill at a later time, I will give him leave to do so. I believe that it is sensible that we discuss the four Bills together.
—The four Bills are before the Chair.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments are directed to the First Home Owners Bill. I have read the various documents. I want to know whether the first home owners scheme is really what it appears to be. I have also looked at the statement of 19 May and the various Budget Papers. Primarily, it appears to me that $50m has been lost to housing this year. I cannot see that we are providing any extra funds at all. We are providing $50m less than was provided last year, and next year the amount could be considerably less than that. I am interested also in ascertaining who will be getting the benefits under the scheme and whether young working couples are being specifically excluded from the provisions of the scheme. The publicity indicates that they are the groups that are supposed to be getting assistance.

SPEECH.PARA: I will take that matter a little further. An ordinary middle-range public servant working in Canberra whose spouse is a shop assistant could expect to get absolutely nothing out of the scheme. In fact, I cannot find any married couple in any type of work these days who would ever be eligible to get any money at all. On analysing the scheme, anybody who takes the first option of getting the subsidy over five years would have to depend on an increase in wages of at least $10 a week above the inflation rate. I am concerned whether this is in line with the prices and incomes accord, whether it is presumed that the prices and incomes accord will not hold or whether there is something else that we do not know anything about. I find it significant that that is what appears from the figures. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) could probably advise me on that later.

Generally, housing is a very fundamental issue. It is a matter of converting a need and desire to a reality. There has to be a capacity to provide, firstly, the money, secondly, the labour and, thirdly, the materials that go with any increase in building activity. The introduction of a new scheme such as this or any other scheme has to be done with a great degree of caution that we do not start things rolling in a manner that will create shortages of labour and material and a considerably inflated price in the end article. On the other hand , I am certainly in favour of any scheme that will improve housing for the wide range of Australians. By nature, the building industry is a volatile and fluctuating industry. It will never be any different. We should remember that, by and large, the buying or building of a home is the biggest single investment that most people make in their lives. They do not do it willy-nilly or flippantly. They do not buy in times of uncertainty. They appear to buy in times of inflation; they do not buy when jobs and businesses are threatened by external or internal economic forces.

I was associated with the housing market between 1947 and 1975. During that time I was involved with building, selling, valuing, arranging finance and generally advising people on housing. All I think I have learnt from so many years in that field is that I still have a lot to learn. The housing market changes so much from year to year and season to season. There have always been ups and downs in the market and there always will be. The fluctuation of the housing market is unfortunately probably the worst single problem in the industry and the economy generally. No government, of whatever political party, will ever stop that. We must agree that some degree of fluctuation will always be with us. The public servant or the member of parliament who could change that would certainly be able to live very comfortably anywhere in the world. He might even be able to get highly advantageous speaking engagements that would pay very well if he could discuss those sorts of subjects.

Matters that affect the housing market include money flows, interest rates and the general feeling of security or insecurity not only in Australia but overseas as well. Since 1947 I have seen a considerable number of pump priming operations set up by State and Federal governments. I would say that they have all been basically good. They have all worked in their areas, and this scheme will work similarly. It will stimulate sections of the market, but I am not sure that it will not be at the expense of the main part of the market. We have to consider whether what we are doing is just a political exercise or whether in fact it will provide more houses for the people in the greatest need in the most difficult areas.

We have done all sorts of things, as I say, but I believe that since 1947 the single most advantageous move was the first one, the introduction of mortgage insurance. Nothing else has been of as great assistance to the housing market in Australia and to the housing of people generally as has mortgage insurance. Last night I heard the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) in another place suggesting that mortgage insurance was the greatest thing that the Labor Party had ever introduced. I think I would be safe in saying that, had the Labor Party introduced it, it would have been a good thing; but even though it did not introduce it, it was nevertheless a good thing.

Population surges also affect the market quite considerably. The Minister for Housing and Construction in his summing-up of the debate on these Bills in the other place last night tried to say that the evils of the last two or three years of the Liberal Government had been responsible for the problems in housing in the last year or two. I suggest that the credit squeeze of 1960-61, the worst since the war, had by far a greater influence on the housing situation of 1981- 1982 and 1983 than what the former Government did in its last two or three years . There was at that time a considerable credit squeeze, with unemployment, insecurity and low birth rates, and the effects of such factors have flowed on to the next generation.

I also heard the Minister claim that wise management had brought about a half a percentage point drop in interest rates. I suggest to him that if wise management brought interest rates down, he should be prepared, accordingly, to accept that unwise management may cause them to go up again. I think I would be wise to caution the Government against extravagant claims on matters over which it has little or no control. If it takes credit for the best bits, it must also take the blame for the worst.

Last night the honourable member for Melbourne just could not resist producing the Australian Labor Party's true position on housing. He came out beating the same old drums, damning all those in the private sector who provide houses for others and following that up by demanding that there should be great holdings of publicly owned rental housing. We all know that that is the Labor Party policy but the honourable member for Melbourne, contrary to what his Minister was trying to get across, insisted on having his say and making sure that his supporters knew that the Labor policy had not changed.

Wherever I can I look at these changes in a fairly practical way. This morning when I was wondering about who would benefit from this legislation I decided to phone one of the prominent local building societies. The first question I asked was: What is the average loan now in Canberra? I was told that the average loan is $40,000. I then asked what would be the monthly repayment with the reduction in interest rates, and I was told that that is now $484, based on 30 per cent of the salary of the applicant. Thus an income of $18,500 a year is required in Canberra to secure a $40,000 loan on which the applicant pays $484 a month. The minimum level of $24,300, as specified in the list, at present entitles a borrower to a loan from the local building societies of $49,500 but if the full provisions of option one are taken into account, this will enable the borrower to raise $60,000. That is quite an advance for the people who fit into that category.

But of course that calculation is based on the presumption that the applicant will fit into that category. It presumes that the family is not a two income family and that the breadwinner can cope with his other commitments, particularly if he is a family man. I barely call people with one or two children family these days, but anybody who had four or five children would find it extraordinarily difficult to meet his repayment commitments on a loan of $60, 000.

I also asked what is the ratio of working couples to single income families who take out loans in Canberra. It is roughly two-thirds two income families to one- third one income families. So we can take it for a start that two-thirds of all applicants in Canberra automatically will be excluded and about a third of all the rest will be earning more than the limit set down. So really not many people in Canberra will benefit much from this proposal.

The Bill provides that people require no deposit but that does not mean that the lending authorities provide for this. From the association I have had with lending authorities in the past, I think it is extraordinarily unlikely that any responsible lending authority would lend 100 per cent of the money to somebody who has no equity and no collateral involved in the proposition. People who have no equity in a venture do not have the same attitude towards trying to retain it as do those looking after their own investment. I think we can be reasonably assured that any responsible lender lending other people's money will require at least a 10 per cent investment by the applicant.

Building societies are also involved in low start mortgages to cater in particular for people who are trying to build up their deposit. I see it very much as a danger that we need to draw the red line on them straight away. I think we have to be careful that lending authorities do not mix both the Government's grant scheme with low start mortgages. If that happens we will place people into an impossible situation by the time they get past the period of the five years involved.

I should like to raise four problem areas about which the Minister may be able to give me some advice. The first question is that if the buyer gets the full grant and depends on a high wage increase to meet later commitments, what happens if the wage rise is lower than anticipated or if interest rates should rise? How will he meet the gap? The second point is that loan funds traditionally come from savings largely from future home buyers. If there is a deterrent to saving, where will the future lending funds come from? The third question relates to the amount of the grant. Will this be determined by the Government or by the purchaser, or will it in fact be determined by the lender? I believe we need to know exactly what people's chances are. The fourth question relates to the taxation problem. Many people are buying houses and have bought houses with the full intention of living in them. But in the search for employment, many people have had to let their houses and move to other areas. The Australian Taxation Office in Victoria is now starting to contest the losses involved in rental properties. This has become a very serious deterrent to people who are buying houses and/or units for their own personal occupation but who believe that later they may have to put them on the rental market because they cannot live in them. What action has the Government taken to ensure that people are not penalised by the Taxation Office for reasons which are outside their control?

I will not delve into the other Bills at this stage. I am perfectly satisfied that this legislation will do some of the things that it says it will do. I am satisfied that it will do them at the expense of other things which I believe would help more people to a greater extent. I find it quite objectionable that it specifically militates against young couples trying to buy a house jointly. I believe that the legislation will need quite an amount of tidying up to be as effective as it should be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my intention to make a few remarks in relation to the First Home Owners Bill and the Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill. I note also that the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 3) and the Housing Loans Insurance Amendment Bill are included in this cognate debate. I was interested to note that Senator Archer clearly said that the Government's new legislation will make some difference to the housing problems facing young people in Australia. He agrees that the Government is going the right way to try to overcome some of the problems that now exist. My interest in this Bill goes back a long way because of the problems that I have encountered in the electorate of Queensland of young people trying to gain enough money to build a deposit in order to borrow money from a building society, bank or some other lending institute.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose one would have to say at this stage that the act by the Government after 1 October to remove the requirement, as the legislation now stands, for young people to have to save money over two years is a step in the right direction. I have found on recent occasions that young people who wish to sign contracts are often unable to do so because of the provision of the savings clause in the legislation. I refer to the case of a young person who recently wanted to sign a contract to buy a house. He could not raise enough money to meet the deposit required by the bank from which he was going to borrow the amount to purchase the house. The purchase price was $60,000. Because he was $2, 500 short of the amount required for the deposit, under the previous legislation he could not apply to receive that $2,500 because he had not, over two years, saved the required amount of money. Because he found that he was $2,500 short he was unable to continue with the negotiations and sign a contract with the builder and borrow from the lending society; in that way he was deprived of any opportunity to own a house. But now, because of the changes brought about by the Government, he will be able to negotiate with the builder and approach the building society or the bank from which he wants to borrow the money. He will find that he will have $2,500 available to him, if he signs a contract before the end of September or if he signs the contract after 1 October or finds the house of his choice after 1 October he will come into consideration for that further assistance that has been brought down under the first home owners legislation. I am talking about an electrician who earns less than the $24,300 which is the requirement of the Bill that is being brought in. He finds that he earns less than that amount and that he is $2,500 short on his deposit to borrow enough money to purchase the house that he wished to purchase. Now, because of the attitude of the Government, he will be able to purchase it. The Government has taken steps, under the legislation which will come into force after 1 October, to provide an opportunity for these young people who have a shortfall in their deposit to be able to have a grant under three options.

I think it is worth pointing out the actual savings which should be held in relation to the grant that will be given. The current legislation provides for savings to be held in one or more of the approved forms for at least one year immediately before the date of the home contract. The grant is paid on a dollar for dollar basis, saved in the acceptable form for a maximum grant of $2,500, where there have been two or more complete years of saving. Under those provisions which were laid down by the previous Government it was impossible for people with a shortfall in their deposit to get any assistance from the Government and it required a particular amount of saving to take place over two years.

A young person's circumstances could change. He may be unemployed for six months. He may be engaged but then finds that he has some problem with his fiancee and the engagement does not continue. Because of that his expenses might be higher. All of those things come into it. There would be no way that he could say to himself that he would save the required amount of money over a period of two years. However, because of the changes brought about by the Government, it is now easier for a young person wishing to purchase a home to save the required deposit and to receive some assistance from the Government. At the moment a person who seeks to enter into a contract with a builder to purchase a house for $60,000 may find that he is $2,000 or $3,000 short of the deposit required. Under the new scheme and the options laid down by the Government, he will be able to gain that extra money and enter into a contract to purchase the home that he desires to build prior, for example, to being married. The other point that I think is important is that the Government has provided for single persons as well as married couples to be eligible for assistance to purchase a house provided that that single person is going to live in the house to be purchased. I think that is a step in the right direction because this allows either a man or a woman to gain accommodation prior to entering into any sort of association with another person.

I think it is worth noting that it is very easy for house purchasers without children such as single persons, to take advantage of some of the options laid down by the Government. I know of a young person who is, I think, $2,200 short of the amount that is required by the lending society concerned to enable him to buy the house he is looking at. He also earns a little less than the $24,000 maximum set by the Government. After 1 October, he will be eligible for the $2, 500 grant. By taking option 3, he will be eligible for a further payment of $550 for the first year, $450 for the second year, $350 for the third year, $250 for the fourth year and $150 for the fifth year. These payments amount to $1,750. Therefore, he will be eligible for a total grant of $4,250. This young person will have to strain every financial resource, including the grant given to him by the Government, to save the deposit so that he can purchase his house. Because he is in receipt of a low income he will receive some assistance each month to help him repay the money he has borrowed from the lending society. This in itself means that he will be a more acceptable borrower in the eyes of the lending society and will be better able to borrow more money on the home he is purchasing.

There is not a great deal more that I can say, except to point out that the introduction of this legislation by the Government will certainly go a long way towards assisting the building industry because more people will be in the position of being able to purchase a home. The legislation will assist also in the creation of further employment within the building industry. It will certainly be of some assistance to the 26 allied trades that are tied to the building industry. It will help also to decrease the level of unemployment in other areas throughout the Commonwealth of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support this package of legislation as, indeed, we supported the previous Government's attempts to stimulate the economy and to encourage home ownership. I have said before-and I think we have all said before in this place over the years-that any assistance to the housing industry is stimulating to the economy. Building homes , commercial premises and so on is of tremendous assistance to the economy of this country simply because building activity is labour intensive. Indeed, the Australian Bureau of Statistics indicated recently that the construction industry directly employs about half a million people which represents some 8 per cent of the total employment in Australia. Clearly, any diminution in that area will severely affect spending power and general family economies. Of course , this will spread into the economy of the country generally. It is estimated that the jobs of a further 8 per cent to 10 per cent of people in this country are indirectly dependent upon the industry. This includes the jobs of people engaged in producing materials and parts as well as business, professional and transport services and so on. Altogether according to ABS figures, more than one million workers-almost one in every six of those in employment in Australia-are dependent on the construction industry and that, of course, includes the building of the average 12 square Australian home, something which has been traditionally dear to the hearts of all Australians and which most of us have no wish to see diminished in any way.

SPEECH.PARA: It is therefore pleasing to note recent reports in the media of a drop in the interest rates charged on home loans. This, of course, means that more people will qualify for home loans as they will be able to afford the home loan repayments required. I do not think anyone in this chamber needs reminding of the problems that occurred during the last two years in which interest rates increased in some instances almost monthly, forcing many people out of their homes when they simply could not afford to keep up their mortgage repayments. Prior to them being forced into that situation, they had to cut corners in other areas such as clothing and food. They had to put off the purchase of white goods and so on for their homes. They did this so that they could meet the steadily increasing mortgage repayments that many of them were faced with in the past two years. So, it is pleasing to see that the financial institutions in this country are accepting the need to lower interest rates in this area.

It is also pleasing to note that the present Government has picked up the previous Government's policy ideals relating to home ownership. These were expressed as recently as in the Department of Housing and Constructions' annual report for 1980-81. According to that report, the Liberal Government aimed to do the following:
ensure that every family in Australia is able to obtain adequate housing within its capacity to pay
encourage home ownership across the widest possible range of income groups . . .
maintain and improve housing styles . . .
ensure that there are economic conditions within which a stable and adequate building industry can assist us to achieve our social goals.

I find it a little strange then to listen to some of the more carping criticisms that the present Liberal Opposition is making to the new Labor Government's scheme to help achieve just those goals. The package that is before us today aims to provide more effective assistance to low income families seeking to buy a first home and to ensure an adequate supply of housing finance at affordable interest rates. This is something which, of course, will be helped by the drop in interest rates that I mentioned a moment ago.

According to the second reading speech of the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes) the package is also aimed at generating additional activity in the housing industry in order to stimulate job creation and economic growth. The package is aimed at re-establishing confidence in this vital industry and to increase the availability of public housing and other innovative forms of low cost housing for the large number of needy households in the community. The Minister has made it quite clear that the path the Government is pursuing is a path that the previous Liberal Government indicated it too was interested in pursuing. I do not think that there is anything much to be gained by petty nitpicking and criticising.

The first element of this package will provide assistance to people intending to build or buy their first home. The second part of the package will provide for a transitional piece of legislation to cover those people who had contracted to build or buy a home between 1 August and 1 October. From memory, this is something that no previous government has attempted to do. It has been one of the major problems that have arisen when any government has changed housing assistance schemes, whether the changes have been to a previous scheme of its own or to a scheme that was put into operation by a previous government. Following such introductions, calls were frequently made to the offices of all members and senators from people who had qualified or were about to qualify under one set of criteria only to discover that, because there was no transitional clause, they had to start all over again. It is good to see that the Minister has taken into account the need for the transitional period between 1 August and 1 October and has removed the savings requirement for those people who had contracted or were in the process of contracting to buy or build a home between those dates.

The third element of the package relates to the role of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. The previous Government intended to sell that authority. This Government has removed the authority from sale and instead has extended the role of the HLIC to give it the right to provide insurance for commercial and non-residential buildings. We certainly have no objections to that. Indeed, the only problem that we can see which is of any magnitude and which is not covered by this legislation-the Minister admits that it is not covered-is that no assistance is provided to low income earners who are not buying their first home . That represents a very substantial group for whom we would all like to see assistance provided.

Prior to the Labor Government bringing down its Budget, the Australian Democrats issued their package which indicated what we felt ought to be considered by the Government and the areas in which we felt assistance needed to be directed. In the main, they included families of all kinds, whether they be the sorts of families that Senator Archer referred to earlier as being families with only two children and therefore not really families, or words to that effect, or whether they be larger families, families on low incomes or whatever. One of the areas to which we directed our attention was the provision of special assistance to people on low incomes who are not buying their first home. We suggested an interest rate rebate of 30c in the dollar for loans up to $40,000 on interest above 10 per cent to all home buyers whose total family income was below $20,000. We suggested that the rebate could be reduced by 5c in the dollar for every further $1,000 of income, cutting out at a salary ceiling of $26,000. We thought that would cover the problem of families of whatever size on fairly low incomes. The Government at the moment has seemed unable to make legislative provision to cover that group of people.

I repeat that we are pleased that the Government has amended the previous Government's legislation in order to provide additional assistance to people building their first home, that it has provided the transition period so that those who had qualified under one set of criteria are not disadvantaged, as has happened in the past, and that it has decided to extend the role of the HLIC. We support in its entirety the package of Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the First Home Owners Bill 1983, the Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill 1983 and the Housing Loans Insurance Amendment Bill 1983. In doing so I make a couple of observations about the Government's purpose in this legislation. First, I am somewhat dismayed at the contributions from the Opposition-I exclude from these remarks the insightful contribution of Senator Haines a moment ago-because they really come down to two major strands. The first is to paint the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation as a socialist bogy. The second is to attack the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Hand) for remarks he made last night in another place. If that is the sum total of the opposition to this legislation in argued reasoned debate in this chamber, we can expect a very smooth passage for these Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that the Govenment has a twofold purpose; there are two major benefits in the introduction of this legislation. Other speakers on the Government side have referred to them, but I will point them out again. Firstly, this package of legislation promotes economic growth which is labour intensive and which has a high multiplier effect in terms of the creation of employment in other sectors of the economy, notably the manufacturing and retail sectors. Secondly, this legislation helps to answer a desperate need for young or new first home buyers seeking to realise what is the unique Australian dream of home ownership. In terms of the Government's overall economic strategy, there is no better way to generate economic growth than to take the measures taken in these Bills which will be followed up by a consistent government program in the home building area. The legislation has that beneficial economic effect and the effect of answering a real need in the electorate.

The first home owners legislation has the great advantage of being aimed at low and middle income earners. In order to qualify for the full $7,000 grant which can be taken in various forms-I will deal with that matter in a moment-families can be on a combined income of $24,300 per annum. The figures relate to taxable income in the year 1982-83. At $27,900 the benefit cuts out. The point I make is that 50 per cent of Australians are on incomes below those levels or on income levels that amount to 55 per cent of average weekly earnings. Those 50 per cent of Australians who wish to qualify for their first home can attract those benefits. That puts purchasing power in the hands of people who would not have had it without this government assistance.

The other point that needs to be made about the area to which these benefits are directed is that in the past there has been a real problem for a number of people whose incomes were above the level to qualify for State housing commissions or housing trusts; that is, for what is known by the bad title of welfare housing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Public housing.

—I accept that correction-to qualify for public housing provisions. Their incomes were above that level but were not sufficient for them to be able to negotiate a loan with a bank in order to build their own home. That gap which these Bills cover means that a lot of people who were too well off to participate in the public housing scheme but were not well enough off to participate in direct home ownership will be slightly better off. A real need exists for a host of people. These Bills address that problem directly. Of course, another advantage is that 70 per cent of additional homes built are purchased by first home buyers. The Government is generating a massive number of jobs and it expects that 50,000 grants will be made in the first year.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is interesting to note the way in which the benefit can be passed on . Essentially, there are several options which include the payment of a subsidy of $7,000 over the repayment period up to five years. Persons will be able to receive a portion of the subsidy in a lump sum and the remainder of the subsidy can be allocated up to the first five years of the repayment of the loan. That helps low and middle income earners over the first obstacle of amassing the deposit and meeting the cost of the mortgage in the first stages of repayment. In that sense I think these Bills cater for a vital need in the community.

Twenty-six trades work in association with the building industry. One only has to walk into a new home to see all the products purchased by new home buyers. They include carpets, furniture, white goods in the kitchen, bathroom facilities and light fittings. Items are purchased for every room to complement the home. As a result someone else in the community gains employment. The multiplier effect for new homes is estimated at between 4 and 4.5 per cent. It means that the jobs directly created by the passage of these Bills in the construction area will be supplemented by the multiplier effect on the whole of the community. With the reductions in home loan interest rates that are beginning to occur across the board we can look forward to a growth in employment in the construction industry and elsewhere. That is to be commended.

It has been argued by an Opposition senator who spoke earlier in the debate that by adopting this reflationary measure there will be shortages of labour and shortages of material. I think the Government has pitched its stimulus at exactly the right level so that there will not be bottlenecks which artificially force up prices. People in the building industry have suffered tremendously from unemployment. Most building workers have been out of work at one time or another in the last several years. Some of them have found alternative jobs. My research has shown that qualified building tradesmen tend to be employed first if they are competing for jobs with semi-skilled or unskilled workers. Building tradesmen have tended to preclude semi-skilled and unskilled workers from the work that is available. The regrowth in the housing construction industry will attract those workers who have been forced out by depressed demand back into the trades and supporting industries. As tradesmen return to their trade the jobs they have been filling will become available for other workers.

In my view there is certainly not a shortage of skilled labour. It was said that there was a shortage of materials. We have seen retrenchments, particularly in Western Australia, in the timber industry. We have seen the closure of a number of timber mills, retrenchments in the cement industry and the rationalisation of plant and equipment in that industry. There has been a massive downturn in the production of bricks and other household commodities. The factories and the warehouses are now emptying because of a decrease in home building. The important point is that the industrial capacity of the building materials sector was developed for a more buoyant housing industry than we are currently enjoying. Therefore, there is considerable spare capacity in that area of production. It is a matter of recruiting workers back into the industry to lift the production output to meet the demand these Bills will generate through stimulating the housing industry. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak about several matters in relation to the First Home Owners Bill 1983, the Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill 1983, the Housing Loans Insurance Amendment Bill 1983 and the Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1983. I will address my remarks to all four Bills. Firstly, I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that these Bills represent the breaking of a promise which the Hawke Labor Government made on coming to power in March 1983. It made the promise that it would continue the housing loan interest rebate taxation scheme. Clearly the Government has broken an undertaking it gave to the Australian people by introducing this legislation to repeal that particular benefit. The benefit was much sought after by the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: If we check the record closely we will find that the Australian Labor Party, in opposition, was very supportive of that legislation. Now that it is in government its political thrust is different. I will come to that a little later and demonstrate that it really represents a major change in the Government's ideological attitude. Although this legislation is clouded in a whole lot of goodies being handed out to particular interest groups, we have to acknowledge that behind it is a very strong thrust towards the development of the Government 's fundamental socialist principles in relation to housing.

I acknowledge the fact that there is a high percentage of home ownership in Australia. About 70 per cent to 71 per cent of people in Australia own their own homes. Clearly, home ownership has been a feature of Australian life for a long time. Long may it remain so. It is something that all honourable senators, in our private activities and in this place, have sought to strengthen and maintain as part of the development of the family. The fact is that the purchase of a house does provide a store of capital. It gives a sense of security because it means that we have a roof over our head, and it also provides some financial security. A home is a solid asset against which borrowings can be made for all kinds of purposes in the event of need. For that reason, home ownership represents a fundamental plank in this nation's development. It is certainly in the interests of the Australian people.

Although the percentage of Australian home ownership is high, and it is true that the figure I cited is an Australia-wide figure, there is some unevenness between the States. There is unevenness also between income levels in the community. It is an unfortunate fact that housing in some States, for instance New South Wales-particularly in Sydney-is substantially more expensive than housing in other States, for example, my own State of South Australia. I think an analysis would show that the average selling price of a house in Sydney would be roughly double the cost of a house in Adelaide. From that point of view, it is very difficult to design policies which will assist the whole population of Australia. Bearing in mind the fact that the price of houses is different from State to State, we immediately have to recognise that classes of people who in one State may not be seen to be needy certainly would be regarded as needy in another State. It is clear that a person who has to spend $80,000 for an average house in Sydney would be in circumstances very much different from someone on the same wage who has to pay $40,000 for a house in Adelaide. For that reason all emphasis I think should be thrust towards developing policies on a macroeconomic level to ensure that house prices do not get away from the average family, that in fact there is a strong downward pressure on inflation, which of course would have its corresponding effects in producing downward pressures on interest rates. All those things are very significant in keeping people in their houses and in ensuring that the maximum number of Australians can enjoy home ownership.

There are one or two matters in relation to the legislation which are of concern. First, we note that a new grants scheme abolishes the need for savings by individuals who qualify for grants. I think that point needs to be acknowledged as not necessarily being in the best interests of the community. I believe it is a very important factor in Australian life that people have learnt to contribute to their own welfare by ensuring that they save for a home. Indeed , I believe the system should be designed to encourage people to do that. The Government has moved somewhat hastily at this early stage of its life in another direction. No doubt, it has its ideological reasons for doing so, although it has to be acknowledged that possibly some people who qualify for this benefit would be the most needy in the community. But they may not have an opportunity to save a significant part of their deposit for a home as others may.

That again draws me to the other point that I made earlier about the differing levels of need across the Australian community as they exist in different States . In the context of savings, I draw the attention of honourable senators to an editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald of 20 May following the Government's mini -Budget. It stated:

The element of illusion in the housing package is simply the extent to which it will assist first-home buyers. Despite Mr Keating's assurances to the contrary, the additional demand for housing must, to some extent, push up home prices. Part of the benefit will go to existing home-owners. It is, of course, also absurd to regard anyone who is within striking distance of acquiring a home as being in urgent need of the taxpayer's assistance. They must, at least, have a job and a fair amount of money in their savings account to be able to take on a housing loan, even a heavily-subsidised housing loan.

I believe, those words spell out the problems that the Government will face, it having embarked upon a path which will present future administrative difficulties for it in assessing need in the community generally. The first point of the editorial also drew our attention to another fact-that is, that subsidies of this kind will inevitably lead to rising prices. I heard Senator Cook a few minutes ago draw our attention to what he regarded as the very balanced package which the Government has brought down. I remains to be seen how balanced that is against events, particularly those events now occurring in the money markets.

We know that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have been very keen to claim credit for drops in interest rates, which are a vital part of any government's policy in regard to housing. But at the same time they gave us no undertaking, nor are they apparently prepared to say, that they are going to reduce the interest rates which they are offering in respect of sales of Aussie Bonds. We will be waiting with bated breath to see what the Government does in this area because the fact is that its Budget presented a few weeks ago rides very heavily on the ability of the Government to be able to raise sufficient money to meet that huge deficit of $8.3 billion. We will know more in six or eight months time about the trend in interest rates. I certainly believe that if the Government is now prepared to claim credit for interest rate drops following its policy successes, it will equally bear the ignominy of the failure of that policy in six or eight months time as interest rates start to rise.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you not think the business community needs confidence now, not knocking?
—Of course it does.
—Then why not give it a bit? You do nothing but knock, you lot-all the time, knock, knock, knock.

—Of course it does, but it is not going to be given confidence by false arguments presented by the Government in this place. I think there is another more deep seated problem with this housing package which really goes to the core of what this legislation is about and really displays this Government's policy in relation to housing. As the figures in the mini-Budget displayed, there was a very big boost of the order of $78m, if I remember correctly, in the amount of housing expenditure in this financial year. If we analyse the mini- Budget papers and the Budget Papers which were brought down the other day, as has already been acknowledged by the Treasurer, we find there is a significant saving to the Government of $420m in terms of revenues and expenditure in housing in the year 1984-85. It is claimed that that will continue in the years thereafter. The lesson to be drawn is that although there is a significant boost in expenditure this year, in forthcoming years there will be a very significant drop. There has been no stated government policy about that matter. Again, the Opposition is waiting with bated breath to see what the Government has to say about those things.

SPEECH.PARA: Even by the most generous analysis of the Government's figures and allowing for the fact that it has boosted the amount of expenditure in welfare housing from $ 330m to $500m in this financial year, it has not committed itself to any welfare housing expenditure in the next financial year. After taking into account the increase that the Government expects this year and assuming, to be most generous , that that will continue next year, there is a net saving to the Government in housing of about $200m. In that event can the Government claim that it is really interested in boosting first home ownership for Australians? I think that is the issue arising in this legislation which the Government will not address itself to. Surely it has constructed a very clever piece of policy to pull the wool over people's eyes by trying to demonstrate that it is interested in that group of first home owners. Clearly the Government has set aside about $200m in savings in the next financial year, and in the years that follow that, for particular purposes which it has in mind but has not yet spelt out.

It is fairly clear that the Government's policy in this area, bearing in mind its statement of policy before the election when in opposition, is that it is determined to increase the stock of public housing. There is no denial that there is a need in some areas for an increase in public housing. But coming on top of a significant expenditure increase this year, and with an obvious intention to build that up in future years, it looks very clearly like the implementation of a policy design to force people to be dependent upon the Government and to seek rental housing provided by the Government rather than to seek their own properties and capital stock. That is where the policy, we believe, is designed to take us into a different kind of Australia. It is a policy which we know will change the basis of home ownership in Australia. It was of course enunciated clearly by government supporters when they were in opposition-I refer in particular to such spokesman as Senator Gietzelt and Mr Uren in the House of Representatives-over a long period. That is the thrust of the legislation. It is designed with an ideological bent in mind. Clearly, it is a clever piece of legislation in the sense that it will deliver some goods to an interest group at a particular time. I refer especially to the building industry . It was very interesting to hear Senator Cook extol the virtues of that exercise but I remain unconvinced that one can create more jobs in the building industry by fostering other industries. If the Government is as interested in job creation as it leads us to believe, why does it not consider altering its thrust in regard to the community employment program with a view to the creation of both jobs and basic national assets in the same way as did the former Government's policies with regard to the bicentennial roads program, the water resources program and so on?

I believe that the few points I have made are important in considering these issues. The Opposition has announced its position on the legislation. Certain of its shortcomings have been pointed to. Certainly, Senator Scott drew our attention to them earlier in the debate. The Opposition is in favour of the general thrust of the policy but draws attention to the points that I have enunciated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I appreciate the difficulties that are faced by Senator Messner and some honourable senators opposite who feel that they must oppose in some way all legislation put forward by this Government but do not know quite how to go about that task when legislation is accepted generally, and very well, in the community at large. Senator Messner uses the ploy he uses so often of saying: ' Yes, this is all right in parts but what are you going to do two, three, four or five years hence? Why not tell us that, because we suspect that this is part of some terrible plot to change the nature of our society and the way in which people are treated in it'? One thing about the Government is that its measures are part of a coherent program-in this case to assist low income earners in particular to get their first home. Other parts of our housing program seek to increase the stock of public housing. We have an overall design which seeks to ensure that people are adequately housed, in a way that they can afford.

SPEECH.PARA: I suppose that the first thing one should do is point out that this legislation provides assistance to low income earners; that it removes some of the restrictions which hampered the previous Government's scheme; that it allows for the provision of funds for what might be called innovative housing purchase, such as is not possible under existing schemes; and that it provides for a smoothing over of the effects that will result from a changeover in schemes. Unfortunately, certain people took advantage of the scheme of the previous Government. It also provides that the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation is not to be sold but will have an extended role in protecting those who will purchase homes in the future. The most important thing to point out, in view of what Senator Haines has called the carping criticism by the Opposition, is that the first home owners assistance scheme, which was introduced by my colleague Mr Hurford, the Minister for Housing and Construction in another place, and is to be brought into effect by this package of legislation, has been greeted with enthusiasm by such organisations as the Real Estate Institute of Australia, the Housing Industry Association and the Master Builders Federation of Australia Incorporated, people who know the problem in the housing industry, who know that in recent years there has been a tragic downturn and that we have to do something to overcome it.

In fact, it seems that these schemes have been greeted with enthusiasm by everyone except the Liberal-National Party Opposition. In their usual way its supporters have offered opposition in the form either of the carping, nitpicking criticism that we have heard from Senator Messner, and Senator Archer or, even more sadly, the tired arguments used by Senator Scott, who went on to describe the legislation as part of a socialist plot akin to what he has called the nationalisation of the health industry-an equally ridiculous statement. He described the legislation as part of a socialist plot to change in some way the nature of home ownership in this country-the term usually used being to eat at out moral fibre. Senator Scott said in passing that it was a pity that the disciplinary, moral and character building effects of the saving requirements in the existing legislation had been removed even though, as Senator Messner said later, the new legislation will provide assistance for those with the least incomes in the community, those who need it now and who, because of the parlous state of the industry will continue to need it.

Senator Scott also spoke of what he described as a vacuum in the home ownership field that had existed since the May economic statement was made. But if one wants to look at what could more accurately be described as a vacuum one need only quote the figures for housing commencements under the previous Government. In the period prior to March 1982 commencements were at the pretty low level of 29,130. The Government then introduced new measures and in the June quarter commencements fell to 28,420. In the September quarter they were down to 26,620 and in the December quarter to 24,920. In the March quarter of 1983 they fell to 24,010. That is more indicative of the industry heading for a vacuum in this regard. It is the real crux of what has been happening in this country in recent years. It is the problem which has faced the Real Estate Institute, the Master Builders Federation and the Housing Industry Association in recent years. They realised that something reasonable had to be done to create capacity. Having looked at the package brought down by my colleague, they welcome it.

A second part of Senator Scott's socialist plot theory involved the non-sale of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation. I point out that the intention of the Government not to proceed with the sale was welcomed by the permanent building societies, by the Real Estate Institute and by the Housing Industry Association- hardly a group of socialists, hardly a group of people who would be described as supporting a socialist plot to take over the whole community. Senator Scott justified the previous Government's intention to sell the organisation on the ground that it was a public monopoly. Apparently it is quite all right to have private monopolies but quite wrong to have public monopolies. We had an organisation which carried out its function effectively and acted successfully. The previous Government followed the old conservative plot that, in those circumstances, it must sell it off at all costs because nothing in the public area can be seen to be effective.

Senator Archer pointed out, quite correctly, that housing is fundamental, that the basic problem we have is to convert the needs and desires of the people to reality. The honourable senator summed up very well what I thought Mr Hurford's package was all about, but he said that the main problem in the building and housing industry is, in fact, the ups and downs in that industry, because that problem led to shortages of labour and of material and to increased prices. Many people would agree that the ups and downs in that industry are a very real problem. One of the aims of Mr Hurford's package is to lead to a situation where those ups and downs can be smoothed out. What happens in those ups and downs is that, as we get economic recovery, there is a shortage of labour and of materials and prices increase, although one would have expected that the price increases and the unreasonable prices now were more to do with high interest rates and the high cost of land because of the manipulation of land in this community.

At the moment we do not have a shortage of labour. We have people unemployed all over the place in the building industry. We have not a shortage of materials , but an underutilisation of materials and the production capacity involved in the building materials industry. I think that Senator Archer ought to go back to Tasmania and talk to some of the people involved in the timber industry in that State to see what they have to say about the problems of shortages of material and labour.

We have to overcome, to a certain extent, the ups and downs in the industry. Neither Mr Hurford nor I claim that this package will overcome those ups and downs; but it will certainly go some way towards smoothing out the capacity of young people, particularly low income people, to get into home ownership despite the vicissitudes of the economic conditions as they exist at the moment. Senator Archer is an advocate basically of what he calls the 'free market'. He is an advocate of those very ups and downs which he sees are essential in his theories to maintain a building industry. Although he complains about them, he is unwilling to take any steps, particularly by government, to even out those ups and downs.

Senator Archer was followed by Senator Jones who pointed out in very specific cases the very real difficulties which are faced by young people and low income earners in gaining home ownership and in getting the proper assistance that they need through the various lending authorities in this country. He illustrated how the provisions of this legislation will assist them.

It was a relief to hear Senator Haines say that she supported the Bills because , as she said, they do assist home owners. Also they will have the very important effect of generating employment because of the labour intensive nature of the building industry and because of the cumulative effect which an increase in the building industry has on increasing employment in other areas. She pointed out, quite rightly, that in this specific package there is no assistance for low income earners who are not buying their own homes; there is no assistance for those renting homes. But this is part of the whole package to enable a better distribution of funds; and there is nothing in the legislation that pretends to do that.

The scheme does provide for young married couples, for singles and for two or more people who decide to purchase a house together to get assistance more easily to provide the finance to obtain accommodation. People earning up to $27, 900 a year will qualify for assistance. That represents approximately $540 a week or 155 per cent of average weekly earnings. One heard an almost plaintive complaint from the other side that this was not high enough. One has to realise that this package is aimed to assist low income earners. Within the capacities of the economy with which the Government has to cope at the moment I would have considered that that was a pretty reasonable cut-off point. Under the previous Government's package, income was tested on the previous year's income.

Under this package, where the income falls because of, say, unemployment-that is, when one partner stops working-only the current year's income will be taken into account in assessing the income. I suggest that this is a benefit which should be welcomed by all honourable senators. The same income limits apply as applied under the previous scheme, but they are linked to the average weekly earnings to allow for the rise in incomes which will apply in the future. I think that the casting around by members of the Opposition in looking for arguments and points of criticism that they can make around the edges and trying to build those up into some plot to cause the downfall of our society does not stand them in good stead with the general public or the electorate in general.

As Senator Messner said, this Government would like to see an increased stock of public housing. Of course we want to, because we have 100,000 families on the waiting list for such housing. These people have very low incomes. Of course we will be making provision, directly but particularly through the States, to increase that stock of public housing. I see no objection to that action. I doubt whether many people in this community would object to that. One of the ways to do that would be to take those low income people who seek to own their own homes off those waiting lists by providing them with an opportunity to obtain finance to get into home ownership, thus taking the burden off the waiting lists for rental and public accommodation. I thought this would have been an entirely laudable aim. I thought it would have been welcomed by people in the housing industry, as it has been, by the Government, as it has been, and by the Opposition. Instead, this proposal has provoked from the Opposition the sort of carping criticism which has come forth this morning.

I remind people that the State governments in this country, both Labor and conservative governments, have been concerned for some years about these very large waiting lists and the lack of capacity of those governments to increase the stock of public housing. The States sought increased funds over the years when the previous Government was in power, but they were restricted in seeking those funds by the previous Government's tendency not to increase funds in this area and its bias against the provision of public housing for low income people.

We are taking a multi-pronged approach to the very real problems of housing in this community. We do so because of the long waiting lists in public rental accommodation, the lack of capacity of the States to provide public accommodation, and the increasing inability, for all sorts of reasons, of young people to get sufficient finance to purchase their own homes. We take this action because of the fact that in these economic doldrums times stimulation of the housing industry is one of the most effective ways of increasing employment, and assisting in the economic recovery that we need. This is so not only in the building industry directly but also in those industries associated with the building industry, those which provide furnishings and white goods and those which process the building materials-the timbers, et cetera. This is a very effective way of assisting employment and the economic recovery that we so need. It is for that reason that I welcome the fact that, despite the Opposition's criticism, it will not oppose the Bills. I thank the Senate for the speedy passage of the Bills and its co-operation in this matter which, I believe, will be of great assistance to the community as a whole.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
