HOME DEPOSIT ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1983
The Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate that it is very soon after the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) made his statement on budgetary reform in the House of Representatives last week. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Another major reform involves the presentation of financial impact statements. In future all second reading speeches of Ministers will include a statement of the financial impact of the legislation. These statements will include estimates of any significant costs, revenue and savings arising directly from that legislation where such estimates can be calculated readily and reliably.
He continued:

Ministers will also attempt to assess the impact on industry and other sections of the community when formulating legislation. While such effects are often indirect and not easily quantifiable, Ministers will endeavour to include this information wherever possible.
Is any of this information available to the Committee at this stage?

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly, in future, the practice announced by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins) will be followed in second reading speeches. The information requested by Senator Lewis is, in all cases, in the Budget Papers. I am sorry, I do not have them with me. I think that, in general, the impact on the housing industry will be what the Minister said it will be and what real estate institutes, the housing industry groups and the master builders groups said it will be. The impact on the budgetary process is, in fact, in the Budget Papers. I will obtain exact details . The outlay, in broad terms, for the first home owners scheme will be $77.7m. The outlay for the home deposit assistance scheme will be $43m in 1983-84.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes) for that information. I am aware that the information relating to the cost to revenue of the legislation is in the Budget Papers. I thank the Minister for reminding me of that. The Minister knows that I have been pressing, for some considerable time, for governments to apply their minds to the impact of legislation of this kind on industry. The Minister indicated that the Government intends spending about $120m under the First Home Owners Bill and the Home Deposit Assistance Amendment Bill. That will have a very substantial impact on the industry. The housing industry will have to gear up to enable it to cope with that amount being spent in that area. I am concerned because we will have to say to home builders 'Not only is $120m to be spent this year but it is anticipated that that sort of expenditure will go on in the future'. People in the industry cannot enter into construction arrangements, employ staff, buy new equipment such as scaffolding and other things that must be organised for the industry to cope with an increase in government expenditure because builders who build homes for people on lower incomes are different from builders who build more expensive homes. The industry needs to take note of these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I recognise that although Senator Grimes is the Minister who introduced this legislation in this chamber he is not the Minister who is in charge of these Bills in the House of Representatives. I therefore ask Senator Grimes whether the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) or his Department made any attempt to assess the impact that these Bills would have on the industry and on other sections of the community when formulating the legislation. For example , there will be an impact on local government. It will be involved in the planning and setting aside of land for the construction of these homes. There are all sorts of consequences as a result of this legislation being passed. I think that the Government should have made some attempt to assess these matters before introducing the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the risk of appearing to be carping on the subject, I ask: Does the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) intend to answer the five questions which I raised?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some difficulty in understanding why Senator Lewis has raised these matters at this stage in view of the situation in the building industry at the moment. The problems which he raised relate to the capacity of the industry to cope with an injection of $120m. I would have thought that one of the last things we should be concerned about at the moment is the capacity of the housing industry. Housing industry activity has been in a depressed condition. In fact, activity has been at its lowest level for about 20 years. In my response to the second reading debate I dealt with the decreasing level of building approvals. In fact, the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) has consulted with all sections of the building industry in the six months that he has been Minister. In fact, as a result of that consultation, there is a general approval of what the Government has done.

SPEECH.PARA: I think everyone in this place knows about the very high level of unemployment in the building industry. Senator Archer and others know about the unused capacity and the low production levels in the associated industries such as the timber industry and the white goods industry. I do not think there has been any suggestion from industry experts or from anyone else that the industry does not have the capacity to cope with this situation. In fact, the construction industry has complained for years about the under-utilisation of its capacity and of its desire to assist in the economic recovery in this country by particularly assisting in an increase in building and, in particular, in housing construction.

I turn the question back on Senator Lewis. Is Senator Lewis suggesting that the industry cannot cope? Is he suggesting, therefore, that we really cannot do something like the legislation suggests, that we must take a nihilistic attitude and say this is part of the economic cycle and we should do nothing about assisting young people to get into homes or that we should do nothing in this area at all? We need to overcome the very real problems facing low income earners in getting into their own homes not only because of their desire to do so or because of the desirability for the community that they do so but also to assist in taking the burden off the public housing area and off the public rental market.

We need to assist the economy generally and, in particular, the building and construction industry and associated industries, which are working at undercapacity, have high employment levels and plenty of reserve capacity to cope with increased activity. For that reason we have introduced this legislative package which, I repeat, is welcomed by all areas of the building industry. For this reason, above all other reasons, it should not be criticised.

I thought I answered some, if not all, of Senator Archer's questions. As I recall it, Senator Archer was concerned about what he considered to be the restrictive cut-off point for assistance-an income of $27,900. He made the point that in his view this would exclude two-thirds of people working in Canberra. We must first remember that average incomes in Canberra are higher than in the rest of the community. Secondly, what Senator Archer says does not accord with the information I have been given. In fact, something in excess of 50 per cent of people in Canberra will be assisted. We must have a cut-off point. We cannot have an unrestricted, open-ended scheme of the type I believe Senator Archer would like-that is, if he wants a program at all. We have introduced a system whereby couples will be tested on the current year's income rather than the previous year's income if for any reason one partner loses income or income falls. I think that measure will be of assistance. As I do not have my notes here to check the exact terms of the other questions asked by Senator Archer, I ask him to repeat them so that I can get information, and answer him now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee will recognise that in fact the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) clearly does not have the information to provide answers to the questions I have asked. I am endeavouring to seek reassurances for those people who enter into the building industry that the expenditure which the Government intends making under this legislation this year will continue. Announcements of this nature can induce people to enter into an industry. They make commitments; they borrow funds in order to get into that industry. If the Government then dumps them after a period they find themselves with burdens they are unable to cope with. That is why we are seeking some sort of reassurance that the Government has applied its mind to the impact of these measures on the industry and how assistance might continue.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Minister can give such a reassurance, perhaps he can then tell me whether he or the Department has made any estimate as to how many people in my State of Victoria might be expected to receive assistance under either or both of these Bills within any period. Surely the Government has endeavoured to make some assessment of numbers. The Government has allocated $77.7m to the scheme that will operate under the First Home Owners Bill. It would be of concern if home buyers or builders in the next 12 months were unable to take up the benefit of that sum of money. The Minster for Housing and Construction (Mr Hurford) has prepared a table showing the benefits available, but those benefits seem to me to have some limitations with regard to income. For example, assistance to a home buyer without any children cuts out above an income level of $27,700; to a home buyer with two or more children, it cuts out above $27,700 also. In fact, it is not really of any great benefit to persons with an income above that figure. I wonder whether the Government has made as assessment of how many first home buyers with the allowable income level will be able to take advantage of this scheme perhaps over the next 12 months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government's commitment to continuing support for the housing industry is known. I believe it is respected by the building industry in general. We cannot ignore the fact that those organisations I mentioned earlier have welcomed the changes. I suspect that Senator Lewis is doing what Senator Messner did. He is asking for me to get up in this place and give a guarantee of exactly how much will be expended in this area next year and the years following that. I cannot, nor could any responsible person, do that; but I can draw an analogy. The worst situation that can affect people who enter the building industry is a sudden pulling-out of the rug from under it by removing government assistance. The best example of that happening was what happened after the 1975 election. In fact, assistance to the building industry was dramatically removed by the previous Government and the industry collapsed. It has continued to be in a state of collapse ever since.

SPEECH.PARA: We want a program of assistance that is consistent, a program such as that embodied in these Bills. The legislation will continue to assist people and to even out those ups and downs which, as Senator Archer said, bedevil the industry . Of course they bedevil the industry; of course we want to overcome them. Senator Archer said that since 1947, when he became associated with the building industry, those ups and downs have existed and we have had to cop them. We do not think that the severity of the fluctuations to date has to be copped. Therefore, we are trying to do something about it. I am informed by officials that in 1982-83 under the existing scheme some 17,000 people in Victoria were assisted. It is estimated that in 1983-84 under a mixture of both schemes in excess of 20,000 people in Victoria will be assisted.

I told him I would do so. I thereupon asked the Usher of the Black Rod to make such an inquiry. The Usher of the Black Rod has reported to me that at about 10.20 a.m., when he made such inquiry, the Public Accounts Committee was sitting.

—by leave-In the light of precedents adopted in the Senate under the Standing Orders and the way they have been applied, this situation does raise a serious question for the Senate. I ask you, Mr President, to refer this matter to the Senate Standing Orders Committee, which I understand will meet quite shortly. That would seem to be the appropriate body to consider the situation which has arisen. I take that step only because obviously the Public Accounts Committee is relying on the legal opinions it has received, otherwise I would have thought that it was definitely and very clearly in contravention certainly of the practice of the Senate and of the Standing Orders of the Senate. That Committee has had a legal opinion that it is able to act in that way, and therefore I think it is proper that the matter be properly investigated by a committee of the Senate, at least at this stage. I suggest that the Standing Orders Committee might well consider getting an independent legal opinion.

—by leave-Mr President, I wish to make a personal explanation on this matter. A few minutes ago you reported that the Joint Committee of Public Accounts was sitting this morning when the Senate was in session. However, I wish to remind the Senate that two members of that Committee from the Senate were not in attendance after 10 o'clock, when the proceedings of the Senate commenced. One member from the Government side and I absented ourselves from that Committee at that time because of the delicacy of a confrontation which is currently before the Senate. DEBATE.TITLE: LIVE-STOCK SLAUGHTER (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983GRAIN (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983EGGS (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983EDIBLE OILS (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
LIVE-STOCK SLAUGHTER (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983
The purpose of the Bill is to allow for an increase in maximum charge imposed on the slaughter of livestock in export establishments.

This charge was first imposed on 1 July 1979 in order to recoup 50 per cent of the cost to the Commonwealth of inspecting meat for export. This Government has carefully reviewed the policy of charging for export inspection and has concluded that there are good grounds for re-endorsement and implementation of the existing policy.

It is the Government's view that cost recovery principles should apply for commercial type activities, especially where major beneficiaries of export inspection services are overseas consumers. However, in setting a recovery rate of 50 per cent from industry for the provision of export inspection for all primary produce commodities, the Government has been mindful of the fact that further efficiencies in the delivery of these services are possible of being achieved and therefore considers that industry should not be expected to pay the full cost of operating the current service.

The Government is aware that despite initiatives taken to date in the Meat Export Inspection Service which have enabled us in 1982-83 to increase productivity, there are still changes in policy that, subject to acceptance by overseas countries, may be made to improve efficiency and reduce costs. It has been decided that the cost of special training programs for inspection staff and other costs associated with achieving efficiencies in inspection practices will be excluded from the cost base on which the levy is determined.

Since 1979 the fees charged have fallen far short of recovering half of the costs of export inspection due to inflation, to changes in the services provided and to reduced throughput. In 1983-84 it is now estimated that the current rate of charge based on $1.80 for adult cattle would recover only $13 million or 17 per cent of costs.

Accordingly it has been decided to lift the effective rate for each class of livestock to the equivalent of $5.40 for adult cattle, which would recoup 50 per cent of costs in a full year. In fact because the new rate will apply for only part of the year the recovery will be in the order of $30.9 million representing 39 per cent of the costs of operating the meat inspection service.

The current maximum rates of charge specified in the Live-stock Slaughter ( Export Inspection Charge) Act 1979 prevent operative rates of meat inspection charges being increased to a level which would allow 50 per cent recovery. Accordingly, it is proposed that the maximum rates of charge for slaughter of livestock for export be set as follows:

Cattle, including buffalo - $10.80 per head Calves 40 to 90 kg dressed weight and pigs - $ 3.60 per head Bobby calves to 40 kg dressed weight, sheep, (lambs) and goats - $ 1.08 per head Other e.g. horses, donkeys and mules - $10.80 per head

The maximums have been set at twice the operative rate. Operative rates will be established by amendments to the Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Regulations, effective from 1 October 1983. This will allow for amendments from time to time of the amounts charged on the slaughter of livestock in export establishments in accordance with changes in the cost of service provided.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
GRAIN (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

This Bill is associated with other export charge bills just introduced. The purpose of this bill is to allow for an increase in the maximum charge imposed on the export inspection of wheat, oats, barley and sorghum.
This charge was first imposed on 1 July 1979 in order to recover from exporters approximately half of the total export inspection costs of these products in 1979-80.

This Government has carefully reviewed the policy of charging for export inspection and has concluded that there are good grounds for re-endorsement and implementation of the existing policy for 50 per cent recovery of costs.

The fees currently charged for grain have remained unchanged since 1981 and would fall far short of meeting half the current costs of inspection due to inflation, to changes in the service provided and to changes in throughput. It is estimated that the current rates of charge would recover some $1.3 million or 32 per cent of costs.

Accordingly it has been decided to lift the effective rate of charge for bulk and containerised grain, and reduce the rate for bagged grain in line with changes in the costs of inspection. Although the new rates of recovery will apply for only part of the year they will cover the large part of the crop and the recovery is expected to be in the order of $1.9 million or 48 per cent of the cost of providing the service.

The current maximum rate specified in the Grain (Export Inspection Charge) Act 1979 would not allow the operative rate necessary to recoup 50 per cent of costs to be established in the Grain (Export Inspection Charge) Regulations. Accordingly it is proposed to amend the maximum rate in the Act.
The proposed new operative rates to be established by regulation are:
Grain shipped for export in bulk - 16.3 cents/tonne Grain shipped for export in bags - 19 cents/tonne Grain shipped for export in containers - 73 cents/tonne
These compare with existing operative rates of 9.6 cents /tonne for bulk, 40 cents/tonne for bags and 40 cents /tonne for containerised grain.

Currently the act specifies a maximum rate for all grain. In view of the disparity in the cost of inspecting grain shipped in bulk, in bags and in containers it is now proposed to set separate maximums for each mode of shipment . The maximums proposed are:
Grain shipped for export in bulk - 33 cents/tonne Grain shipped for export in bags - 40 cents/tonne Grain shipped for export in containers - $1.46/tonne

The maximums have been established at approximately twice the proposed operative rate. This will allow for regulatory amendments from time to time of the amounts to be charged for inspection in accordance with the changes in the costs of the service and other factors such as the volume of exports.

The bill also provides for a definition of a container in order to ensure that the higher charges associated with inspection for this mode of transport apply only to what is commonly known as a re-usable container.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
EGGS (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

This Bill is associated with other Bills just introduced to amend certain export inspection charge Acts. Its purpose is to allow an increase in the maximum charge imposed on the inspection of eggs other than eggs in shell.

The charge was first imposed on 1 January 1983 in order to recoup 50 per cent of the cost to the Commonwealth of inspection eggs for export. This Government has carefully reviewed the policy of charging for export inspection and has concluded that there are good grounds for re-endorsement and implementation of existing policy.

It is the Government's view that cost recovery principles should apply for commercial type activities, especially where major beneficiaries of export inspection services are overseas consumers. However, in setting a recovery rate of 50 per cent from industry for the provision of export inspection for all primary produce commodities, the Government has been mindful of the fact that further efficiencies in the delivery of these services are possible of being achieved and therefore considers that the industry should not be expected to pay the full cost of operating the current service.

On the basis of exports of eggs in 1983-84 the operative fees specified under the Eggs (Export Inspection Charge) Regulations would recover more than half the cost of inspecting shell eggs and less than half the costs of inspecting other eggs. Overall, it is estimated that the existing rates of charge would recover $ 97,000 or 33 per cent of costs.

Accordingly it has been decided to lift the effective rate for eggs other than in the shell from $8 per tonne to $16.00 per tonne and reduce the effective rate for eggs in the shell from $11.00 per 1,000 dozen to $10.00 per 1,000 dozen. These new rates should recover half of the costs in a full year. Because the new rate will apply for only part of the year, the recovery will be in the order of $129,000 or 45 per cent of costs.

The change in charges must be seen in the context of rapid changes in inspection procedures. These are being reviewed in conjuction with industry. It is hoped to commence trialling of revised procedures early in 1984. The objective is to achieve efficiency in the use of resources and to reduce costs.

The current maximum rates of charge specified in the Eggs (Export Inspection Charge) Act 1982 prevent the operative rate for eggs other than eggs in the shell being increased to a level which would allow 50 per cent recovery.

Accordingly, it is proposed that the maximum rate of charge for inspection of eggs for export, other than in shell be set at $33.00 per tonne. It will allow for amendments from time to time of the amounts charged for inspection in accordance with changes in the cost of the service provided.
I commend this Bill to honourable senators.
EDIBLE OILS (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983
This Bill is associated with other export charge Bills just introduced. The purpose of this Bill is to allow for an increase in the maximum charge imposed on the export inspection of edible oils.
The charge was first imposed on 1 January 1983 in order to recover from exporters approximately half of the total export inspection cost.

This Government has carefully reviewed the policy of charging for export inspection and has concluded that there are good grounds for re-endorsement and implementation of the existing policy for 50 per cent recovery of costs.

The fees currently charged for edible oils would fall far short of meeting half the current costs of inspection. It is estimated that the current rates of charge would recover some $5,000 or 15 per cent of costs.

The unit cost of inspection for edible oils was initially underestimated due to the volume of throughput and the work effort involved. Frequent changes in unit export costs are common particularly where the product is minor in terms of effort and the volume varies with the season. The annual change in costs can of course be down as well as up, as is illustrated by bagged wheat export charges.

Accordingly it has been decided to lift the effective rate of charge for edible oils from $1.00 per tonne to $3.30 per tonne. The new rate of recovery will apply for only part of the year and the recovery is expected to be in the order of $13,000 or 38 per cent of the cost of providing the service.

The current maximum rate specified in the Edible Oils (Export Inspection Charge ) Act 1982 would not allow the operative rate necessary to recoup 50 per cent of costs to be established in the Edible Oils (Export Inspection Charge) Regulations. Accordingly, it is proposed to amend the maximum rate in the Act from the current rate of $2.00 per tonne.

The proposed maximum rate for inspection of edible oils is $6.60 or twice the operative rate in order to allow for amendments from time to time of the amounts charged, in accordance with changes in the cost of the service provided, and other factors such as the volume of exports.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to refer to the four Bills before the Senate and advise that whilst we do not oppose them we intend to move an amendment. I foreshadow that amendment. We are confronted in these industries by quite massive increases in export charges and, to say the least, although there are grounds on which they can be justified, they are premature from a number of points of view. Indeed, they would bring some $18m or more from the producers, from the industries concerned, in export inspection charges at a time when the industries can ill afford it, but, more importantly, at a time when the facility of export inspection is far below that which is ultimately required. In other words, the ultimate development of a first class export inspection circumstance has yet to be achieved and the industry is virtually being asked to prop up, in the meantime, what may well be, relatively speaking, an inefficient system.

SPEECH.PARA: There is certainly a measure of irony in the circumstance that whilst the export quality control arrangement received some $1.5m in the 1982-83 Budget, and that was an amount of money that was to be operated by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation in satisfying the requirements of quality control in the export industry and therefore of great importance, that money was to be followed in the 1983-84 Budget year by a further $1m. The almost incredible circumstance is that whilst the Government insists on $18m for export inspection to be taken from the industries when that inspection is not capable of being fully implemented at top level, the $1m for AMLC export quality control has apparently been denied to the industry. As I said earlier, this seems to be an extraordinary circumstance and one that we can hardly abide.

I refer to the massive increases in charges that were floated by this legislation; the inspection charge would rise by some 200 per cent, from $1.80 per adult beast to $5.40. That is an extraordinary jump in one move. It was indeed Liberal- National Party policy that ultimately a level of 50 per cent of the cost of export inspection should and could be borne by the industry. It certainly was indicated by the previous Minister, Mr Nixon, and it was naturally the policy of the then Government, that this sort of contribution should be achieved over a period and clearly with relevance to the economic circumstances of that time and to the quality and capacity of the inspection service to be implemented. The export inspection service of itself has escalated, cost wise, enormously in recent years. In 1977-78 the amount involved was $33.6m and, only six years later, the estimate in 1983-84 has risen more than 100 per cent to an amount in excess of $70m. The industry is concerned also that the inspection services available are not properly decentralised. They are, on the contrary, tending to increase their staff numbers in Canberra, which is an extraordinary circumstance for an industry that stretches throughout Australia and certainly needs a real measure of decentralised managerial control in this inspection area . The Government is asking the industry to make a greater contribution in respect of containing cost although the inspection service remains costly and inefficient. This is a circumstance that seems to me to be intolerable. Indeed, it is very hard to understand why a government would insist on such an impost at this stage. Paragraph (A) of our amendment states:
Rural industries, which are struggling to emerge from the worst drought in history, are not at this time able to bear the burden of such massive increases . . .

That is true. Although fortunately Australia's seasonal circumstance has become very much better in recent months, only six months ago this country was still struggling as a result of the worst drought in terms of intensity and extent in its history. There is no simple or quick way of overcoming a drought of the proportions of the one we have just been through. The whole process of re- establishing involves purchase and breeding. Purchase is extremely expensive and breeding is relatively slow. The retarding effect of what has happened over the last year or two is not going to be overcome in a matter of weeks. Indeed, the circumstances of the last year or two mean that a high priority will have to be put on a very costly exercise in rural Australia to re-establish a significant fodder reserve which in the last year or two has diminished to a point where it is almost non-existent. This in itself will be a costly and time consuming operation. Of course, liquidity in the industry will take some time to eventuate . However, fortunately, if the harvest is as good as it appears it may be, this may not be such a problem. Paragraph (B) of the Opposition's amendments states:

Industries should not be expected to contribute 50 per cent of the costs of Commonwealth inspection until the Export Inspection Service restructuring is completed and the Service is as efficient and cost-effective as possible.
That is the very basis of our objection to this piece of legislation. It seems quite intolerable that a massive cost should be implemented for a service that virtually does not exist.

The other matters that concern us greatly relate to the failure to consult properly with those significant and appropriate areas of the industry when determining the sort of inspection charge and capacity that needs to be developed. Consultation with the industry has been remarkable by its absence. Indeed, that is a matter that I trust the Government will take very seriously in the near future.

One other area of concern to me, the industry and the Opposition is the virtual inference that the industry may ultimately have to meet 50 per cent and even 100 per cent of the cost of meat inspection. That has not been said in so many words but there is a very strong inference that that arrangement is being considered. If it were to eventuate, we would face the exact opposite of what applies in regard to virtually all of our competitors in the meat marketing field where the total cost of meat inspection is sustained by the government of the country concerned.

With those few comments, I indicate that the Opposition believes that the inspection charge is acceptable in principle but totally unacceptable in terms of the manner and speed with which it is imposed and the way it is being developed. I move:
At end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(A) Rural industries, which are struggling to emerge from the worst drought in history, are not at this time able to bear the burden of such massive increases in charges;

(B) Industries should not be expected to contribute 50 per cent of the costs of Commonwealth inspection until the Export Inspection Service restructuring is completed and the Service is as efficient and cost-effective as possible;
(C) There is inadequate industry participation in inspection procedures; and
(D) There has regrettably not been full consultation with industry on all aspects of development of the Export Inspection Service and inspection charges'.
Sitting suspended from 12.46 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: In view of the Prime Minister's plea to the Australian Council of Trade Unions Congress this week to observe the principles of the prices and incomes accord, and the Prime Minister's statement on the same occasion that the Government would not support any rises in allowances which amounted to a disguised wage increase, will the Government now firmly oppose the ratification of the building industry and the Heinz company wage settlement agreements which are before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said in the Senate on a number of occasions that the Government would intervene in the building industry matter when it comes before the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to be ratified. That is still the position. In fact, the Government has already intervened in those proceedings. When the formal matter comes before the Commission, the Government will announce its attitude to the building industry claim.

ANSWER.PARA: With regard to the agreement in relation to Heinz, the Government has already indicated, and I have indicated here, that it will intervene in those proceedings and, consequent upon whatever decision is made by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the national wage case, will advance its submission in those hearings. It is quite clear what the nature of that submission will be. The Government has opposed sectoral wage increases outside the broad framework of the accord.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question of the Leader of the Government. Why will the Government not say-it has already told us that it will intervene- whether it will oppose these agreements?

—I am asked why I will not say what the Government's attitude will be. I have indicated a number of times that the Government is opposed to sectoral wage claims outside the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, although it has been said that certain aspects of the building industry agreement place it in a somewhat different category. However, the attitude to both those matters will be determined prior to the time when the Government puts its view to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It has to be determined , as I am sure Senator Durack will know, in light of any decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in the national wage case.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. I have received submissions from a number of groups, including the Central Commission of the Catholic Bishops of Australia, which claim that the Government's decision to abolish the nexus between the cost of educating a child in a government school and the level of recurrent grants to non-government schools is potentially destructive to non-government schools. They further claim that reducing the basic recurrent grant to some students could endanger the right of all students to a share in educational funding. In the face of these claims and similar protestations from Senator Baume, could the Minister explain the implications for funding levels of non-government schools and for the right of choice in education of the Government's decision to abandon the percentage link formula so as to still the fearful beating of the protesters' hearts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that in some sectors of the non-government schools area there have been expressions of concern about the different way in which the Government decided to allocate funds to non-government schools. However, the kinds of fears to which Senator Crowley's question referred are quite unnecessary. There is no intention on the part of this Government to take any step which would be destructive of the non-government school sector nor is there any intention to take any step which would deny to any child an adequate level of resources for his or her education.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has made decisions on funding for 1984 which have directed the limited additional resources available to the neediest schools. For most schools in group one, per capita recurrent grants will be maintained at the 1983 level. Grants for group 2 schools will be increased by 1 per cent in real terms, and those in group 3-the vast majority of the non-government schools-will receive a 3 per cent increase in real terms.

The Government abolished the percentage link formula for one very important reason. It did nothing to close the gap between low resource schools and those operating at high resource standards, whether government or non-government. The Government's needs-based funding policy will bring the greatest benefit to those schools in greatest need and over a period will close the gap.

I am now in a position to say that the neediest schools would have received less subsidy under the percentage link formula than they will under the arrangements I announced on 28 July. The Commonwealth Schools Commission has informed me that government school standard costs for 1984 have increased by 2.6 per cent and 1.1 per cent at primary and secondary levels respectively. Had the percentage link mechanism been continued for 1984, group 3 schools would have received increases in per capita grants of $18 and $12 for primary and secondary students respectively, compared with the increases they will now receive of $20 and $32 respectively. As a result of our Government's initiative, the neediest schools-those in category 3-will receive $5m more than they would have under the percentage link formula.

Senator Crowley's question also addressed the matter of the right of choice of those parents who choose non-government schools. Parents who choose non- government schools can be confident that this Government recognises their right to do so. As I have said on many occasions, this Government recognises the high standards that many non-government schools attain and values the contribution they have made and are continuing to make to the education of young Australians. However, we are a government which will concentrate its efforts on raising resource levels where they are lowest.
Finally, I would like to point out that the Government plans to implement a new funding scheme in 1985 based on advise from the Schools Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you read it more slowly?
—I will repeat that for Senator Archer as he seems to have some difficulty in hearing--
—Order! I suggest that the Minister ignore the interjections and give the answer to Senator Crowley.
—They are not interested anyway.

—I think it is the case that some honourable senators opposite are not interested in the Government's real actions or real intentions in this matter. They are much more interested in whipping up panic campaigns based on rumour and dishonesty. However, it is our intention in 1985 to have a different formula for the funding of non-government schools which will take better account of the various needs of those schools.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said before in this place-there are honourable senators here who do not want to hear it-in the development of that new formula, all sections of education will be involved. They are already involved. Consultations are already taking place with the various sections of the non-government sector. It will be a fair and equitable formula from which we will be able to continue to do what it is our policy to do; that is, to fund on a needs basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask Senator Ryan to table the paper from which she was reading .
—I table the paper.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Crowley having addressed a supplementary question to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is out of order.

—Has the Minister for Industry and Commerce seen reports that up to 10,000 more jobs will be lost in the car industry? Does he agree with that prediction? If he does, were these losses in employment taken into account in assessing the levels of employment predicted in the Budget? If Senator Button does not accept the prediction, what changes, if any, does he expect in car industry employment levels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen reports in the newspapers that certain people have said that up to 10,000 more jobs will be lost in the car industry. I can say with a fair degree of certainty that it is the intention of General Motors- Holden's Ltd, for example, to reduce its work force by 1986. In terms of that company's policy, it will involve, presumably, a substantial further loss of jobs. Insofar as other car manufacturers are concerned, I doubt very much whether one could foresee at this stage any loss of jobs. One manufacturer is putting on new employees at a fairly regular rate. A second manufacturer has indicated to me in the course of the last week or so that it will be putting on more employees. Honourable senators will appreciate that I cannot foreshadow what might happen in terms of demand for motor cars two or three years hence, but it is quite possible that there will be job losses in certain companies and there will be increased employment in other companies.

ANSWER.PARA: It is a very brave or perhaps foolish person who makes the prediction of a 10, 000 job loss with the confidence with which it has been made in some places. Because these projections for car industry employment are essentially made in respect of a substantial period, I do not think it is reasonable to say that the figure which Senator Teague cited was specifically taken into account in assessing employment implications of the recent Budget and the estimates in respect of unemployment which were predicated in the documents accompanying the Budget. A great variety of matters must be taken into account in assessing those employment figures, including the general level of demand in the economy. I think the figure which Senator Teague projected would be submerged in the context of those general calculations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. Is there not a further flow-on to component part manufacturers in increased unemployment? How does this confirmation by the Minister of increased and unexpected unemployment square with his statement last Wednesday that the alarming decline in employment seemed to have been halted?

—Of course the components industry has been affected by the downturn in the car industry. There is now very much reduced utilisation of capacity in the components industry. But it does not follow that a reduction in the manufacturing work force of the car industry-that is to say, the people who are basically engaged in assembly operations in the manufacturing plants-of necessity has any relationship to employment in the components industry. I understood the second part of Senator Teague's question to ask how I rationalise , as it were, the comments I made about the car industry and the comments which I made last week when I expressed hope that there were signs of an upturn in the employment situation. The answer has already been given to the first part of Senator Teague's question; that is, a great variety of industries and a great variety of figures have to be taken into account in assessing any general trend in employment. The car industry is only one industry.

—Can the Minister for Veterans' Affairs provide figures on the number of persons receiving each category of pension through his Department? What are the likely trends in these figures in the near future?

—The question of increases in the number of pensions was dealt with fairly substantially in the presentation of the Budget several weeks ago. In my Department a fairly substantial increase is clearly taking place in one area, that is, the service pension area. I am advised by my Department that currently some 733,000 pensions are being paid through the Department. That comes about largely because most World War II veterans have reached the age of 60 and, therefore, qualify for pensions. Some 341,000 people receive them. In reply to a question last week I indicated that potentially about another 190,000 people would become eligible when they reached 60 years of age. My Department expects that by this time next year the figure will have passed 800,000. Of course, by about 1986 there will be approximately one million pensions paid. Of the 733,000 pensions to which I have referred, 168,000 are disability pensions. It is interesting to note that that is the only section in which there is a noticeable decline in the number of applicants for the pension and the number of pensions being granted. The number of applicants declined in the last year by some 1,200. However, there is a growth in the number of people seeking a war widow's pension. I will check and let Senator Childs know the precise figures.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence and concerns the purchase for the Royal Australian Air Force of 75 F18 fighter aircraft. What is the latest information on when these aircraft will be delivered? Is it a fact that due partly to the fall of the Australian dollar against the United States dollar the cost of the aircraft is escalating alarmingly and may well approach $4 billion based on this year's currency figures, with the potential for even higher cost growth, possibly as much as double the figure when the purchase was confirmed in late 1981? What limitation, if any, exists which would control the cost in future? In these circumstances and in the light of criticism of the F18 project, does the Government still regard these aircraft as a good purchase in comparison with others available? Finally, to what extent are we committed to the purchase? Are we indeed committed to the purchase of all 75 machines or can the number of aircraft provided for in the contract be reduced?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the question as to when delivery of the aircraft is to take place is that the first two of Australia's 75 FA18 aircraft are due for delivery in the United States in October 1984. Subsequent aircraft are to be delivered from the Government Aircraft Factories at Avalon in Victoria from April 1985 through until May 1990. As to the second question about the suggested escalation in cost, the Government has agreed now to revise the total project cost estimate of $3,396m at December 1982 price levels and post- devaluation exchange rate. This represents a net increase of $969m on the original approval of $2,427m in August 1981 prices and is due entirely to the effects of inflation and exchange rate variations, offset by some real reductions in some items of the project. Despite some speculation recently, including that advanced by Senator Mason, in constant dollar terms-that is to say, real terms-project costing has not increased. Exchange rate variations, I should add, constitute the largest proportion of the increase and have affected other equipment purchases in a similar way. They need to be reflected in our outstanding liabilities to the United States and to other countries. This situation can, of course, be expected to change again over the years, hopefully in our favour. I understand that the Minister for Defence will be making a statement to Parliament later this session which will include full details of the increases.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Mason asked a further question about whether there was any possible way in which the cost burden could be limited. Every possible means to limit the burden of this very important and very costly project is being pursued and will continue to be pursued. As is usual in purchases of this kind through the United States Government under foreign military sales arrangements, the United States Government agencies involved in our program are required to develop contracts for Australia's requirements as favourable as for their own purchases. Arrangements are in place that will enable us to monitor these processes most carefully. Further, as is the case with any major defence project, the various elements of the FA18 project have been and will continue to be the subject of most thorough reviews to ensure that what is being acquired is the absolute minimum, consistent with sound defence planning.

In the final part of the question I was asked whether we are committed to purchase all the aircraft we have ordered. We do in fact want to continue with the purchase and there is no resiling from that. The situation technically is that the Australian Government has executed with the United States Government formal letters of offer and acceptance under which 75 FA18 aircraft and associated supplies and services are to be provided. There are provisions under which the arrangements could be varied if that were desirable. Whilst those provisions are favourable to the Australian Government, there would still almost certainly be some cancellation penalty in the event of any reduction. As a result and for any of the reasons I have mentioned the Government has no intention to reduce the FA18 program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Resources and Energy a question about the use of wind energy in Tasmania which I am keen to see supported. Is he yet able to say whether Commonwealth assistance can be made available for the proposal of the Australasian Wind Energy Association for a demonstration wind farm project in north-west Tasmania, either under the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council or as part of the arrangements with Tasmania following the High Court decision on the Commonwealth's stopping construction of the Gordon below Franklin Dam? Does the Minister acknowledge the excellent test results on wind velocity already obtained in the area, the employment potential of the creation of a wind generator industry in Tasmania and the benefits of developing such an alternative energy source which is already widely used overseas, the generators for which can be installed to match demand closely? Finally, will it be necessary, if the energy is to be fed into the Tasmanian grid, for such a demonstration wind farm project to be undertaken in co- operation with the Hydro-Electric Commission? If so, is there yet any sign of agreement by the Tasmanian Government and the HEC to a joint study with the Commonwealth of Tasmania's energy needs, demand and supply?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Regarding the very last point of Senator Coates's question, on the latest information I have, discussions on that joint study are still proceeding. In response to the major part of the question-whether there is any way that the Commonwealth could become financially involved in the proposal to establish the wind farm-the answer is yes, there is a way. I understand that an application for a total amount of something like $1m is currently before the relevant NERDDC committee. The provision of that amount would be spread over some two or three years. The NERDDC committee has not yet made a recommendation on that application but I have, as Senator Coates will know, taken considerable interest in the matter and made a number of inquiries.

ANSWER.PARA: There is wind data from one site going back over a number of years. There is also wind data from another site which has had a significantly higher wind velocity for one year only, which I am advised is probably enough. But more importantly there is a clear need for reliable data over an extended period on variations in wind velocities at different heights above ground level. The importance of velocity must be stressed because the formula for calculating the potential electricity production includes wind velocity squared. In other words, the difference in electricity output between a wind velocity at 8 metres per second and a wind velocity at 9 metres per second is not 11 per cent, as one might think; it is in fact over 25 per cent. So wind velocity is extremely important.

Yesterday I authorised the Department of Resources and Energy to seek discussions with the Hydro-Electric Commission with a view to funding, through NERDDC, to the extent of about $50,000 or $70,000 the collection of the required technical data on wind velocities at varying heights and sites and then to continue discussions with the HEC as to whether, probably 12 months hence, it would co-operate in a technical study for the integration into the Tasmanian grid of wind generated electricity in the north-west. I might add in closing that I also have tentative plans to study in Denmark, probably later this year, the commercial production of wind generated electricity.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the answer he gave to Senator Chaney last Thursday when he was asked about Australian Bureau of Statistics figures showing a loss of 52,000 jobs during August and the lowest labour force participation rate in 20 years. The Minister said then that he had not examined the figures and preferred to rely instead on other information to justify a claim he had made during the Budget debate the previous night. Has Senator Button now analysed the ABS figures? Does he still maintain the view that he put to the Senate on the night of Wednesday, 8 September that: 'there is every sign that the alarming decline in employment has been halted'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the speech I made in relation to the Budget I said that there were a number of indications that what I referred to, I believe, as the alarming decline of employment of recent years, had been halted. In a subsequent question to me Senator Chaney raised the matter of the lower participation rates as revealed by the ABS figures published in relation to the month of August. First of all I think it is agreed that the decline in participation rates, as revealed in the August figures, is most alarming. Secondly, I think it is agreed by a wide range of commentators that the August figures have to be seen in conjunction with figures for the preceding months and later figures which will be revealed in September or October before any definite conclusions can be drawn from them.

ANSWER.PARA: As I indicated to Senator Chaney in answering the question the other day, I think there must be a grave degree of uncertainty and disagreement, if the August figures are in fact correct, as to what is responsible for those figures. At this stage that can only be a matter of speculation. I see nothing inconsistent with what I said to Senator Chaney and what I am now saying.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lajovic Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. When Senator Button was replying to Senator Chaney, in his last sentence he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I will undertake to examine the figures and give Senator Chaney a further answer in due course.
When will we get those figures?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lajovic has in fact sought to ask a supplementary question based on Senator Chaney's question rather than his own. What I said in answer to Senator Lajovic's question just a minute ago was that it was very difficult to draw any conclusions on the basis of the lowered participation rate as revealed in the August figures. I think that implies to most people that I have examined the figures and I have drawn that conclusion; and that is the conclusion.

—Before I call another honourable senator, I should mention that there have been six questions asked so far and four supplementary questions. This is creating difficulties in calling honourable senators.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PRIMARY PRODUCTION: TAX DEDUCTIBILITY OF INVESTMENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Treasurer advise the Senate whether any representations have been received from representatives of airline company employees about the tax deductibility of investments in primary production? If so, can he advise the Senate of his response to these representations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, representations were received by me in respect of senior Qantas Airways Ltd personnel, which sought my assistance in securing an appointment with the Treasurer. The representations were conveyed through an accountant. The accountant, in a letter which I sent on to the Treasurer with a request that he consider the application for an interview, said that he was acting on behalf of 40 or more senior Qantas personnel-for reasons which will become obvious later they were clearly Qantas pilots-who were developing farms. They have been offsetting their primary production losses in the development of these farms as tax losses against the salary paid to them by Qantas. Of course, that is quite legitimate. They were also-and this was equally legal at the time- claiming a refund for tax losses incurred in their farm development investments not in the next financial year, as is normally done, but on a monthly basis, as an offset to their PAYE obligations. The accountant wrote that they were claiming, say, $2,500 a month and from 1 July would no longer be able to claim that deduction on a monthly basis. They would have to wait until the next financial year to get a refund as a result of their expenditure of, say, $30,000 over the full year by way of tax deductible investment in the farms they were developing. The point of the letter from the accountant acting on behalf of these Qantas pilots is that they want this appointment with the Treasurer to rectify the massive injustice which has been thrust upon them because they will have to wait until the next financial year to get the tax benefits from the, say , $30,000 tax deductible losses that they had incurred in developing their farms . So much for the letter.

ANSWER.PARA: I wish to make a couple of further points. First, the clear implication is that these pilots have $30,000 of income surplus to their current needs which they can invest in their farms. Secondly, the rationale for their greedy demands for tax exemption of lump sum superannuation payments is the assertion that they need those payments tax free in order to establish themselves in business following their often involuntary early retirement. We now know that at least 40 of these people have in fact been setting up their alternative businesses for retirement from their bloated salaries in the years in which they have been employed. They now have the audacity to complain that they have to wait an average of six months in order to get the tax benefits which flow from their, say, $30,000 a year tax deductible investment in farm property. The final irony- and these are the sorts of people that the Opposition supports-is that their employer Qantas, which pays them these salaries which according to the evidence produced in the letter of the accountant acting on their behalf enables them to spend $30,000 a year on farm investment, was rescued from insolvency in the last financial year by large infusions of government cash.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry to incur your wrath, Mr President, but I must proceed with this matter a little further and ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister not believe that the development of farming properties is far preferable to the development of high rise luxury apartments, as is practised by some people?
—I call the Minister representing the Treasurer to respond insofar as the question is supplementary.

—I think that there are some cases in which the development of both high rise residential or commercial buildings and agricultural properties is socially useful and defensible. Of course, there are other cases in which people become involved in them for no reason whatsoever other than to exploit the tax laws and escape their social obligation to make some contribution to the public welfare from their very large salaries. In such cases that sort of action is deplored by members of the Government. It is admired by members of the Opposition. Indeed, it was practised by some of them when they were in government.
—Order! I ask the Minister not to go beyond the supplementary question.
—It is anti-social behaviour.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. The Minister will have noted the broad interpretation of section 51 (xx) of the Constitution by Justices Murphy, Mason and Deane in the Tasmanian dam case. I ask whether the attention of the Minister has been drawn to these comments made by Mr Justice Murphy in Canberra on 5 September 1983 in a seminar on 'Changing Industrial Laws':

QUESTION.PARA: The future course of federal industrial law will, I think, show a much greater reliance on the corporations and commerce powers than hitherto.
Is this the view of the Government and, if so, how would award workers be protected from interference by this or future parliaments in matters concerning their wages and working conditions?

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the question is addressed to me in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. As Senator Harradine will be aware, the Minister has embarked on a number of initiatives in relation to both the current wage fixation system and the arbitration system generally. I had not been made aware of Mr Justice Murphy's remarks. I will see that they are drawn to the attention of the Minister and an answer obtained for Senator Harradine as promptly as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ASSOCIATED PULP AND PAPER MILLS LTD: HEALTH SCHEME

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health whether the Government is aware of representations made by an organisation known as the APPM Council, which is concerned with the social well-being of the employees of the Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd timber-based operations in Tasmania, particularly north-west Tasmania. In particular, is the Government aware of the excellent medical and hospital benefits fund, with a membership of some 3,000 persons, which has been operated for many years to the satisfaction of employees and with the support of the company? Will the Government make special arrangements to ensure minimum disruption to the present arrangements when Medicare is introduced on 1 February 1984?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Tate says, representations have been made to Government members and to the Minister for Health by APPM concerning its medical and hospital benefits fund, which is a closed fund for employees of that organisation. The fund has a very good record of providing health benefits for employees of APPM. That record has been important in cushioning the employees of the organisation against the various changes made by the previous Government to the health insurance scheme over the last seven years. Senator Tate, as a senator from that area, has been quite assiduous in making representations on behalf of the organisation to the Minister for Health. It should be remembered that in introducing the Medicare legislation the Government is not of a mind to extend to closed funds the agency arrangements which APPM would like, although it does not have a completely closed mind on the matter.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is aware also of the very real importance of this fund to the employees and of the fact that APPM subsidises the fund's operations by about $ 200,000 a year. I am sure that everyone hopes that after Medicare has been introduced the company will continue to expand the health services that are made available to its workers. The introduction of Medicare will relieve the company of some of the burden of providing basic medical and hospital benefits, thus freeing some of the resources of the company for use elsewhere. The Health Insurance Commission will take all necessary steps to ensure that the level and quality of services provided to APPM's workers in Burnie and on the north-west coast of Tasmania are not adversely affected by the introduction of Medicare. If any of the employees of the Council are affected by the introduction of Medicare they will be given preference of employment with that organisation. I am sure that the Minister for Health, with the assistance of Senator Tate, will be able to arrive at a satisfactory solution with the Health Insurance Commission and APPM in this matter. I am sure there will continue to be satisfactory co- operation between industry and government in the provision of benefits for workers which has existed for so long in the case of this company in the north- west of Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I remind him of his admission, in answer to a question by Senator Chaney yesterday, that higher unemployment would result if the unions did not stick to the prices and incomes accord. Is the Minister aware that the accord approves of wage rises outside its scope only in 'special and extraordinary circumstances'? What is Senator Button's and the Government's understanding of the meaning of those words? I ask what is the Minister's attitude to the view attributed by Geoffrey Barker in the Melbourne Age of 8 September to union officials, namely, 'everybody has a special and extraordinary circumstance, mate '.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question relates to wage rises outside the scope of the accord. I remind Senator Crichton-Browne that in Australia wages are fixed by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Government has embarked on a policy of a centralised wage fixation system and has urged the Commission, successfully, to deal with wages claims on the basis of a centralised wage fixation system. Whatever system one has in place, there are always, as I think some union official said in a pub, special circumstances which pertain to particular industries. Although Senator Crichton-Browne might be excited by this issue, it is clear that Senator Messner, who is yawning, is not. It has always been the practice of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in recent years to provide for a special procedure and anomalies provision, or something of that kind, in relation to wage fixation practices when there has been a centralised system in place.

ANSWER.PARA: I illustrate that point by saying that, before the Fraser Government irresponsibly abandoned wage fixation in 1981, with disastrous results to the Australian economy, leading to a 22 per cent pay increase in some industries the following year, there was a de facto centralised wage fixation system in operation in Australia. Throughout the period for which that system existed, basically from 1976 until its irresponsible abandonment by the Fraser Government , there was an anomalies provision in place whereby special or extraordinary circumstances could be dealt with by a bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I am confident that when the Commission shortly gives its decision in the national wage case-whatever that decision may be-it will similarly provide for special and extraordinary circumstances to be dealt with in the way in which they have been in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer the Minister to the 'special and extraordinary circumstances' provision of the accord. I relate that to the expression that is conventional wisdom in the trade union movement that everybody has a special and extraordinary circumstance. I ask the Minister: Is it not the case that the trade union movement, irrespective of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, is able, for its own benefit, from its own interpretation of the accord, to find unique, special and extraordinary circumstances?
—Order! If the Minister regards that as a supplementary question, he may answer it.

—Everybody has subjective views about these matters. If special and extraordinary circumstances are seen by some unions in some industries to entitle them to make sectoral claims outside the accord, they can do so and see how they get on.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. How do approvals for new dwellings and the demand for housing finance so far this year compare with 1982 levels? What could be the effect on the level of activity in the housing industry of the recent half a per cent reduction in home loan interest rates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —There were two parts to the question. One dealt with dwelling approvals and the other dealt with loan approvals. I am afraid that I do not have with me the figures pertaining to the second part of the question, but I do have some figures on the first part of the question. On a quarterly basis-of course figures derived on a quarterly basis are more reliable than monthly figures, as they are less subject to off-trend fluctuations-for the June quarter of 1983, as against the June quarter of 1982, new dwelling approvals were up by 5.4 per cent on average. This shows that in the housing industry the very deep recession has begun to turn around. However, it was not a uniform improvement. For example, in Queensland dwelling approvals suggest that, along with the rest of the Queensland State economy, the housing industry is collapsing. During that June quarter, dwelling approvals in Queensland fell by almost 12 per cent as against a national increase of 5.4 per cent. The story in Senator Maguire's State is very much happier. South Australia had the highest rate of increase of all the States-a quite remarkable 27 per cent increase. I might add that Queensland, as one would expect, had the greatest fall of all the States in that 12-month period. The level of dwelling approvals is not only below average in Queensland, but also lower than in any other State.

ANSWER.PARA: Regarding the one-half per cent reduction in interest rates, which has been announced generally over the last week or so, various estimates have been made as to the effect of that on demand for new housing. One estimate-one would expect it to be a reputable estimate-suggests that for every one-half per cent fall in interest rates, another 4,000 buyers will be brought into the market for housing. For those who already have loans, the effect of the one-half per cent reduction on a typical $30,000 bank loan over 20 years will be a reduction of around $10.50 in the monthly payments. As I said yesterday, the Government welcomes this downward movement in interest rates which has appeared over the last year or so. I note that not since August 1981-more than two years ago-has the standard savings bank rate for home buyers been below 12 1/2 per cent. It is now 12 per cent.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PRICES AND INCOMES ACCORD: BUILDING INDUSTRY

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does he agree with the reported concern expressed by Mr Willis that part of the building industry pay deal has a capacity to flow fairly widely to other industries? Does he agree that if that flow-on occurs it means that the prices and incomes accord has failed? What plans does the Government have to prevent the spread of this agreement, which one employer is reported as estimating is worth up to $50 a week to workers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already answered questions about this matter which cover some of the ground which is dealt with in Senator Scott's question. I do agree with the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, in expressing concern that there may be attempts to have flow on any agreement ratified by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission in respect of the building industry. The Government is concerned about that question. It is concerned with any implications which might follow from the ratification of any such agreement by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I remind the honourable senator, however, that the matter has to go to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission for ratification.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not in any position to agree or disagree with the estimates which he quoted to me about what the building industry agreement in fact meant in terms of wages for particular employees. I think that sounded a somewhat extravagant estimate. As it was not sourced, I do not propose to comment on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware that the New South Wales Minister for Health announced yesterday that more Aborigines are to be appointed to hospital boards in that State in an effort to increase Aboriginal involvement in health management? Will the Minister indicate whether the Federal Government will encourage this important initiative so that it may be followed in other States, particularly in Queensland, where, to the best of my knowledge, Aborigines are not represented on hospital boards and where Aboriginal consultation in health policy and in other matters is not regarded as a priority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not read that the New South Wales Government had taken this very excellent and constructive step of encouraging the appointment of Aboriginals to hospital boards. Having heard of it, I believe that the New South Wales Government should be congratulated for taking such a step. I am sure that my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Clyde Holding, would feel similarly, that such a step is in the interests of the development of appropriate health services in New South Wales and is an example that could well be encouraged throughout Australia and at a Commonwealth level, where appropriate.

ANSWER.PARA: I point out that in my own area of responsibility, education, I have adopted a similar policy of involving Aboriginal people at the highest levels. I have made the first appointment of an Aboriginal to the Australian Schools Commission, Mr Paul Hughes, and the first appointment of an Aboriginal to the Tertiary Education Commission, Ms Pat O'Shane. I believe, and the Government believes, that participation by Aboriginal people ought to be not only at the level of their own communities and in their own organisations but also at the very highest level of policy formulation. Only in that way will we be able to develop policies which will compensate Aboriginals for the centuries of neglect and disadvantage that they have suffered, not only in the area of health, of course, but also in many other areas.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TAXATION OF OILS, GREASES AND LUBRICANTS

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Industry and Commerce seen the report in the 3-9 September issue of Business Review Weekly that a wide range of manufacturing industries will be severely hit by the 20 per cent tax on oils, greases and lubricants announced in the Budget? Is he aware of claims that orders for these products have already been cancelled because of the tax? Will he confirm that the added cost of rolling oil and rust preventive coating oils could add up to $ 4 to the cost of a tonne of steel, with resultant flow-through costs to the rest of industry? What effect on employment will this rise have?

—I am aware of the effects that some announcements in the Budget might have on particular manufacturing industries, but I am certainly not aware of all the matters raised by Senator Hill in his question. I have not read the article in question. I will certainly endeavour, both in consultation with the Treasurer and with my own Department, to obtain an answer for Senator Hill about the details to which he referred.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is it true that, under existing taxation laws, expenses incurred by disabled people in earning a living, such as motorised wheelchairs, are not tax deductible? If so, is the Minister aware that certain added expenses incurred by disabled persons are incurred in earning a living and that the present tax regulations are a major disincentive for disabled people participating in the labour force and making their contribution to society? Will the Government consider changing the present taxation regulations to allow disabled people to claim, as tax deductions, expenses incurred by them in earning a living?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I am aware, as Senator Richardson said, that extra costs incurred by disabled people who work are not generally tax deductible. Limited amounts of assistance are available to those who are disabled-largely the mobility allowance which is fairly restricted, and the sales tax deduction which is allowed on vehicles. Certainly, some aids for disabled people are available in a limited way under government programs.

ANSWER.PARA: We have to face the fact that disability, in itself, is an expensive lifestyle, but a lifestyle not chosen by those who have it. I believe that many changes are needed to the system, not only affecting those disabled who are able to work but also those disabled who are unable to work. I think we need to look at the broad aspect as it affects disabled people.

We have to look at the fact that there are tariffs on certain products that they use. One would expect that if one needs to protect such industries it would be better done by bounty and therefore carried by the rest of the community rather than by those who have to purchase the goods. We have to look at the matter of tax deductions. Whether tax deductibility is the best way to go about it, rather than try to quantify the cost of the disability and make a positive payment for that, I think is a matter to be decided.

However, the matter raised by Senator Richardson is an important one. It is being considered by a working party in my Department which is looking at the general range of assistance available to disabled people. Not only will we look at that but also I will hand on Senator Richardson's suggestion to the Treasurer for his consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health by saying that no doubt the Minister would be aware that in some head injury cases certain nerves can be damaged, leading to the person becoming cross -eyed. No doubt the Minister would also realise that overseas the purified extract of botulinum toxin can be used to paralyse the muscles that pull the eyes crossed so that, even though the person cannot move his eyes sideways, he can move them up and down.
