Why does the Government restrict the import of this toxin when its use has been proven overseas? Must we wait until some senator or member becomes cross-eyed or suffers severe head damage before the extract is allowed into Australia?

—I am sorry to have to inform Senator Townley that, despite my extensive knowledge of medicine, I have never heard of the use of botulinum toxin to paralyse nerves in cases where people become cross-eyed as a result of head injuries or as a result of any other injury. I am afraid that I have no knowledge of restrictions on the importation of this purified toxin. I will refer that matter to the Minister for Health and seek his response.

—Is the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women aware of having been publicly described recently as the head feminist of the Australian Labor Party Government which is accused of making feminist appointments? Is there any substance in these allegations? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to assure my colleague Senator Giles that there is some substance in the allegations in that I, as a member of the Government, support and encourage moves to improve the status of women and to allow the participation of women in all aspects of public life. I am supported in my endeavours by the Government to the extent that a number of outstanding appointments have been made which could, I suppose, be described as feminist appointments, if by feminist appointment is meant the appointment of very highly qualified, able and competent women to participate in very significant activities within government control.

ANSWER.PARA: It has been a policy of the Government when making appointments to statutory bodies to aim at 50 per cent of the appointments being women. We have not yet achieved that in every case, but we are certainly moving towards that very quickly. I have a list of over 30 women of outstanding ability who have been appointed by the Hawke Labor Government to a number of very important bodies such as the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the Tertiary Education Commission, the Universities Council, the Australian Film Commission, the Economic Planning Advisory Council and so on. I will not take up the time of the Senate now by reciting the appointments we have made, but I table the list of names. I affirm for the information of Senator Giles and all honourable senators that it is the intention of the Government to secure the participation in the community of competent, highly motivated women, of whom there are many thousands . I am happy to report progress in this matter and to say that we will continue doing this until we have achieved our objective of full participation of Australian women in public life.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. I remind the Minister that, as a result of adjustments to the tertiary education assistance allowance and to unemployment benefit levels contained in the Budget, the gap between the two has worsened, causing further disincentives for further education. I ask the Minister how the widening gap between TEAS allowances and unemployment benefits will help to increase the participation of young Australians in tertiary education.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true, as Senator Peter Baume said, that there is a gap between the level of unemployment benefits paid to single persons or to youth and the level of tertiary education assistance that is paid. It is a matter of concern and regret to the Government that we are unable, because of the economic chaos we inherited from the previous Administration, to take significant steps towards closing that gap at this stage. The Government had a number of options available to it. We decided that in time of economic stringency, and given the national crisis of youth unemployment and the long-standing unemployment of many young people in our community, our first priority had to be the improvement of the standard of living of the young unemployed. To that end my colleague Senator Grimes has now made two adjustments to the single unemployed benefit. We have now increased the junior unemployment benefit by several dollars a week. In neither instance has the Government arrived at a position about which it or the young unemployed are complacent. We acted because we recognised that those young people in our community were suffering most from poverty and homelessness. We made an adjustment to the tertiary education assistance scheme which is not a major adjustment. I will not pretend that it is major; but it will enable us the next time around to make a more significant adjustment because at least the tertiary education assistance scheme has not been slipping behind as it did in so many Budgets brought down by the Fraser Administration.

ANSWER.PARA: I draw Senator Peter Baume's attention to another aspect of the Budget which has a direct bearing on our objective of encouraging participation of young people in tertiary education. I refer to the 20 per cent increase in the secondary allowance scheme. We will not make significant increases in participation in tertiary education unless we can overcome this appalling problem of low participation rates in secondary schooling. Senator Peter Baume should be aware of that. At this stage, on average only about one-third of young people in Australia complete secondary schooling. This figure is in contrast to countries such as Japan, Canada and Western European countries where up to 90 per cent of young people complete secondary schooling. Until we can get the majority of young people in a position to complete secondary education we will not be able to make very much progress in terms of increasing participation in tertiary education.

In giving our first priority to the needs of the young unemployed and our second priority to those needy families who want to keep their children at school until their completion of secondary schooling, but who need assistance to do so, I think we have acted in good faith with regard to the overall commitments of Labor. I certainly assure Senator Peter Baume that it is the intention of the Government to make further improvements in the level of assistance to all students when budgetary conditions permit us to do so.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VICTORIAN GOVERNMENT AND GENERAL MOTORS-HOLDEN'S LTD: OFFSET PROGRAM

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 August Senator Peter Rae asked me a question without notice in which he referred to comments by Mr Townsend, the Federal Secretary of the Vehicle Builders Employees Federation. It related to the Victorian Government's offset arrangements with General Motors-Holden's Ltd. On that day Senator Peter Rae asked me whether I would agree with the suggestion by Mr Townsend that I, or the Australian Government, should follow the Victorian Government's action.

QUESTION.PARA: I remind the honourable senator that the Australian Government has had an offset procurement program successfully in operation since 1970. In 14 years offsets valued at over $600m have been arranged. In the current year, offsets to a value of about $120m are available. State offset schemes are of comparatively recent introduction, Victoria last year being the first State to introduce such a scheme. In some ways it is similar to the Commonwealth program. I do not need to go into the details of the similarity at this stage. In regard to State procurement policies such as Victoria's, offset arrangements discriminate against suppliers in other States. In the case of the locomotive contract referred to by Mr Townsend, it is understood that the Victorian Government specified in the tender documents that the locomotives were to be built in that State even though Victoria did not have a locomotive manufacturing facility and there was capacity with locomotive producers in other States. I hardly need to remind honourable senators of the views which I have expressed as Minister, and which governments of both persuasions at the Federal level have expressed, in relation to State Government purchasing policies and unnecessarily moving jobs from one State to another and fragmenting the Australian manufacturing industry.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Peter Baume proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The united opposition from the whole of the non-government school sector to two central principles of Labor's non-government school funding policy.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 September the Central Commission of the Catholic Bishops of Australia released an important statement in Canberra on its assessment of some aspects of the Australian Labor Party's education policies. The statement is not terribly long and I think it important to read it out. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Central Commission of the Catholic Bishops of Australia in Canberra today vigorously re-affirmed the School Funding Policy of the Bishops as presented by their Catholic Education Commission in November 1982.
The Central Commission expressed its very deep concern over two aspects of the funding guidelines recently given by the Government to the Commonwealth Schools Commission.

The Government has decided to abolish the nexus between the cost of educating a child in a government school and the level of recurrent grants to non-government schools. This is against the Bishops' stated policy and is potentially destructive of non-government schooling. The removal of this automatic linking also minimises the capacity of non-government schools to plan.

The Bishops expressed misgivings over the decision to reduce the basic recurrent grant to some students. The right of all students to share in educational funding would be endangered if this reduction were a move towards excluding any student from a basic grant.

The Bishops re-affirmed the role of Government in relation to those in need. However, once again, they affirmed the right of every child to educational justice and the duty of Government to protect the right of parents to choose the kind of education that will be given to their children.

That document was signed by Archbishop Francis Rush of Brisbane, Archbishop Sir Guilford Young of Hobart, Archbishop James Gleeson of Adelaide, Archbishop Sir Frank Little of Melbourne, Archbishop Edward Clancy of Sydney, Archbishop Francis Carroll of Canberra-Goulburn, Bishop Douglas Warren of Wilcannia-Forbes, and Bishop Patrick Dougherty, the then Secretary of the Episcopal Conference of Australian Bishops and now the Bishop-elect of Bathurst. These bishops in fact carry enormous authority. They speak for the 45 Catholic bishops in Australia. Through them they speak for the Catholic Church in Australia; they speak for Catholic education in Australia. Their statement is an immensely significant one and is properly a matter of public importance.

May I say, Mr Deputy President, that we have confined our criticisms of the Government to some parts of its school guidelines. We have not criticised all the guidelines. Neither have the bishops. We do not reject all the initiatives the Government has taken; neither have the bishops. We have concentrated our attention, and so have they, upon two central features contained in the guidelines which are part of Labor's new school funding policy. Labor has abolished or abandoned two policies which underpinned funding for some time. The Government has a new policy for funding non-government schools. It has abolished the principle that there should be a universal basic grant for assistance with schooling for all children and, as set out in its policy, has announced that some grants are to be reduced progressively for some students. It has abolished the formula which indexed the level of grants to non-government schools-an indexation which allowed their value to be maintained as rising costs tended to take away the value of the dollar. It is comments on those parts of Labor's policy that we will highlight today. They are important areas of policy and the comments by the bishops are direct and important.

The bishops are not the only ones who have spoken out about Labor's policies. Other people to add their voices include the Anglican Bishop of Tasmania, Bishop Newell, who, in giving the presidential address to the Anglican Synod in Launceston recently, made specific reference to the inadequacies of the guidelines in terms of educational justice. He said that the sizable reductions in grants now being made would result in a considerable number of parents not being able to exercise their freedom of choice, and he went on to state:
Surely this is not the Government's intention, yet the trend is beginning to show.

He urged the Government to look very carefully and dispassionately at the education funding guidelines and arrangements for 1985. So it is not only the authoritative voice of the Catholic bishops that we have heard on this matter; we have heard also the Anglican Bishop of Tasmania, Bishop Newell, in his presidential address. The National Catholic Education Commission, representing Catholic schools and Catholic education systems, has added its voice. The National Catholic Education Commission has issued its policy, and I understand it is about to re-affirm that policy. The policy is quite clear. The Catholic Education Commission says, inter alia:

All children have a right to share equitably in the public expenditure on education. This derives from the principle of every citizen's right to freedom of choice in education. This right is guaranteed only if State and Federal governments ensure that all citizens, all children, have access to public funds for education, irrespective of the school chosen by parents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am grateful to my colleague for his interjection. In another part of the Commission's policy statement it lays on the line its acceptance of another principle-the principle of the importance of indexing the grants to allow for inflation. The Commission says it in these words:

SPEECH.PARA: Since the level of resource usage in Australian schools is set by the decision of State Governments, these de facto establish the standard for resource usage in Australian schools generally. As long as this process continues, the level of grants to non-government schools should be based on this same standard: the average cost of educating a child in a government school. Such average cost should include all elements common to both systems, whether funded from State or Commonwealth sources.

The National Catholic Education Commission has not departed from that point of view. The National Council of Independent Schools also lost no time in writing to the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, after the guidelines had been announced to make her aware of its dismay and concern about the effects that the guidelines would have upon its schools. I have a copy of that letter of almost two pages. Senator Ryan will know it and I seek leave to have the text of that letter incorporated in Hansard to save the time of the Senate.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Senator Susan Ryan,
Minister for Education and Youth Affairs,
Parliament House,
Canberra,
Monday, 22nd August, 1983. Dear Senator Ryan,
I am writing on behalf of NCIS to object to certain elements of the CSC Guidelines for 1984 and to request a delay in the implementation of these elements.

We object to the replacement of the automatic nexus (% link) between government school standard costs and per capita subsidies to non-government schools ( Guideline 30, p. 15); the reduction in grants in respect of students attending certain non-government schools (Guidelines 35 and 36, p. 16); the removal of the automatic eligibility for Commonwealth recurrent grants when schools are registered by relevant State or Territory authorities (Guideline 37, p. 17).

These changes to Commonwealth Government funding are regarded as arbitrary and discriminatory. The right of parents to choose the kind of formal schooling they wish for their children is restricted by these policies.

Funding in respect of a child will be reduced or completely withheld because a parent chooses a particular school. The principle of the basic grant is destroyed through the removal of the automatic nexus.

We do not believe that sufficient thought has been given to effects of these policy changes on children and their parents. The continual reference by you to schools cannot hide the fact that parents, who are already making great sacrifices to exercise their right of choice, will be forced to make even greater sacrifices when they should instead be receiving an equitable share, for their children, of the government funds available for education in Australia.

Labor's Policy for Non-Government Schools (16th February, 1983) promised that ' 'funding at present levels will be maintained during'' the period of time '' required to allow the Schools Commission to determine the community standard and to allow schools, in the light of that determination, to make their decision''. (Section 5 (d), p. 6).
This promise has been broken.

It was also promised that ''adjustment assistance will be provided for at least two years to ensure that no disruption occurs to the learning programme and that the rights of employees are protected''. (Section 5 (c), p. 5).
This promise has also been broken.

The concepts of ''need'' and ''community standard'' have not yet been defined. The Government should wait until this has been done, the review has been completed and an agreed scheme developed, before making any changes.
Not only do we object to the reduction in grants for the 41 schools, but also to the method by which these schools have been identified.
The 1981 data used to measure private cash income is now out of date and was collected for a different purpose to the one for which it has now been used.

We also believe that it is invalid to compare private cash income at non- government schools with expenditure at government schools because of the many discrepancies our research has revealed. We have grave doubts about the reliability of the Schools Recurrent Resources Index (SRRI) as a tool of measure .
These factors add even more to our impression that this decision and the method used are arbitrary in the extreme.

The result of these Guidelines, if implemented, will be a reduction in accessibility for the children of those parents who are already making great sacrifices. This is regarded as punitive, discriminatory and divisive.
We believe that 1984 should be a year in which no change is made to funding until the review of the present scheme is completed and, if necessary, replaced by an agreed system of funding.
Yours sincerely,
P. E. Rhoden
Chairman

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to the Senate. Senator Ryan, in answer to a dorothy dix question earlier today, made it clear that she thought she had an answer to the breaking of the nexus. She said that the Government abolished the nexus quite deliberately. The fact is that the bishops do not agree with her and the non-government school authorities do not agree with her. She says, of course , that some of the schools will be better off than they would have been under the existing formula. Is it not interesting that even in spite of an attempt, to use Aneurin Bevan's words when he talked about the doctors in 1945, 'to stuff their mouths with gold', they are determined to adhere to principle? They are not willing to abandon principle, in spite of the money which has been offered. Let me illustrate that argument. The Most Reverend John Kelly, the Roman Catholic Auxiliary Bishop of Melbourne, wrote recently to the Age newspaper. His letter said, inter alia:

SPEECH.PARA: It has been announced that cuts will be made from the so called 'wealthy' independent schools. But, note the cunning inbuilt contradiction, the money from these cuts will not be given to indigent government schools, rather it will go to 'poorer' independent schools, i.e. mainly Catholic schools.
In the face of that blatant sectarian tactic, I challenge any Catholic independent school to accept this Judas money.

I am quoting a Catholic bishop talking about the money which has been offered to them by the Australian Labor Party under the guidelines and giving his opinion of what it is worth. He describes it as Judas money. I remind Senator Ryan, since we are canvassing some of the views of the non-government sector on these elements of the funding guidelines, that Father Williams, the Chairman of the National Catholic Education Commission and the person she saw fit not to re- appoint to the Commonwealth Schools Commission, had his say in a Press release which he issued after the guidelines had appeared. While praising some parts of the guidelines, he made it quite clear that he was concerned about the Government's action in removing the automatic linking of grants to the cost of educating children in government schools. Part of the Press release states:
Father Williams said that parents and administrators in non-government schools would be concerned about the long term implications of this major policy.
But this is not all. Archbishop Sir Frank Little, in writing in the Advocate Magazine on 8 September, added his voice:

Recent government activities have shocked these independent schools. Funding to enable them to continue their present operations has been cut, with prospects of further loss. Is this the recognition of freedom? Is it the reward for initiative? Is it stifling a basic human right?
An equitable share in the public purse is fair; recognition of needs certainly, but only after a receipt of a fair, basic grant by all.
The way in which these cuts were published was also most unfortunate.

People understood that a certain amount was made available by government to schools other than state schools and that Catholic schools would be given a greater share of the cake by depriving other independent schools of their expectations.
It has been made to appear that Catholic schools have gained advantage by depriving their friends in independent schools.
What has been the result?
The Archbishop of Melbourne goes on to say what he thinks has been the result:
We now have a bitter sectarianism running riot. It has been described to me as the worst in living memory.
He concludes his article by asking:
Am I now living in a fool's paradise? Is the honeymoon over?

We cannot dismiss the views of people as significant in the community as these groups. But let us look again at what the Central Commission of Catholic Bishops actually said. First, the bishops vigorously reaffirmed the school funding policy presented by the National Catholic Education Commission. That is their position on behalf of the Catholic schools in Australia. They expressed very deep concern about the abandonment of the formula for indexing grants to rising costs. They expressed misgivings over decisions to reduce the basic grant to some students. They affirmed that the breaking of the nexus is against the bishops' stated policy. They declared that the breaking of the nexus is potentially destructive to non-government schooling, and they went on to declare that it minimised the capacity of schools to plan. They also expressed misgivings over the decision to reduce the basic current grant to some students, and they went on to reassert:
The right of all students to share in educational funding would be endangered if this reduction were a move towards excluding any student from a basic grant.

This is as important a group of community leaders as one could find. The archbishops and bishops on the Central Commission speak on behalf of all 45 Catholic bishops in Australia. They speak for the Catholic education system in Australia. They speak for six out of every seven children in non-government schools throughout Australia. Far from regarding the proposals as likely to help Catholic education, as Senator Ryan keeps trying to assert, they, the people who are the potential recipients of this 'help', are rejecting them. They see it in opposite terms. They see it as a threat. They see it as threatening the future of the systems for which they are responsible. They fear for their future. They are not willing to put aside the principles on which the welfare of non- government schooling has been built.

Some people may wish to assert that among those who have objected are those who have a direct vested interest, those who may perhaps be parents of children at one of the 41 schools on the hit list. Their objections need to be looked at. Perhaps one could argue for a vested interest, but in the case of the bishops there is a statement of concern from a basis of principle. They have spoken out, in spite of the inducements offered to them in lieu of the guarantees which have existed under our policies and up to this time, on behalf of principle together with an Anglican bishop, other Catholic bishops and representatives of the non- government schools. The Australian Parents' Council has spoken out on behalf of parents of children in non-government schools in Australia, as has the Council of Independent Schools. I cannot find a non-government group of significance that has spoken out and applauded the breaking of the nexus or the reduction of the basic grant.

The principles which we are seeking to examine today and about which there has been so much adverse public comment are the right of every child to some support from the Government and the necessity to index the grants so that as costs rise in the community so do the grants as a matter of course. The Australian Labor Party and the Minister would have us believe that all is well. The bishops, the non-government authorities, Catholic and Anglican, and the parents' groups do not agree. They do not believe that the short term advantage, 'stuffing their mouths with gold' which the Minister offers, justifies the abandonment of principle which has grown up over many years. Let me say again, we are not suggesting that everything in Labor's education package is bad. Of course it is not. We agree with much of Labor's education package. We agree with many of the programs. I recognise some of them as initiatives which I was developing; some of the others which are new initiatives we welcome because they will help education and will help children.

On these two central matters of principle, I put it to the Minister that she and her Government are wrong. They have taken a wrong turning, and the views of significant groups in the community are properly matters of pubic importance. It is proper that when those views are put before the public we bring them here and as part of a discussion of a matter of public importance make them known to the wider community. This matter of public importance has mentioned two important principles. It mentions the support which has been attracted from groups in our community. Community concern is important, especially as important a set of concerns as those expressed so firmly by the people I have quoted today. Since some of them stood to gain in the short term, their rejection of what has been offered becomes more significant and more important. Any government seeking to develop education would want to take these expressions of concern to heart and consider them carefully. In the long term interests of children and education, in the interests of non-government schools and in the interests of equity, I invite the Government and the Minister to listen to what the bishops have had to say and to think again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance alleged to be so by Senator Peter Baume, who has brought it forward couched in the hyperbole for which he is notorious. I must say that what he has had to say has done nothing to change my view that his main interest in this matter is not in education, whether it be for the education of children in schools for which bishops are responsible or education in any other schools. His concern is to provoke and to whip up a spurious campaign of fear based in many cases on deliberate misunderstandings of what the Government's decisions have been and the principles on which they are based.
—Have the bishops done this?

—I will address myself to the matters raised in the bishops' statement later on in this debate but undoubtedly, excluding the bishops, there are a number of people who have mischievously misinformed people, and Senator Peter Baume is one of them, about what has actually been decided and what the Government's intentions are. I should say also that the terms in which the matter of public importance is couched and the way in which Senator Peter Baume has presented it to us is another example of the poverty of thought and principle which has characterised the education policies of the Liberal Party, whether it has been in government or in opposition. The Liberals have never had an education policy. During the seven years they ran this country they did not have an education policy. They simply had a funding policy and, having heard from Senator Peter Baume today, it is clear that the Liberals still do not have anything that approaches an education policy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Peter Baume said in passing that he and his colleagues are not critical of everything in the education guidelines. It is all very well to say that in passing, but I think the Australian public has a right to ask why it is that Senator Peter Baume and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney), when he chooses to speak on education, which is rare enough in itself, concern themselves solely with some funding arrangements which have affected, in a negative sense, only 41 schools in this country. Why do they not address themselves to the real and basic problems and issues that are facing educators, parents and teachers throughout this country. Why has Senator Peter Baume paid no attention at all to the major new initiative of the Hawke Labor Government, the participation and equity program which is designed to overcome the dreadful disadvantages that two-thirds of our young people in secondary schooling, whether they be in the government or non-government sector, are suffering from. Why has he not addressed himself to the initiative whereby we have earmarked capital funds for the upgrading and improvement of schools serving the poor populations in inner city areas, be they government or non-government schools. No concern has been expressed by Senator Peter Baume about this, and of course he took no initiative in that direction himself when he was in charge of this portfolio.

Why do we not hear from Senator Peter Baume about the steps we have taken to assist the Catholic education system in its expansion, in its provision of schools in new areas, about the way in which we have incorporated the new places program into our capital program for non-government schools or about the way in which we have streamlined and improved planning procedures so that the planning of non-government schools in new areas throughout Australia can proceed in an orderly and equitable fashion? There was nothing of that from Senator Baume. Of course, there was nothing about special initiatives such as our initiatives to overcome the disadvantages suffered by girls in the school system.

Most surprisingly, and perhaps most disappointingly, there was not one comment from Senator Baume over our major initiative in Aboriginal education. Senator Baume, as honourable senators may have good cause to have forgotten, was previously the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, yet what account did he take then of the fact that, in parts of Australia, there is no secondary schooling available for Aboriginal students? In the whole of the Kimberleys region, in many parts of the Northern Territory and in the Torres Strait Islands, Aboriginal communities have no secondary schooling at all for their children. We have taken initiatives in the guidelines to overcome that. But there has been not a word on those aspects from the former Education Minister and the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

I think it is important to put into context the concern with which Senator Baume comes so hypocritically into the debate today. He has chosen to concentrate on the views of the non-government sector and he has chosen to say that there is united opposition to our educational program from the non- government sector. I would just like to refer to a few facts which refute that exaggerated and very mischievous claim. I should say first that, in making these claims, I am not merely relying on correspondence or public statements. I have spent many, many hours of every week in consultation with non-government schools authorities, including the National Catholic Education Commission, the Catholic education commissions of Victoria, New South Wales, Western Australia, Queensland and South Australia and, of course, with the Australian Parents Council, the independent schools Associations and other bodies representing Catholic schools.

As Senator Baume has so assiduously ferreted out snippets of statements and so forth that seem to support his point of view, I would just like to balance the record with some of the statements which came directly to me from the non- government schools sector in response to our guidelines. First of all, I would like to read a telegram from the Reverend Father Doyle, the Director of the Catholic Education Office of Victoria, who telegramed me immediately after the appearance of the guidelines and said this:

Commend you and your Government on budgetary provisions for 1984 to meet needs of Australian children. Balance in guidelines between government and non- government schools should forestall divisive debate.

The telegram continued. Unfortunately Father Doyle's optimism must be undermined now by the efforts of Senator Baume who is intent on provoking a divisive debate . That is Father Doyle's point of view.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the bishops?
—Tell us about the bishops.

—I have the formal response from the Chairman of the New South Wales Catholic Education Commission, Archbishop James Carroll-I have the documents available for tabling; I do not have time to read them all but, they are available in toto to be perused-who writes:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator Ryan,

As already intimated to you, the many positive initiatives of the Guidelines have given great encouragement to all concerned with the quality of schools and with the particular needs of the present time.
In the specific comments attached to Archbishop Carroll's letter, we find this:
The guidelines contain many initiatives which should redound to the benefit of education in both government and non-government schools.
I congratulate the Archbishop on his concern for all children and not just children in one sector. Included in the specific guidelines is the following statement:
Some of the thrusts of the Guidelines which are of significant importance in the future development of education are welcomed as evidence of long-range objectives.
I draw Senator Baume's attention to that since he seemed to think there was a long-range problem. Further, the guidelines provide:

A greater stability in the organisation and future planning of schools in assured by the introduction of triennial funding in some areas, forward commitment in others and the reintroduction of retrospective cost supplementation.
The guidelines continue:

It is noted with satisfaction that additional capital funds are being made available for government schools and that, in the case of non-government schools , the government will provide continuing capital and recurrent support for the establishment of new non-government schools.
The following statement is made also in the guidelines:

. . . it has been thought opportune to bring to the notice of the Minister and of the Schools Commission the deep concern felt by many parents that the rearrangements announced already have hidden implications and are but the prelude to such all-round reductions as would inhibit the present maintenance of non-government schools and the modest expansion which is being achieved.
This Commission does not accept this view and it is clear that the Guidelines issued by the Minister should be sufficient to dispel such fears.
The guidelines continue:
I have available from Mr J. V. Faulkner from the Catholic Education Office of Victoria a letter which says:
Dear Senator Ryan,

I write to you personally and as a Schools Commissioner to commend you and your Government on the quality of the Commonwealth Schools Commission Guidelines for 1984. They represent a clear indication of your commitment to improved education for all Australian children and your particular concern for those most in need of additional resources for their education.

It is my hope that a major achievement of the guidelines will be to forestall the divisive debates that have occurred in the education community over recent years. The reasonable balance of funding for government and non-government schools should ensure that result.

It is very clear from those few statements that I have drawn to the Senate's attention today that there is no united opposition to the guidelines presented by the Government, that there is in fact a very sensitive, thoughtful and responsive support running right through the non-government sector for these guidelines, as indeed there should be.

With respect to the bishops' statement, I am replying, of course, to the bishops collectively and individually. However, I should say this: When they made their statement they did not have available to them the information which I have given to the Senate today which shows that the new formula which we have devised gives $5m additional support in comparison with the percentage link to the schools in category 3. This is not, to use Senator Baume's ludicrous hyperbole 'a stuffing of mouths with gold'. This is a genuine act of redistribution by a government which is concerned to raise the level of those schools which are unable to provide satisfactory educational opportunities to their children.

TALK.START.PARA: —People don't believe you, Senator. They just don't believe it.

—Senator Baume chooses to try to mount a campaign to undermine that . But people who are running schools, people who are concerned for the education of children, know that there are very large gaps in the level of resources available to most children and the level of resources available to a few privileged children. They are concerned that these gaps be overcome and they know that the approach that we are taking will achieve that in the long run.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the bishops' statement does not acknowledge the fact that there was never any certainty in advance of trends in standard costs and, therefore, no certainty about future levels of grants. I can understand the bishops having grown committed to the percentage link since that was all they were offered for the last seven years. I can understand that they took a measure of security from the fact that at least they had a certain percentage. But they had no security about what that would mean in terms of improving standards in their schools and they certainly could not look to any closing of gaps between the schools for which they are responsible and the schools whose standards we agree are adequate or more than adequate.

The bishops, of course, form an independent body. They are, as Senator Baume says, an important part of our community. they are entitled to develop their own policies and to change those policies as circumstances change. But we, the Government, do not have our policies for education or anything else determined solely by one particular group. We have to develop policies that accommodate the needs of all children throughout Australia. We have done that. We take account of the views of the bishops, the teacher unions, the various parent organisations and so on throughout the community. I will certainly address myself to the matters the bishops raised. I will discuss these matters with them when an opportunity is arranged. But it is really quite remarkable that Senator Baume seems to suggest that the Government's entire education policy should be directed by the views of a group of people, important as they are, important in the provision of education services as they are, who, nonetheless, do not represent all of education in this country.

I proceed to comment in some detail about something that still seems to elude the Opposition whether by accident or design. I wish to clarify what was involved in the percentage link policy and why we chose to develop a better and fairer formula for the funding of non-government schools. It must be stated clearly that the percentage link-that is, a formula whereby a certain amount of funding was allocated to non-government schools-is not in itself a moral principle, is not in itself a theological principle and is not in itself an educational objective. It is simply a formula which the previous Government developed to achieve certain objectives. On the other hand, the principles under which our formula is worked out and will be further refined, as I described to the Senate at Question Time today, is based on proper principles such as needs and equity. They are both principles from which our funding formulas will be developed.

It would be a relief to everyone concerned and would contribute to informed education debates if we could talk about principles and not about certain mechanical formulas as if they had been handed down by some divine right. The problem with the percentage link was that it was a formula for funding schools which gave the same percentage increase to all non-government schools regardless of their different needs. Those non-government schools in group one with the highest resources got the same percentage increase as all other schools. The percentage link at best only perpetuated the gap between the recurent resources of the great bulk of non-government schools and those, on average, in government schools. After almost a decade of Commonwealth funding of non-government schools , that gap has not been reduced. In 1974 the gap between Catholic schools and government schools was 21 per cent at the primary level and 27 per cent at the secondary level. By 1981 the gap had in fact increased to 29 per cent at both levels. Is it any wonder that a government concerned with equity, needs and redistribution should find that that formula was not doing the job and should find, in consultation with the various interested parties, that it could develop a better formula?

With respect to those 41 schools whose generous Commonwealth grant has been reduced very modestly, I wish to offer some clarification. The remarks of Senator Baume and some of his henchpersons would seem to suggest that the 41 schools will be thrown into absolute financial and administrative chaos because of the modest reductions. What were those reductions? Any of the 41 schools-lets us remember that we are talking about schools which operate well above the standards established as reasonable for all schools-would receive cuts of $84 per year per primary student and $134 per year per secondary student. Even if those schools felt that they had to adjust fees to recoup that lost revenue entirely-there is no evidence that they do, that they will do or that they cannot engage in some internal redistribution, which I know some of them do-by how much would they have to raise their fees? They would have to raise their fees by $2 per week per primary school and $3.35 per week per secondary school. I really do not believe that even Senator Baume could pretend that such a minor adjustment would throw the planning and administration of these schools into absolute chaos. Let us have some rationality and objectivity on what has become a very heated subject.

I also point out that non-government schools receive a whole range of publicly funded educational support systems. Not only do they receive the recurrent grants, which have been the subject of my remarks today, and the capital assistance to which I have also referred though not in any detail, but also they have access to the joint programs of the Commonwealth Schools Commission and to the initiatives of the Hawke Labor Government. For example, under the new participation and equity program, non-government schools will receive a 20 per cent increase on the old transition program. In the computer education program, which is a new program, they will receive $1.2m. As I have said, they have received an overall increase of 1.3 per cent-that is, 3 per cent for the neediest non-government schools. That represents a total increase of $9.5m in those programs alone on last year. In addition, of course, there is the retrospective cost supplementation. Some of the criticisms of our policy have been concentrated on the problem of planning, and I am extremely sympathetic to those problems, as is the Government. For that reason we have taken the very important step of committing ourselves to retrospective cost supplementation which is the single most important contribution to rational and orderly planning that a government can make.

We have also reactivated the National Curriculum Development Centre which, before it was cut off by the Fraser Government, was of great benefit to the non- government school system. That decision has been widely-I may even borrow a hyperbole from Senator Baume and say universally-endorsed by the non-government school sector. In addition, the Commonwealth provides grants for teacher training for non-government schools-a total of $16m in recurrent grants for 1984 . That amount is for teacher training colleges which train teachers specifically for non-government schools. Of course, as honourable senators will be aware, the vast majority of teachers teaching in non-government schools are trained at public expense in colleges of advanced education and universities, which are publicly funded. There is a vast range of ways in which public support is given to children in non-government schools.

In conclusion, I wish to say that it is extremely disappointing to the Government that, at a time when we have some very real and fundamental crises and problems in education, at a time when we are trying as a nation to encourage the development of skills and education throughout the community so that we will not have the awful problem of a growing army of poor and unemployed, the best we can get from the Opposition is this constant harping about a few schools. We have no criticisms of those schools. They are operating at this stage at a level which did not justify in our view the very substantial Commonwealth funds that they were getting. The modest adjustment to those schools' arrangements has become the preoccupation of the Opposition so that all other education issues have been neglected.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing today this matter of public importance raised by Senator Baume:

SPEECH.PARA: The united opposition from the whole of the non-government school sector to two central principles of Labor's non-government school funding policy.

I believe that, in any genuine debate in this area, to suggest that the whole of any particular sector is behind, either for or against, a particular policy is taking things to the extreme. Certainly this area is one which has caused an enormous amount of concern, worry and anxiety for as many years as one unfortunately cares to remember. It is a bit like the old western moves. We go round and round the same track year after year, and still we do not progress to a satisfactory position. With the change of government, we have seen some schools benefit and other schools lose some of their funding. If there were another change of government, the reverse would be the case, and so it would go on. Ultimately, I believe that the only way out is for all parties to consider what might be the fundamental principles necessary in funding school systems in Australia.

The first principle that one has to accept is that there has to be a differentiation in funding for schools. The only way to achieve equity in a schooling system is to have differentiated funding. Some schools doubtless care for and look after many more children with problems than do other schools. If one wishes to give the children in those schools equal opportunity, the only way to do it is by giving those schools a different amount of funding to go about that task. Hence that first principle is incompatible with the notion of a basic grant for everyone. It is just not possible to pursue that first principle and to hold out that there ought to be equality of grants to all. That, of course, applies if one is looking at funding of schools. The alternative is to look at funding of children to undertake education.

An unfortunate aspect of the education debate in Australia for many years has been the notion that schools can achieve social equality. The schooling system does not have and has never had that capacity. It is a fallacy which is perpetrated not only by people who have a vested interest in it but also by many people in the education sector. The schooling system does not have the capacity to bring about that social reform. The social inequalities which exist in our community must be dealt with by broad social policies. The thought that the manipulation of funding to schools will actually have a fundamental change on the inequalities which exist within our social structure is a pure myth but it is a nice comforting myth. To pursue the opposite is a much more difficult and probably almost impossible task. Therefore, there are vested interests in pursuing the myth that by concentrating on the schools we can fix up most of the problems from which our society suffers. It is a conservative policy, a conservative ideology of the worst kind, which suggests that the children will reform the society of which the parents and adults have made such a mess. There can be no more conservative type of ideology than that.

If we are looking at funding the schools-this seems to be the settled way that this debate has gone on both sides of the House-we have probably passed up the possibility of raising the notion of the funding of children and individuals to pursue education in a very broad sense. It is disappointing that this debate is lacking in that sense. It could have enlivened this particular debate. I would like to concentrate on the area on which the previous speakers have concentrated -that is, on the funding of schooling systems themselves. I would like to point out that indeed we will never achieve a reasonable level of agreement while we continue with the notion that we have got two fundamentally separate schooling systems. We have at least three operational systems in this country to start off with.

I want to suggest a classification which may point towards a solution in this area. The first classification which one has to accept-any honourable senator who knows anything about the way in which schools function will accept this point-is that of the private schools. They are referred to in many States as GPS schools-greater public schools. Some are called wealthy schools and some are called top private schools. There is a variety of classifications. They tend to be schools which are either grammar schools or schools developed by the Lutheran Church or the Church of England. Included in that group are some Catholic schools. Undoubtedly those schools have had the largest amount of recurrent expenditure and expenditure on capital equipment available to them for a considerable amount of time.

The next group comprises the government schools. I am talking basically of the secondary school level because the short time allotted to me in this debate will not allow me to talk about the primary school level. Government schools are the next group of schools in terms of recurrent and capital expenditure. The third group covers the Catholic parochial system, the so-called systemic schools that are generally run by the Catholic Education Office in each State. Traditionally they have had the poorest capital and recurrent resources. As the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) pointed out, that gap has really not changed very much over the years. In fact, under the previous Fraser Government that gap increased. That is a disappointment to those of us who believe that we ought to look forward to being able to give an education to every child at a level commensurate with the ability of the community to pay. As far as possible every child ought to have an equal opportunity to enter life in the community. The fact is that this has not occurred under the present structure, and it did not occur under the Fraser Government's structure. I do not believe it will occur under the present Government's structure, because all we see happening is a constant tinkering with the problems on the periphery.

Ultimately, I believe that if we want to look forward and try to get away from the acrimonious debate of the past we will have to do two things. First, somehow or other we will have to convince the troglodytes who run the State education systems throughout Australia that they have to free the state school system, that the state school system must have more parental involvement and must be given the ability to control larger amounts of its own budget and the ability to make projections of capital expenditure and recurrent expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hiring and firing?

—Yes. Senator Peter Baume has raised the question of hiring and firing. I believe that we will have to look at the involvement of schools more in the employment and the dismissal of teachers. I have had discussions about this matter with the teachers' unions and I do not believe that great difficulties are necessarily faced in that regard. There are many ways in which the rights of teachers could be protected and rights could be given to the parents and schools-rights which do not currently exist. That is one area of development whereby the state school system could partake of the very real advantages experienced by the non-government school sector in relation to the length of time teachers remain in a particular school and the ability of the teachers and parents to have a more effective say not only in the buying and disposal of footballs and cricket bats but also in the day to day educational tasks of the school.

SPEECH.PARA: On the other hand, I think that ultimately private schools will have to look at their basic principle. The basic principle to which private schools hold is choice. I support that principle. If one wants to analyse choice one has to be very careful if talking about public funds. The crux of the problem as I see it, from the point of view of public policy, is that if an institution is receiving the bulk of its recurrent funds from a public source there needs to be a fair amount of public accountability. That is already required of private schools. I believe that, with one or two changes that could be introduced effectively to the satisfaction of most people in the community.

The other factor is the right to go into those schools and the rules governing who can be expelled from them. Essentially a publicly funded institution, as a matter of policy, should have public entrance and public exit rules. To allow private schools-we have many private schools in this country and I have visited many of them-that are funded in recurrent terms at a level in excess of 90 per cent the right to have total control over entry requirements cannot be squared with the basic principle of public policy. I do not believe-I am sure that people involved in the non-government sector would not say this publicly and I have had discussions about this matter with many groups in the private sector in the past 18 months-that ultimately they would back away from that hard choice.

Let us examine what would happen if we did go down that road and look at having three categories of schools. Basically, private schools receive the bulk of their funds from their own sources, can look after themselves and do what they like. Government schools are totally funded publicly and must agree with the rules that are laid down by any particular State. I believe there is a third category. For want of a better term it could be called assisted schools. Assisted schools are those which are developed by various groups in the community to pursue certain ends. I fully support that concept. I do not support it only in the area of religion; I support it in the area of other educational philosophies.

I believe it is a lack in the educational system of this country that we do not have a large variety of schools promoting different types of educational philosophies. Many private schools promote different religious beliefs and that is to the good of a community such as ours. I believe it ought to go further; there ought to be a wider range of choice. For example, if parents have a child who has particular mathematical attributes they could send that child to a school that had a particular interest in mathematics and computer education. I believe that would be to the benefit of this country and enable progress to be made that I think all honourable senators would wish the country to make. If that were able to be done, we would need to have assisted schools that abided by the state regulations in terms of their entrance and exit criteria. They would have to abide by all of those various regulations laid down by the state yet still be able to pursue their particular educational philosophies, whether that be of a purely educational kind or connected with a moral or a philosophical input from a religion or some other grouping.

We need some debate for us to decide where we should go to bring both of our major systems together rather than constantly look back over our shoulders at the acrimony of the past. We should look ahead. For example we could have a summit of all the people in this area who I believe have the interests of the pupils at heart. If we could sit down as rational and reasonable adults and make a decision, surely this country would be far better off than continuing a debate that is divisive, which does not do anything for schools, which demoralises our education system and which, worst of all, finally has a very seriously detrimental effect upon the education of all children in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to deal with the points just made by the previous speaker, Senator Macklin. Suffice it to say that at a future time I would like to canvass some of the issues that he has raised. I do not agree with many of them, but it seemed to me that the conclusion to which he must inevitably come is not a bad one. When he was talking about a true freedom of choice for a student to be able to go to a school of the parents' choice, be it because that school specialises in advanced technology or some other such factor, he appeared to adopt the idea of a voucher system for parents. That is not a bad idea. Recently, Dr Peter Carnley, the Anglican Archbishop of Perth, made this comment:

SPEECH.PARA: If we had a voucher system parents could cash the voucher at whichever school they wanted their children to attend.
One of the advantages of this system would be to allow a choice among government schools, as well as between state and private schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —I canvassed that at the beginning of my speech.

—I am sorry, I did not know the honourable senator had. That certainly is an interesting concept and it may well ensure ultimately that the taxpayers' moneys are returned to them in some form. After all, we are talking about the taxpayers' money. We are not talking about public moneys but the moneys that have been paid by the parents of the students. I think that could be dealt with in a future debate. We are now considering a matter of public importance, namely:

SPEECH.PARA: The united opposition from the whole of the non-government school sector to two central principles of Labor's non-government school funding policy.

I believe this is an important debate, not just for the non-government school sector but also perhaps more importantly for the government school sector. If the end result of the guidelines is uncertainty in the non-government school sector we will see further pressures being placed on the government school sector by the transfer of students from the non-government school sector to the government school sector. Of course, that will eventually dawn upon the people who are pushing these new guidelines. Let me put certain facts on the record. The first is that parents have a prior right to send their children to the school of their choice. That is a right enshrined in the United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights. Secondly, when we are talking about public funding and guidelines for public funding we are talking about taxpayers' money. Parents who send their children to non-government schools have the privilege of paying twice for their children's education. The Australian schooling budget does not pick up the tab.

In supporting this matter of public importance I do not suggest that the previous education system was absolutely perfect. Let me give honourable senators the figures. In 1981-82, 86.8 per cent of the Australian schooling budget was spent on government school children, who represented 76.1 per cent of all students. In contrast, 13.2 per cent of the Australian school budget was spent on students attending non-government schools and those students represented 23.9 per cent of the total student population. We are talking about a cake which already has diminished in size and we are talking about guidelines which are cutting a nexus of funding which is calculated according to a percentage of what it costs to educate a student at a goverment school.

As the matter of public importance states, the non-government school sector is opposed to two central principles of the Australian Labor Party's non-government school funding policy. The two central principles are these: Firstly, to abolish the nexus between the cost of educating a child in a government school and the level of recurrent grants to non-government schools; and, secondly, the decision to reduce the basic recurrent grant to some students. There has been united opposition. The first time the parents were able to express themselves was here in Canberra, and what did they have to say? At a meeting of 700 people on 16 August in the Albert Hall and at a meeting of 900 people on 18 August the parents carried motions which included a demand for the Government to restore the nexus between per pupil grants for non-government school children and to re- establish a federal basis grant for all children attending non-government schools, and that this grant be tied to the cost of educating children at government schools. That is what the parents said.

We have heard what a number of other people have said about it, including Bishop Newell and the Central Commission of the Catholic Bishops of Australia, who expressed very deep concern over these two apsects of the funding guidelines . They said that the abolition of the nexus was against the bishops stated policy and potentially destructive of non-government schooling, adding:
the removal of this automatic linking also minimises the capacity of non- government schools to plan.

Further aspects of the guidelines, which are relevant to this debate, appear in the commentary by the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) entitled 'Participation and Equity-Funding Guidelines to the Commonwealth Education Commissions for 1984', which was issued on 28 July 1983. In the very first paragraph, the commentary states:
These guidelines also reflect the Government's intention to shape policies in ways consistent with its social, educational and economic goals.

Having regard to what the non-government schools sector is saying, is it a social goal of the Minister to reduce the role played by the non-government education sector? That is a question to which she should respond in this Parliament. That is the end result of applying a policy guideline such as that. Later, in paragraph 5 of the guidelines, reference is made to 'social equity' as a policy objective of the Government. What is equitable about a reduction in grants to 41 non-government schools and other moves to hamstring such schools? It has been suggested that certain schools, on a basis of need, require additional funding. Under current guidelines that can already be provided. Another objective of the new guidelines is claimed to be: 'to restore stability and predictability in funding arrangements for Government and non-government schools'. How does that tally with the statement of the Central Commission of the Catholic Bishops of Australia that: 'The removal of this automatic linking also minimises the capacity of non-government schools to plan'?

What the Minister has expressed in her guidelines is quite contrary to what was indicated clearly by the then shadow Minister for Education, Mr Chris Hurford, just prior to the last election and accepted by so many of us. In the words of the New South Wales Teachers' Federation, she has taken the first anti-state aid step taken by any government over the last two decades. As I said during a previous debate, I believe that parents of children at some of the schools that will benefit temporarily will not wish to be drawn into the sectarian vortex that has now been created by Senator Ryan's guidelines. The sectarianism which previously surrounded the debate on so-called state aid has now raised its ugly head by reason solely of Senator Ryan's guidelines, which attempt to divide and conquer the non-government school system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -This afternoon the Senate is debating the following matter of public importance submitted by Senator Peter Baume:

SPEECH.PARA: The united opposition from the whole non-government school sector to two central principles of Labor's non-government school funding policy.

The Minister for Education, Senator Susan Ryan, clearly outlined a little earlier the fact that the united opposition to which Senator Peter Baume has referred just does not exist. As well, Senator Macklin remarked that to say that all of one particular group is for or against a certain Government policy is to overstate the case. It was certainly overstated in the matter of public importance that was submitted to us. That being the case, should this matter be debated further? That question was raised at Question Time this afternoon by my colleague Senator Crowley. It certainly need not be debated further in order to indicate the fallacy of Senator Peter Baume's proposition. Nevertheless, this whole debate is well worth pursuing so that certain aspects of the Hawke Labor Government's forthright approach on education in Australia can be examined.

It should be remembered by all honourable senators, and certainly is by most people in the education sector in Australia, that the largest boost to Commonwealth education occurred during the period of the previous Labor Government, 1972-75. Prior to that period certain funds were made available for education by governments but the boost given during that period really put the Commonwealth Government in a prominent position in relation to education in Australia. In general, recent governments have funded education in line with the community's expectations, as developed during the term of their predecessor the Labor Government. However, on attaining office the Hawke Government realised that, because of certain creeping effects of the seven years of Fraser Government education funding, some changes were necessary.

I want first to address myself to the relative funding of government and non- government schools and, in particular, to look at the policies introduced in the period beginning in 1976, after the Fraser Government came to office, and ending some time earlier this year. Since 1976 there has been a substantial shift in Commonwealth funds from the government to the non-government sector. From 1976 to 1982 total grants for government schools decreased by 11 per cent, while total grants for non-government schools increased by 77 per cent. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table indicating percentage changes in respect of particular programs during that period.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-
Percentage changes in Government and Non-government funding 1976-1982
Change Program
Per cent Government general recurrent -1.9 Non-government general recurrent +92 .6 Government capital -35.8 Non-government capital +10.3

TALK.START.PARA: —This table on percentage changes reveals some startling figures . During the period from 1976 to 1982, government general recurrent funding decreased by 1.9 per cent. Over the same period, non-government general funding increased by 92.6 per cent. Over that period government capital funding decreased by 35.8 per cent and non-government capital funding increased by 10.3 per cent. These are startling figures. Whilst the increase in recurrent grants to non-government schools could be justified in terms of need, several points must be made. Firstly, the most significant increases in grants were for the wealthiest non-government schools. For example, a level one primary school's percentage subsidy increased from 11 per cent to 20 per cent from 1976 to 1982. For a level six primary school, which is now a level three primary school, the percentage increased from 30 per cent to 38 per cent. That represents a proportionate increase of less than that of its wealthier counterpart.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point which should be made is that, since 1976, Commonwealth general recurrent grants for government schools have declined slightly. The improvement in government resources since that year has thus been achieved by the States increasing their expenditure on such schools. As Commonwealth recurrent grants to non-government schools are based on government school running costs, the increased State expenditure has been directly reflected in increases in Commonwealth subsidies for non-government schools. Therefore, to some extent there is a circular progression favouring non-government schools. This circular progression is created by the current funding policies. Increased subsidies for non-government schools lead to increased enrolments in those schools and thus decreased enrolments in government schools. The decreased enrolment in government schools means there is an increased student expenditure in government schools which leads to increased subsidies for non-government schools and so on.

With the background of imbalance between the two education sectors becoming so evident, the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Susan Ryan, issued guidelines to the Commonwealth Schools Commission assuring the Commission that the Government would discontinue the nexus between government school standard costs and per capita subsidies in non-government schools. I will return to the nexus agreement shortly. It should be noted that at the same time as the Minister made this statement she announced also that additional funding would be made available for the non-government sector. In stressing that it was government policy to provide funds to those schools most in need, it was announced that the Government wished, as far as possible, that those non- government schools in group three-those most in need-would benefit from the additional recurrent resources.

Amongst the increased funding for non-government schools in 1984 is an amount of $750,000 for a participation and equity program, which was mentioned a little while ago by the Minister. This program will encourage young people over the school leaving age to participate in useful and fulfilling education and training activities in schools and technical and further education centres. As well as that, I mention that an extra $1.2m is being made available for computer education in the non-government sector and $7.2m in general recurrent grants. Level two schools will have a percentage increase of one per cent in real terms and level three will have a 3 per cent real increase. The Minister expanded on both of those matters earlier.

At this stage I wish to return to the decision that the Government made that there would be a discontinuation of the nexus between school standard costs and per capita subsidies to non-government schools. To discontinue the present nexus is not something that is new on the education horizon. It is not true, despite the inferences that were made, that the discontinuation of the nexus has been plucked out of the air by this Government. This is by no means the first time when this matter has been raised. The Schools Commission, in its report for the triennium 1982-84, remarked that it:

. . . believes that the 'basket of services' approach provides a proper standard on which to base grants to non-government schools. It is to this standard that recurrent grants to non-government schools should be linked.

The Schools Commission raised three basic arguments in favour of breaking the nexus. The first was based on the suggestion that non-government schools have a more homogeneous student population than government schools. This leads to fewer resources being required to cater effectively for non-government schools as are required in government schools. The second argument was that non-government schools need fewer resources because their industrial conditions are not and need not be the same as those in government schools. The third argument arose from the movement in enrolments from government to non-government schools. The Commission argued that, because of this movement, the basing of recurrent subsidies to non-government schools on average government school summary costs becomes increasingly untenable because of the growing diseconomies and economies of scale in the government and non-government sectors respectively.

In mentioning those factors, I have given but a potted precis of the arguments for breaking the nexus. The arguments are outlined on page 54 of the Schools Commission report of March 1981. I mention that a further argument for breaking the nexus is also listed on page 55 of the report, and so too are three counter arguments. What is important is that this issue has been publicly debated before and the Schools Commission came down in favour of a different approach. Irrespective of what the Schools Commission said, the argument has been raised before. It was not the first time, when the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs brought down her guidelines, that the matter was raised.

Finally, when debates ensue in this place in relation to education, almost invariably the discussion is about education funding. This is understandable because the Commonwealth has a direct responsibility for educational services in the Australian Capital Territory. Yet we must never lose sight of the fact that this funding is not an end itself but a means to a end, namely, the provision of sound educational opportunities, particularly for our future citizens. Like many honourable senators, I visit educational institutions when I have the opportunity to do so. When I see funds being spent with little or no regard to need I am appalled. This happens in my home State where, it is claimed by many, electoral boundaries can be drawn on a map of Queensland on the basis of the quality of schools and the resources within those schools. The schools in Labor- held electorates have been discriminated against in recent years. Put another way, the children attending those schools have been discriminated against because funding is made on a basis other than that of need.

The Federal Labor Government has made no secret of the fact it will provide education funding on the basis of need. In correcting the imbalance that occurred during the term of office of the previous Government, it is obvious that some groups will object. However, equality of educational opportunity is too precious a principle to be set aside. I look forward to funding on a needs basis not necessarily from this Goverment which embraces that idea but on a needs basis being adopted in Queensland after the event that is to take place on 22 October of this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a matter of public importance. It deals with the basis of funding for education in Australia. The actual issue that we are debating is the united opposition of the whole of the non-government school sector to two central principles of the Australian Labor Party's non-government school funding policy. The word 'principle' has been thrown around fairly loosely by Government speakers today. These central principles involved were spelled out in a statement by the Catholic bishops when they expressed their concern about the abolition of the nexus between the cost of educating a child in a government school and the cost of educating a child in a non-government school, and the level of recurrent grants to non-government schools. The Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, in her reply to Senator Baume , the shadow Minister for Education, made heavy play on the use of the world ' principle'. She accused the Opposition of not having an education policy but only a funding policy. What we are really supposed to be debating today is the principle of linkage of funding for children in government and non-government schools and the principle of a certainty of base funding for a large sector of our educational system.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of principle that the Australian Government provide education for all Australian children. It is a matter of fact that Australia, over the years, has developed a large non-government school sector. It is a matter of principle in Australia that parents have a right of choice between government and non-government schools. It is a matter of fact that the parents of 23 per cent of our children attending schools choose non-government schools, despite the fact that the parents of those children are required to pay extra costs. Enrolments in non-government schools in recent years have increased relative to enrolments in government schools. Obviously that has been substantially because there has been a contribution to the cost of running the non-government schools. There was a time when there was no government contribution to non-government schools in Australia.
