In those days the fees for the education of children at non-government schools were prohibitive for most of the population, and it was virtually only the wealthy who could afford the non-government schools, with the exception of the Catholic sector. The Catholic Church poured huge amounts of resources into those schools to subsidise the costs.

In more recent times and, one would hope, in more enlightened times governments in Australia have accepted that the non-government sector is an important educational sector. It is important as a matter of funding and as a matter of principle. It is important that parents have a right of choice, that there be some competition amongst educators to draw children to their schools. It has been important because, frankly, it has saved governments large sums of money to have a substantial percentage of our students that we do have in non-government schools. Every principle that a government implements ultimately has a price attached. The principles of education policy cost money. Eventually there is a cost for educating children. The two cannot be divided. The amount one is prepared to apply and the way in which one applies that amount is a reflection of the principles on which one proceeds. I reiterate that it is a matter of principle that all Australian children have access to education. It is now firmly established as a matter of principle that, in Australia, parents have a choice. That is what this debate is about. That is what the Catholic bishops' statement was about.

Senator Ryan made a vitriolic attack on Senator Baume and on the Liberal Party' s education policies. She derided debate on the subject of funding. She derided debate on the amounts that are spent and the application of those amounts. In response to the bishops, Senator Ryan said that, of course, their statement was made on 1 September, and that was before her statement today stating that group 3 schools would get an extra $5m. Faced with the principles that the bishops expressed in their statement, Senator Ryan applied a $5m band-aid and said that money answers the principle. Very clearly, the bishops will not fall for that bait. Very clearly, those independent schools which are not, at this stage, disadvantaged will not be fooled by an additional $5m. That is not to say that an extra $5m is not welcome in our education system. However it does not meet the bishops' stated opposition and the stated opposition of many other people involved in the independent schools sector.

Senator Ryan referred to a statement by Archbishop James Carroll. I have a copy of a letter written by Archbishop Carroll to the Minister, to which she referred . I will read a section of that letter which was not highlighted by Senator Ryan .

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit of selective quoting.
—Selective quoting, indeed. Archbishop Carroll, in his letter to Senator Ryan, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission--
that is, the Catholic Education Commission-

has requested me to express the concern raised in the minds of many people by the reduction and possible eventual elimination of some recurrent grants and by the removal of the automatic percentage nexus with the standard government school costs for 1984.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is disgraceful.
—Indeed, it is.
—That is the one bishop she quoted.

—The bishop whom Senator Ryan quoted as justification of her policy and her Government's policy, in other words, Archbishop James Carroll, expressed to Senator Ryan exactly the view that was expressed in the statement of the Catholic bishops of 1 September this year.
—We should scrutinise her stuff very closely.

—Yes, it might be a good idea to scrutinise the other papers that have been tabled today. Senator Ryan seemed to think that it was some defence against the principles that were expressed by the Catholic bishops that, in her own words, only 41 schools were affected. Very clearly, the principle that is raised is that if 41 schools can be separated out now in a divide and conquer exercise, many would think, other schools not presently on the list could well be threatened. Very clearly, the independent schools sector feels that.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan threw around loosely and with great sarcasm the word 'wealth' and referred to wealthy schools. I remind the Senate that the entire emphasis in Senator Ryan's speech was on an accusation that the Opposition talks about quantities of money and not principles. Her response to the principles that we have raised is to quantify and to say it is only 41 schools and to say that it is the wealthy schools or schools with a high level of assets. Senator Ryan is not replying on a basis of principle, the principle to which she says the education debate ought to be linked. I agree that the education debate is very much linked to some fundamental principles, some of which I have stated and some of which were stated by Senator Macklin, Senator Harradine and Senator Baume.

Senator Ryan cannot have it both ways. She cannot say that when we talk about a sum of money we are not talking principle, and then herself talk about a 'small number' of schools and say she is talking principle. In the end, these principles are quantified. They are quantified in terms of cost and in terms of the number of schools, the number of children and the number of families that are affected.

To then go on to say that the Hawke Government's policy is a better and fairer one sits very strangely indeed. We can debate whether some aspects of it might be better. I am sure that we will debate that at great length. Senator Ryan will not find that Opposition senators agree with her. But she cannot claim that the Hawke Government's policies are fairer. Its policies single out a group of schools and students at those schools for expressly unfair treatment as compared with students at other schools.

By using terms that the Labor Party hopes are emotive and will appeal to some meaner streak in some members of the community-terms such as 'wealthy schools'- and by avoiding touching the Catholic systemic schools, Senator Ryan takes the debate right off any better or fairer basis. However we will meet her on that basis. We will meet her on the basis of principle-but if only she and her Government will come on to the point of principle. On what grounds does a government decide that there is a group of students in schools in Australia who are entitled to less than a base amount that is available to other students? I reiterate, it is only, after all, a percentage of the cost of education of students at government schools. The balance of the money is provided by parents or from other resources, notably so in the Catholic education system.

The thrust of the Government's policy is very clear. Senator Ryan ought to explain to the Senate how the principles of the Hawke Government's education policy and her education policy sit with the principles enunciated in Labor's statement of policy on non-government schools of 16 February this year. It claimed that one result of adjustments should be 'a reduction in fees so that over time the parents would benefit from those reduced fees and that access to the schools by less well off parents would accordingly be increased'. In February the Labor Party's principle was that access to schools ought to be increased for those who are less well off.

TALK.START.PARA: —It still is.

—If that is so, I ask the honourable senator to explain it, in view of the fact that the Labor Party in government has increased fees at some schools or reduced facilities. Senator Crowley and other Government senators, including Senator Ryan, would have received communications from a number of schools which have surveyed, for example, how many of the children in those schools have two parents in employment, how many of the mothers of those children have stated that their reason for being in employment is to meet the cost of sending their children to non-government schools, how many of those women's earnings are equivalent or nearly equivalent to the cost of the fees. It is a fact that that is a reason that a lot of the women work. Not that I am saying they have to use it as a justification, but it shows the choice those mothers make. They choose to go to work in order to pay that difference. The Labor Government's policy has made it even more difficult because one of the effects of its policy is to increase fees in precisely those schools which have up to 70 per cent of mothers of students in employment, well above the national average, to make it even more difficult, to give those women even less disposable income. Those are some of the human facts. The Labor Party says in its policy document that access to education is important. It says that it will pursue certain issues so that there is more access. In fact, it will make access even more difficult.

SPEECH.PARA: At the commencement of her speech, Senator Ryan, in very strong terms, in a personal attack on Senator Peter Baume said that his main interest was to provoke a spurious campaign of fear based on a deliberate misunderstanding. There is no misunderstanding among those who are sending their children to school in Australia. They understand that the Labor Party is now embarked on a policy which, far from being based on principle, is based on discrimination and prejudice. Those who are importantly involved in providing a significant section of education in Australia today, namely the Central Commission of Catholic Bishops, have recognised that and have stated it. I doubt whether Senator Ryan's extra $5m will have any bearing at all on their assessment. The reason she could even think it might is that she herself cannot recognise the principles that they have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Martin has asked on what grounds some schools are entitled to less funding. There has been a great deal of talk in this chamber this afternoon about choice, principles and, dare I say it, bishops. I also would like to comment on choice and principles. I make reference to a statement which was drawn up by the Anglican Social Responsibilities Commission, the Catholic Commission for Justice and Peace and Social Justice, the Uniting Church Commission on Social Responsibility, and the Australian Council of Churches. It is published with the approval of the Catholic Bishops Committee for Development and Peace. The statement, entitled 'Changing Australia ' urges that the 'share the wealth' call go out to all schools. The document states:

SPEECH.PARA: The co-existence of wealth and poverty in a nation as rich as Australia affronts human dignity.

It calls for far reaching alterations in Australia's social and political system . What has been stated in the education guidelines and by Senator Ryan and Senator Colston this afternoon is just the beginning of that 'share the wealth' call to which the Hawke Labor Government is committed. We do, in fact, have the support of the major churches of this country.

The Opposition seems determined to resist the basic premises that were recognised by the Age education supplement on 16 August. First, under the guidelines the vast majority of private schools will be financially better off next year than they are in 1983. The non-government school sector itself is not under attack by the Labor administrations. Instead, the increased sums of money which will go to private schools are being partly redistibuted, and it is the Roman Catholic schools by and large which will benefit. I note that with all the comments that have been made here this afternoon no one has suggested that Catholic schools will not accept increased funding.

Secondly, schools singled out for reduced subsidies are among the best equipped in Australia. They may not all be wealthy in the sense of having large reserves of capital, but even with reduced State aid they will still be able to operate at levels exceeding those of most public schools. I would have thought that was what equity was all about. In general, these schools have total incomes at the moment that are 60 per cent greater than those available to government schools. Each has a private cash income alone which is about equal to that required to run a State school of similar size. It is the quantity of private income derived from school fees, endowments, interest from investments and so on that the Commonwealth has used as the criterion in selecting schools for cuts in State aid in 1984. The reason why none of the most noted Catholic schools are on the list is simply that they employ many nuns and brothers as teachers. They are therefore able to charge lower fees than other independent schools and so do not have the same private income.

The third and perhaps most important point that seems to have been overlooked by the Opposition this afternoon is that, despite claims to the contrary, the affected schools are exclusive. Although most do not discriminate against children in an obvious way, there is an inevitable selection process at work. The poor, the black, the handicapped and childen from migrant backgrounds are under-represented, if they are present at all, in these schools. I do not think choice is really a matter at issue when one considers that up to 75 per cent of Australian parents are not in a position to choose. On average, the annual family income of the parents of students who attend the elite private schools is estimated at about $40,500. That is an estimate made by the Age of 11 December 1982 after a survey of 76 private schools. That same survey showed that nearly 80 per cent of parents whose children attend the elite private schools are managers, professionals and farmers. Less than one per cent actually represent unskilled workers.

Senator Martin mentioned that many mothers go out to work to help pay fees. This is not an argument for State aid. Many families which spend their disposable income on speed boats or holiday homes are no more entitled to public subsidies than those who decide to devote their income to their children's education. The schools themselves are also somewhat exclusive in their outlook. They are very much geared to preparing their students for further education in a university or college. Here I cite studies of university recruitment which show that Australian universities remain a bastion of the privileged, dominated by private school students. That was the finding of Professor Adnerson, of the Australian National University, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 11 August this year. Furthermore, a study of entrants to Melbourne and Monash universities, by school, undertaken by A. Smurthwaite and published in Australian Universities in July 1974, shows that independent schools, having 8 per cent of all students, took up 30 per cent of all university places.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the date?
—Nothing more up to date than that?

—That is the date in the book I took the information from, and that situation has not changed. It is recognised that universities are the bastions of the elite. I think it is quite outrageous that we should be debating this matter this afternoon on behalf of the most privileged section in Australian society. With all the problems that are facing so many people in Australian society today, we are debating whether the parents of students in elite schools might have to pay a little extra.
—Two dollars a week.

—The amount is $2 a week extra. Senator Baume has placed much attention on educational justice. In his comments he failed to represent the views of some 75 per cent of children who attend State schools. This in sharp contrast to his commitment to government schools as recently as 22 February 1983 , when he stated in a letter to those schools:

SPEECH.PARA: I am sending the Liberal/National Party Government's policies on education direct to you. Education is an important issue for this Government and I hope you will see fit to pass this material on to your staff.

The Government reaffirms its basic support for all children wherever they go to school and its willingness to embark, even in difficult economic times, on policies that will meet the special needs of young Australians.
Our policies-more support for government schools . . . will help lead us towards a better educated society.

In this letter, Senator Baume makes great play of how committed he is to the government school sector, yet this afternoon all he could do was talk about the parents of the students at those 41 elite schools who will have to pay, Senator Ryan says, $2 extra. How does this statement rest with his preoccupation with non-government schools today? How did he plan to incorporate those policies to meet the needs of all young Australians? Why are we not debating giving all young Australians a better opportunity rather than concentrating on those students in 41 elite schools?

Despite Senator Baume's emotive talk about educational justice, he has failed to demonstrate how the Opposition would give greater equity of educational opportunity to all Australian children. I have not heard Senator Baume speak out about educational justice for the hundreds of disadvantaged schools throughout Australia. Are not Aborigines, girls, migrants, handicapped children and children in isolated areas entitled to educational justice? Is it educational justice for the children of some islands of the Torres Strait to be taught by unqualified staff in schools run by the Queensland Department of Aboriginal and Islander Affairs rather than in schools with standards set by the Department of Education? Senator Baume and Senator Martin did not mention any of these things. Is it educational justice for the child shown on the Four Corners program last Saturday to have the continual battle and frustration to communicate with her teacher on the School of the Air because of interference on the radio? Why do Senator Baume and the Opposition not talk about more funds to improve education in isolated areas?

Senator Baume and Senator Martin are selective in their concern for educational justice. Senator Baume and his colleagues consider that the standard of Australian education is so generally high that we can afford a debate on a matter of public importance on whether it is appropriate for a handful of elite schools to have to tighten their belts in order that poorer schools may share scarce resources. Malcolm Fraser said that life was not meant to be easy, but it is easier if one is entitled to wear the right school tie.

In conclusion, I quote some figures which indicate why it is not surprising that the Opposition is speaking out in defence of the elite schools. The figures I have indicate that an overwhelming number of Opposition members in this place and in the other place are in fact products of the elite private school system.

TALK.START.PARA: —If you do that, we will quote the Labor people from Scots College and Geelong Grammar. We will quote them back.

—I will quote both. I refer to the shadow Ministry to start with. Of a total of 30 members, I could locate the records of only 26. Four came from state or Catholic schools and 22 came from elite private schools. Of the 27 members of the Ministry, I know of the education of 24 and, of those, 21 attended state or Catholic schools and only three attended elite schools.
—What about universities?
—I do not happen to have those figures but I would be very happy to get them. The elite schools are being championed by members of the Opposition because they have a vested interest.

DEBATE.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS GENERAL ASSEMBLY-THIRTY SEVENTH SESSION 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report of Australian Delegation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

I should like to refer in particular to references to nuclear and disarmament issues, on page 13 of the report. I find this quite an alarming aspect. As honourable senators will recall, the United Nations General Assembly last year had a session which was to have sorted out the problems of disarmament and which in fact did not do so. The report, on Page 13, refers to the difficulties which arose subsequently. It states:

The relative dearth of results at the Special Session inevitably affected both the atmosphere and the course of negotiations on nuclear and disarmament matters at the General Assembly itself. In particular, frustration among some key delegations at the inadequacies of the Special Session resulted in reduced willingness to seek consensus on drafts and an increased propensity for the non- aligned to use their superior voting strength to force resolutions through both the First Committee and the plenary.
The report goes on to mention both the International Atomic Energy Agency and the Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy. In the case of the first of these, the report states:

. . . a previously negotiated text was amended from the floor to include language critical of Israel. A second set of amendments, introduced by Brazil and India, was designed to alter the thrust and balance of the resolution, especially in its non-proliferation aspects.
This of course is the point which concerns me most. As far as the Conference on the Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy is concerned, the report states:

. . . prolonged negotiations in pursuit of a consensus text proved fruitless and the non-aligned eventually tabled a draft which caused severe problems for both Western and Eastern bloc countries and which led the majority of these delegations to vote against the resolution in plenary.

This clearly indicates a state of affairs in the international forum which is unsatisfactory and likely to become more so, and those of us who are concerned with the prospects of a proliferation of small, dirty, atomic bombs, made with the by-products of so-called peaceful purpose reactors, can find little comfort there.

From time to time we hear from honourable senators in this place that all is well in the world nuclear situation because the International Atomic Energy Agency is on the job, it is a wise, universal and omnipotent authority that will ensure that nothing goes wrong in the nuclear industry and that especially plutonium, readily available as a by-product of electric power generation, will not be diverted to make atomic weapons. People who believe that are living in cloud cuckoo land. Nothing could be further from the truth. Not only are many of the nations now installing nuclear power plants not a party to the non- proliferation agreements but also they are strongly suspected of seeking to make nuclear weapons of the type I have described, roughly analagous to the atomic bombs which destroyed Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

There is also strong and reasonable criticism about the effectiveness of the inspection apparatus of the international agency. I suggest to honourable senators that this is surely a disquieting situation for any reasonable person. Surely we are adopting a lemming-like, even a suicidal impulse, if as a nation we do not pursue and try to rectify this unsatisfactory situation. Ought we to accept willingly a Judas-like role of accepting our 30 pieces of silver for our uranium in the full knowledge that there are not proper safeguards to prevent it turning up in nuclear weapons which, quite possibly, we might be on the receiving end of. I urge the Government to look back, while there is still time, over all the contracts we have concerning the sale of uranium and abrogate these contracts if necessary where it is felt that there is not a decent and reasonable safeguard against proliferation.

It is often said in this place that as a major potential supplier of uranium we hold considerable power to influence the development of the nuclear industry and to prevent the diversion to weapons of fissionable materials which can be either enriched uranium 235 or plutonium 239. There might be some argument for this if indeed there were iron-clad provisions against non-proliferation. But of course there are not, and the situation, far from getting better, is getting worse. Last year, President Reagan forecast that he would want to look to the civilian nuclear power industry for plutonium to make nuclear weapons, even though we already have more weapons than are needed to destroy the planet many times over.

The Australian Democrats ask the Government, as a matter of urgency, to take a much more positive and stronger line in this matter. In particular, I should like the Government to look at the very weak and dangerous precedent set by the previous Government to allow reprocessing of our uranium in conditions where it could very easily end up in weapons. The warnings are clear enough and I think it is high time we took some notice of them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the same report, the report of the Australian Delegation to the Thirty-seventh Session of the United Nations General Assembly in 1982. Of course, it is the report of a delegation during the period of office of the previous Government. Since that time, of course, under the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Bill Hayden, I believe a much more active role , of course within the context of the general and historical alliances which have been established since the Second World War, has been undertaken. I believe that whilst we have differed with our allies in some areas as to emphases and perceived best means of achieving our common goal of international stability, those initiatives which Bill Hayden has taken have indeed been, as I say, within the context of our general historical alliances. In the very brief time available to me, I should like to comment upon two matters in the report. The first relates to the section headed 'Political and Security Issues' raised during that session. Under the heading 'Kampuchea' there is a quite extensive discussion of the effect of the continued occupation of that country by Vietnamese troops on the prospects for peace in South East Asia. I believe that it is right to take this opportunity to commend the Australian Foreign Minister, Mr Bill Hayden, for his persistent initiatives in this area. If ever a Foreign Minister of a middle power-and we have to be modest in any expectations of what influence we can bring to bear-has put his own credibility on the line in relation to this intractable problem, it is certainly Bill Hayden. The basis of his extensive travels throughout the region and in China has been not to try to fulfil the role of a mediator or arbitrator or negotiator but, rather, to seek to engage in discussions with the various groups in order to see whether it is possible to identify some common ground which would allow the groups to show a little more flexibility. As I say, we cannot overestimate our potential influence but at least, as I say, the Foreign Minister is to be commended. In particular, the key to any success remains China's attitude and the attitude of China must be a matter for continued concern. I commend this Government on its initiatives in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter on which I should like to touch briefly has been noted by Senator Colin Mason of the Australian Democrats. It has to do with nuclear and disarmament issues. The fact is that this Government has taken many steps, some of a symbolic character but many concrete practical steps, and sometimes combining both in this regard. Mr Richard Butler has been appointed Ambassador for Disarmament. He has been given a mandate by the Foreign Minister in particular in relation to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty which Senator Mason rightly identified as a matter of prime concern for the international community. It is essential in particular that Article 6 of that Treaty be observed by the present identified possessors of nuclear arsenals. That is that they take proper steps to reduce those particular holdings of nuclear weapons. I would imagine that that would be a pre-condition of other countries continuing to adhere to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. Insofar as some of them have refused to adhere to it, it is a matter of very real concern and the Australian Government, I know, is pressing for the further successful extension of that Treaty during its review year of 1985. The text also notes, at page 13, the work of the Australian and New Zealand governments in relation to the comprehensive test ban treaty. Once again two quite modest powers in the sense of political weight, Australia and New Zealand, have continually asked the international community to endorse a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty and I believe that that particular initiative by our Government will continue.

Finally, I want to refer to the great mass movement of hundreds of thousands of people through the streets of New York which accompanied the particular special session on disarmament. In the report on that event, Mr Tony Street, the then Minister for Foreign Affairs, exhibited a fear of mass movements in that they may be manipulated for ends which were inimical to those of Australia and the Western alliance. In fact, the Labor Government takes the completely different view that, without in any way being dictated to by these mass movements, we will encourage and support the expression democratically and non-violently of the very real fear and misgivings throughout the community as we are facing the imminent nuclear holocaust which we must bend our energies to avoid.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1982-83

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I was very interested to read the annual report of the Department of Science and Technology and to note in its introduction some of the Department's guidelines. I am particularly interested to note that amongst other things the Department is established to:
Ensure that science and technology issues are considered in the development of government policies, particularly industry and economic policies;
and also to:
Improve the awareness of the benefits and disbenefits of science and technology .
In particular, the report states:

Success of a policy for a more selective approach depends on it being co- ordinated with other government policies. For example, the finance needs of new technology-based industries must be met and the education system must provide people with knowledge and skills appropriate to the current and future needs of a strong, competitive and innovative Australian industrial sector.

At this point I began to feel the absence of any comments or recommendations about occupational safety and health in the Department's report. The report addresses itself to social implications of technological change and points out that the Department has completed a large study in this area. This study particularly looked at the effect of technological change on:
Employment, skills, the nature of work and leisure, groups in the work-force, industrial relations, institutional systems (education, health, trade unions, politics) individuals and the community.
But, again, no specific reference is made to matters of occupational safety and health.

It is interesting, too, that many of the Department's programs and planning are designed to implement such things as improved management techniques. The report even contains an item referring to noise reduction. The Department has a function to look at the whole problem of noise. The report states:
Excessive noise in industry is a considerable health hazard, particularly in metal manufacturing, and is an area of increasing compensation litigation.

One would imagine from reading this report that it is a matter of compensation litigation rather than an emphasis of occupational health and safety for those people involved in areas where the noise level is very high which leads the Department to design less noisy machines. The Department rejects the band-aid approach of absorbing noise and is investigating the design of machines that will not make noise. However, the Department's emphasis again is not on occupational health and safety which I believe needs to be written into management design and technological planning from the beginning.

The report makes reference to the completion of a departmentally-sponsored occupational safety and health pilot promotional campaign in 1981. But I would submit that a pilot promotional campaign is insufficient for an understanding of what real occupational health and safety is all about. This concept must be incorporated at the very beginning of any planning for the introduction of new technology and I submit it ought to be part of the functions of this Department.

The report also makes reference to information about new technology and to the contribution that has been made to an understanding of the impact of microprocessor-based information systems on life styles and work activities. We are already well aware of the rapid repetitive injury syndrome and the enormous amount of compensation that is beginning to accrue in that area. However, once again, the Department makes no reference to planning or job design which incorporates the occupational health and safety dimension that would prevent these injuries occurring. This would not be because people will not work with word processors but because their job design is such that they will not have to work continually at these machines.
The Department has an occupational and safety health committee in the Department. That committee met twice. The report states:
The Department is implementing a recommendation of the committee to engage an occupational health consultant to survey safety and health in the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories.

Again I would suggest that this is hardly a sufficient dimension for an understanding of occupational safety and health, particularly in this Department , and particularly as this Department is involved in areas of innovation. I appreciate that the Department has put out a paper about the pilot promotional campaign on occupational safety and health. I have acquired a copy of this very interesting document. But again it talks about the effects on perception and attitudes of a mass communication campaign. I think we need to move to a consideration of occupational safety and health that is actually built into jobs , built into departments and built into the thinking of people so that it is not an added on component.

I might say in conclusion that I have taken this matter up with the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) who is appreciative of this dimension, that is, the need of occupational health and safety planning at the very initial stage of any development. I will be interested to see what next year's annual report has to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks on this report tend to be an extension of what Senator Crowley has said. I feel that a reading of the report makes plain the unsatisfactory nature of the Department of Science and Technology from the point of view of structure. It is not really a department of science and technology at all. Heaven knows, we need badly enough just that one thing-a properly constituted department of science and technology. Rather the report lists a ragtag of activities loosely associated with science and technology which certainly have values in themselves but are in no way comprehensive. It includes such things, of course, as the Patent, Trade Marks and Designs Office, the Bureau of Meteorology and the Antarctic Division of the Department.

SPEECH.PARA: According to appendix D on page 80 of the report, the Department's expenditure for 1982-83 was some $215m. This certainly seems to me little enough for a nation with our problems, which must develop high technology industries and which must at all costs come to terms with modern developments in science and technology if we are not going to become, as has been freely forecast, the poor white trash of Asia in the next generation. When one considers that of that money only $60m is actually going to industrial research and development incentives, only $120,000 to assistance to inventors and some $22m to research grants, the situation emerges as being even more tacky than one would wish. In addition, about $5m in grants-in-aid was allocated to a large variety of organisations, none of which really received enough money to make a significant contribution.

Vast steps are being taken throughout the world in the fields of alternative technology, especially the development of new forms of electric power generation which I hope will be keenly followed in Australia with the objective of establishing such new industries in this country. There is a direct relationship between power generation and the employment rate. While traditional industries are unable to employ all the people trained to work in them and who want work, it seems axiomatic to me that the way to get more people into jobs is through new and innovative industries. I refer here to the vast advances currently being made in Japan and the United States of America on solar technology, namely, the direct photoelectric effect through the use of photoelectric cells which are very much cheaper and easier to make than the cells which have been produced in the past. One such innovation is the use of amorphous cells which consist of a silicon deposit on a plastic or metal substrate. The stage is being reached in America where this technology is competitive with nuclear and fossil power plants for the generation of electricity. Australia ought to be in that. We should not be doing this in 10 year's time. It should be done now. The Department of Science and Technology should be the cutting edge in this respect. With our huge loss situation of reticulating from a large central electric power source to remote areas, surely we in Australia are a potential market for this kind of electricity which could be of enormous importance to us.

Private enterprise in Western Australia is now, of course, getting into the wind energy manufacturing situation. Indeed, 55 kilowatt plants are being made in Perth for a promising market. Here again, government development has lagged dismally behind what private enterprise is attempting to do. Of course, in Australia as elsewhere, a proper conservational approach should be encouraged. The development of wind generation would be one way to do this.

I think the Department of Science and Technology should be making a major study as soon as possible into the effects on employment of various kinds of new technology. This is an area of study which has not really been carried out in Australia with any kind of consultation with the community. A vital part of the way in which the Department could do so would be to try to determine through community consultation what the approach to this would be, if a neo-Luddite reaction is not to check this progress. By neo-Luddite I mean, of course, that people are afraid of new technology because it appears to be taking away their jobs-for the same reason that the Luddites broke up mill machinery in the past. That neo-Luddite reaction has already begun in Australia. It is urgent that it should be checked.

The Government has a Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Barry Jones) who is much admired for his intelligence, vision and breadth of view. The Government should give him his head and let him create a real Department of Science and Technology which would be a spur for the new developments necessary for this country if it is to continue to be an advanced nation in the twenty-first century.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to refer to several aspects of the report and, firstly, to the Executive Director who is listed and named in the report as Mr Neville Whiffen. He has recently retired from the position that he held from the time that the Board was originally set up. I just wanted to refer to that and to thank him for all he did. He worked tirelessly to publicise Canberra and to let people in the business community know of the advantages of setting up business, industry or their headquarters in Canberra. In fact he was employed on a part time basis, but he contributed a great deal more of his time and effort than that would indicate. Success of the Board in bringing the number of businesses that it did to Canberra in that time is very largely due to his effort. We can be thankful to him for that. He is still associated with another activity that he set up; that is, the science school for students which will take place next January. I am glad that he is still involved in that activity.

The report refers to the role of the Board with the National Capital Development Commission. Under the heading 'Functions' it states that one of the functions of the Board established in 1979 is to express its views to the National Capital Development Commission in relation to the Commission's statutory responsibility for the development of Canberra. At present, the Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) has in his possession a report which is a review of the activities of the National Capital Development Commission. The Minister has had that report since July this year-some 10 weeks- but has not made it public or given people the opportunity to know what is in it . Of course, that presents a particular hardship for the employees of the NCDC who do not really know what the future holds for them. The Canberra Development Board has its problems because, as I have said, it has a responsibility to make its views known to the NCDC. It is necessary for the Board and the community to know what is in this report.

Initially the Minister did not release it and our shadow Minister agreed with the Minister that to keep it to himself for a couple of weeks so that he could study it was reasonable. The Minister said that he would table it in the Parliament when Parliament resumed. That was as long ago as 23 August and still it has not been made available. I do not know what the mystery is or why the Minister is keeping it secret, but I suggest to him it is high time that he made public the report of the review of the NCDC so that the people of this town can know what is in it, what the future is and what recommendations ought to ought not be accepted.

The other aspect of the Canberra Development Board's report that needs highlighting is that part of one of its initiated projects which it has entitled 'International Hotel, Convention Centre and Tivoli Gardens'. I will not go through it in detail, but it refers to the project that has become known as the White Industries Ltd development. It is envisaged to provide an international hotel and convention centre. Part of the project, which perhaps is of great significance, is the office block which is to be on the site and a part of the development. Honourable senators may recall that only Thursday of last week the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt), in talking about the fact that he had not been able to open in Canberra a Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Service, stated that it was because of the lack of office space in Canberra. As far as I know, this is the only office block that looks like being available in the near future. It has not even begun to get off the ground. Rumor has it that the matter has gone back to Cabinet and for some reason has been held up. It is a project that should go ahead and needs to go ahead. I ask the Cabinet to get on with it and let it go ahead. We need the office space. We need the international hotel. We need the convention centre. The jobs that it will provide we most certainly need.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The Canberra College of Advanced Education fills a number of important roles in the Australian Capital Territory. In particular, it has been teaching in the area of computer science for some time. The Public Service relies fairly heavily on graduates from the CCAE. It has a high record of its graduates obtaining jobs . The College Council decided some time ago that its computer needed to be replaced. It needs a separate building in which a new computer could be housed in order for it to proceed with this important aspect of its teaching. During 1984 it will continue to teach with the facilities it has, but it is imperative that new facilities be available in 1985 .

As I understand it, the Council's recommendations are conveyed to the Advanced Education Council, which considers the priorities and then makes a recommendation to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission which in turn makes recommendations to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan). I say to the Minister: Please give the question of the computer facilities at the Canberra College of Advanced Education the very highest priority and urgent attention. One would normally expect that it would take about 18 months to construct the building necessary at the site. That really ought to be under way quite soon if it is to be available for the teaching year of 1985. The risk is that by 1985 the College will not be able to continue teaching these important subjects if that facility is not made available. As I have said, I ask the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs to give this a high priority and her urgent attention.
