DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON CONSTITUTIONAL AND LEGAL AFFAIRS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 September 1983, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue before us is very important. It is a matter of very great concern to us that the conditions that have obtained in this country in relation to Aboriginals have in fact led to such a report as this being necessary. The report stimulates thinking along the lines of a makarrata. Of course, as is aknowledged by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs, the report does not touch on the principles behind the idea of a makarrata but rather introduces us to the issues and to some of the individual concerns of some of those who might be involved in preparing the way for such a document. I think it is terribly important to recognise that issue, as was pointed out by Senator Tate when he introduced the report yesterday, and to draw attention to the fact that unless there is wide community understanding of the nature, form and the real meaning of a makarrata it will be extremely difficult to establish Australian community acceptance which might lead to such a document eventuating. That being so, I think it is important that this document has come before us in such a way that it can be widely distributed in the Australian community and can lead to the widest possible community debate about the issues involved. There can be no doubt that an enormous gulf exists between some groups in the Australian community and the Aboriginal community as to the wishes, future aspirations, culture and the great achievements of the Aboriginal people. From that point of view, there needs to be a further development of understanding at all levels in Australian society.

SPEECH.PARA: Although we have had only a brief time to look at it, the report sheds a lot of light on issues that will be the basis of future discussion. Consequently, the report should be widely distributed. I hope that all honourable senators will take the opportunity of talking to community groups and, of course, to our own party organisations on this very important matter so that we can get to the real essence of the problem, that is, an understanding of the nature of the problem of Aboriginality in this country.

It should be acknowledged that a considerable amount of work has gone into this document. There is a very significant problem in recognising the nature of white settlement in this country since 1788 and the way in which Australia has developed since that time on the basis of European settlement. Clearly there is a very real problem in understanding the nature, in law, of European settlement. It has already been demonstrated in case law, I understand, that Australia was not necessarily settled by way of conquest over the Aboriginal people but indeed by way of settlement. The distinctions are difficult and the law would need to come to terms with them. It is certainly an issue which we will need to address in our future deliberations on this very important matter.

I wish to reiterate the main point. I commend Senator Tate for his eloquence in choosing the right phraseology in this regard. I believe that he clearly pointed out that unless there is a wide understanding and agreement on this very important matter-that is, the nature and extent of a makarrata-there is very little likelihood that such an arrangement will succeed. I believe it is something to which we as members of the Australian Parliament should give our utmost attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and legal Affairs entitled 'Two Hundred Years Later . . .' is extremely important and valuable at this time in Australia's history. The central question to which the Committee sought to address itself was of considerable importance-whether the Commonwealth Government actually has the constitutional power to enter into a makarrata was adequately and extensively discussed in the report. I thought that some very useful points were raised in the report. The difficulty with which we are confronted, of course, is essentially the notion of sovereignty and a sovereign nation. The report refers to similar situations around the world that have developed beyond the stage we have reached in this country. I refer particularly to the situation of the American Indian, which raises basically a question of domestic sovereignty. Of course, the lawyers have informed us that technicalities arise with the use of words in that regard. The application of a law within a territorial framework, as is applicable in the American situation, seems to me not to be beyond the possibilities in Australia. Certainly we will have to change the structure of our law and our Constitution to be able to accommodate that.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Committee has cleared up a lot of problems but it has presented us with a whole new batch. I believe that the new problems are weightier, more important, more cohesive and certainly much more coherent. The Commonwealth Parliament and the Commonwealth Government will be able to address those problems. The National Aboriginal Conference, on behalf of the Aboriginal people , will also be able to address itself to those problems. The Australian Democrats believe that the Commonwealth has to accept the inalienable right of the Aboriginal people not only to maintain their traditional cultures, customs and lifestyle but also to govern, manage and determine their own lives in the future. Essentially that might be seen as a definition in any reasonable sense of what sovereignty means in domestic law. I do not know whether one wants to make the definition sufficiently tight as to enable the jurisdiction of the International Court of Justice or some other international body to deliberate on problems that may arise between ourselves and the Aboriginals in pursuing this aim. That is probably outside the ken, and I think in many ways it is probably not a realistic or even a reasonable proposition.

I believe we ought to establish within our own framework, traditions and history some way of dealing with this matter. But I would lend my strong support to the notion of a compact between ourselves and the Aboriginal people so that we can put down for negotiation all those very large and complex problems that still remain between us as peoples. If we are to do this I believe we have to acknowledge that the Aboriginal people never surrendered this land to the Europeans and the invasion that started in 1788 has not taken away the sovereignty of the Aboriginal people in relation to their own land.

I have raised here on previous occasions the notion of Australians rewriting history for just a moment by putting ourselves in the same situation as the Aboriginal people. Let us suppose that the Japanese remained in control of Australia until 1983 once it was sucessfully invaded and occupied during the Second World War. I think that the Australians, and their children, who had been in that conflict would today still regard this as their land. In other words, for one or two generations, if that Japanese invasion scenario had occurred, I am sure that Australians would still assert that this was their land, despite the fact that the Japanese were occupying, running and controlling it. Likewise the Aboriginal people need look back only one or two generations in the same way to assert that this is their land.

We are not going to settle the problem by the paternalistic policies of the past. The only possibility is to take a bold step forward, to be willing to acknowledge a radical departure from the policies which have been pursued in the past and to accept as the Aboriginal people accept, that this is their land. We must come to terms with that in a very real and concrete way. As I have said before, I am indebted to the Committee for raising the problems and in pursuing that line of investigation and work. I do not wish in any way to suggest that it might be easy. I will read from a small article in yesterday's edition of the Daily Sun about the Queensland Minister for Local Government, Main Roads and Racing opening the new Gold Coast district police headquarters. In his speech he referred to the Gold Coast's first police station which was opened at Tallebudgera in 1855. Mr Hinze is quoted as saying:
. . . a constable at the time had complained to the . . . Office that 'the blacks were bad'.
The Minister . . . then said: 'Well, they haven't changed, have they?'

This, in 1983, from a Minister in a State Parliament, I think must give us enormous cause for concern. When we see how the compassionate, the sympathetic and the detailed attempt that the Committee has made stands in marked contrast to the degrading and disgusting remarks made by a Minister of the National Party of Australia in opening a police station, I think we all realise how much further we have to go in this country before we even have the chance of sitting down together and discussing our mutual problems. That I believe is what we ultimately must do. We must agree to sit down with the Aboriginals and discuss with them their land and our land so that together we can go forward. We cannot overturn the problems of the past. We cannot wipe them away. This is now the land of everybody who lives here, and to that end we must make sure that the injustices of the past are recognised, and we must seek to correct them so that we can all live in a country which will recognise each individual's right to self-determination within his or her own cultural traditions. I hope that by that time the types of remarks which are quoted as having been made yesterday by a Minister of the Crown may never again be made in this country by anybody in such a responsible position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President:

SPEECH.PARA: Our children die more frequently than yours, our life expectancy is less than yours, a higher percentage of our people are in gaol than yours. We have a lower income and more people unemployed than you. We have to meet racism and disadvantage, often hostile police and other threats to our people.

That, Mr Deputy President, is part of a quotation from a submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs made on behalf of central Australian Aboriginal organisations. In effect the authors went on to say: You invaded our land, committed genocide on our people and despoiled our graves and sacred sites. They went on to say:
For this and other crimes against our nation the settler state should negotiate restitution and compensation with the Aboriginal nation.

I am sure that all Australians, black or white, would have understanding, sympathy and concern about this sort of statement and this sort of evidence. It was made perfectly clear to the committee throughout its extensive investigations of outback Australia that this evidence was not unusual. I believe we in this Parliament must have grave concern and sympathy for Aborigines. We must approach their problems with great sensitivity. In particular, what we need is understanding. I am afraid that no matter how much Australians, other than Aborigines, think about this problem, very frequently there is an almost total lack of understanding. In particular, I believe that parliamentarians must not be paternalistic and must not endeavour to impose a white man's solution on these people. Believe me, Mr Deputy President, the central Australian Aborigines put their views very firmly to the Committee when they met the Committee at Alice Springs. It is a submission which I must quote because it certainly puts one Aboriginal point of view-I do not say it is the only point of view-very firmly indeed. I now quote parts of what they said in the preamble:
To the extent that the Makarrata or Treaty will cover Aboriginal people and the invaders-
I draw attention to that word 'invaders'-

it will amount to an agreement by Aboriginal people that a white law takes precedence over Aboriginal law. It is impossible for us as people who continue to exercise our law to agree to a white law taking precedence over it. It is also impossible for the two laws to be mixed as they are based upon completely different cultural premises. We are not a homogenous nation. We have different laws depending upon where you come from. Even if it was possible for one group to find a mixture with your law that would work it would then not work for anyone else. Similarly, no Aboriginal person can speak for the members of any other group.
. . . Since 1788 our nation has been invaded by ever-increasing numbers of Europeans.
. . . The Aboriginal people have never surrendered to the European invasion and assert that sovereignty over all of Australia lies with them.
I am just taking extracts from the submission. As honourable senators will appreciate, I have a maximum of 10 minutes to speak on this subject. A further statement is:
We reject and detest the view of the settler state regarding a treaty, compact or whatever as according us dignity and rights as an Aboriginal people.
They are very strong words. That group went on to say to the Committee:

. . . We have limited time, energy and resources and we must allocate them carefully and most effectively. To divert our efforts from our daily, local struggles to participate in the formation of a Makarrata or treaty would require a high level of confidence on our part; an assurance that such an exercise was going to result in something worth while-a meaningful advance of Aboriginal people towards self-management of our own affairs.
Nothing in the current proposals for the Makarrata or treaty has given us reasons to have that confidence.

In other words, this group of Aboriginal people was saying to the Committee: ' Look, we have been conned by the white man before. We do not want to be conned by the white man into wasting our time and energy on something which may not lead to any worthwhile solution. What we want to do is to make sure that the matters which cause us grave concern are dealt with and dealt with very quickly' . I do not say that that is the answer to all of the problems but it does raise very firmly before the Parliament the question as to what the Parliament should do for the Aborigine. Should we endeavour to continue to have them exercise their energies in some sort of negotiation or should we turn to perhaps some other solution of their problem? Perhaps there is a whole series of pieces of legislation which may be of assistance to them. I might say, Mr Deputy President , that the question of sovereignty was raised very clearly by the members of the Committee and Mr Forrester, the National Aboriginal Congress representative for NAC, gave evidence in which he said:

To quote one fellow, he said: 'I want to be free like my grandfather and therefore if we want to be free like our grandfathers we have to get rid of the assimilation policy. We have to get rid of all those things which are detrimental to Aboriginal culture and ways by getting back all our traditions and protecting our sacred sites.
He went on-
This treaty--
If there is to be a treaty-

must be able to protect us from assimilation. I cannot be a white man; I am a black fellow. I have black skin, my children are black and my grandchildren will be black. We do not want to be white Australians. We want to be Aboriginals from all around here. That is what we want to be.

That is the sort of evidence which makes me say that we really must understand the Aboriginal point of view. I do not believe that there are very many non- Aboriginal Australians who do really understand that point of view but clearly it is becoming stronger as the Aboriginal people begin to realise their heritage , to be proud of it and to push their point of view. It is of course a grave problem for us because, as Senator Gareth Evans pointed out to these people, they are Australians whether they like it or not.

I am running out of time but would like to compliment a number of witnesses. The evidence is really well worth while reading for anyone who is interested in our Aboriginal heritage. I thoroughly recommend the reading of the Hansard record. I would like to compliment Miss Margaret Valadian and Mrs McNamara of the Aboriginal Training and Cultural Institute of New South Wales-

TALK.START.PARA: —Very impressive.
—whose evidence struck me as very impressive, as Senator Missen says. Miss Valadian, in particular, said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . you may not need a treaty at all. You may in fact need a series of other strategies that guarantee the resources, work towards better understanding between the two communities and provide the personnel and whatever else is needed to resolve the problems that we are facing.

She went on to talk about how to get through to the Aboriginal people. Finally, because I am down to my last minute, I wish simply to refer to one aspect of the Committee's recommendation, and that is that a broad enabling power be proposed, as a constitutional alteration. May I add that one paper put to the Committee said:
The practical point may be made that an amendment of the Constitution which does not specify the content of the agreement might excite less opposition.

In effect, that paper was saying that the way to get this through was not to allow the people of Australia to understand what the significance of the constitutional alteration would be. The Committee rejected that point of view totally. I thoroughly agree with that rejection. However, the Committee did end up saying that the way to go about it was to have a broad enabling power in the Constitution but that in regard to any such broad enabling power there must be a clear understanding by the Australian people of what was proposed, so that all Australians, black and white, could understand where the proposal would take the people of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, rise to speak to the report of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee entitled 'Two Hundred Years Later' . . . It is of course, a report on the feasibility of a compact, or makarrata, between the Commonwealth and Aboriginal people. I want first to thank the Chairman of the Committee who, since the change of government, is Senator Tate. The Committee is in very good hands. The honourable senator has supervised the bringing into existence of the report and its presentation. I had, as Chairman, most of the experience of taking evidence around Australia. That was indeed a fascinating and interesting experience and one that I hope will be of value. I thank Senator Tate for the gracious remarks that he made in his tabling statement about my chairmanship of the Committee over the last seven years. I am sure that the Committee will continue to do a lot of good work for the country and the Parliament on the issues that it has now before it.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two or three things that I should say as the retiring Chairman of the Committee because I have felt that in a couple of ways we have not had the opportunity to complete work that might have been done had circumstances been different-if there had not been an early election at the beginning of this year and we had gone ahead in the normal way and completed our report. As we went around the country in the last 18 months seeing so many of the Aboriginal communities on their home ground and obtaining their opinion on matters of relevance to this report, on a number of occasions we expressed the hope and expectation that we should be able to return to the scene with perhaps a draft report and go into those matters with the members of the community. The making of decisions by Aboriginal communities is undoubtedly a slower process than is the making of decisions by many groups-companies and so forth. It is necessary for members of the community to understand, and to reach thorough agreement, before they can be expected to accept a recommendation. Unfortunately, revisiting them was not possible. Nor did it become possible for us to go to various other areas of Australia such as northern New South Wales and South Australia where we might well have had an opportunity to call more evidence and gain a clear picture of the situation throughout Australia.

In some ways the relevance of this inquiry was not to ascertain what the various communities wanted in a makarrata. That was not the purpose of the inquiry. Its purpose was to look at the legal and other feasibility questions which arise in the making of an agreement, if that is the wish of the Australian people, that is, the black people of Australia and the white people of Australia . The Committee had such a facilitating purpose. It did not try to determine whether the people desired a makarrata or an agreement. The Committee's purpose was to determine the problems involved and to facilitate the passing through those problems if it is decided to go ahead with the project. From this point of view, I feel that the Committee, in its report, made some practical suggestions which will be useful.

The basic part of the report dealt with the way in which such an agreement could be brought into force. In our recommendations we came down on the side of an idea that this could be achieved by something like a section 105A agreement in the Constitution which would empower the Commonwealth to enter into agreements and arrangements with the Aboriginal people. The details could be worked out in an agreement which would be signed later. Obviously the Committee thought that was the best option. It considered other options, such as putting all matters that were part of the agreement into the Constitution. That is a complex matter. With our well-known difficulties in carrying out constitutional change, it would be difficult to see that it would not run into trouble in passage. There are other ways, by legislative means, agreement and so forth, of dealing with the matter. That formed a very major part of the inquiry.

During the inquiry, particularly from the studies that we undertook at the various communities, it became apparent that there was a great lack of knowledge about what a makaratta would mean. There was a certain amount of suspicion. Senator Lewis has referred to some quite cogent evidence about that. Certainly, there was no desire to waste the small amount of money and the small facilities of the Aboriginal people on something which might not turn out to be useful. I say this because as one went through the communities, particularly the communities in northern Australia, Western Australia and northern Queensland, one found very articulate leaders in those communities. They had very strong ideas on what would be needed if such an agreement came about. But to that date there had been very little information available to tell them what was involved in this process. As it appears from the Committee's report, this is not a matter of criticism in any way of the National Aboriginal Conference or any Aboriginal organisation. It concerns the mere logistics, the lack of facilities which Aboriginal people have and the inability of a small number of members of that Conference to get around to the vastly separated communities which they represent. Obviously there are other more urgent needs such as the inability to inform themselves and the members of the community.

Consequently, when we went to visit the various communities, at first on arrival we did not ask them what their ideas of a makarrata or an agreement were ; we asked them what it was. There was basically no knowledge of it. When it was explained and when we got down to discussing the needs of the community, the people were most articulate. Both men and women in those communities, acting with great dignity and obviously with great support in their communities, were able to give us a lot of very valuable information. That information is set out in the evidence. As Senator Lewis has said, a reading of the evidence will be very valuable to people throughout Australia. That evidence is available. It is in Hansard form. I think that it will be very instructive to both government and others as to the way in which we proceed from now.

To my mind, the setting up of the National Aboriginal Conference on some regular and independent legislative basis, with more staff and facilities to enable it to pursue inquiries about agreements with the white Australian people, is essential if the makarrata is to go ahead. Many of the witnesses who were most valuable to the Committee were those who were able to discuss these aspects , that is, the informing of white Australia and black Australia of the way in which such an agreement could operate, what it involved and the nature of the demands which each side makes.

Overall, a clear feeling by the Aboriginal community came through to us regarding the loss through an invasion 200 years ago of the sovereignty which these people enjoyed. The necessity for the recovery of dignity by the Aboriginal people is among the most urgent priorities. Other matters concern their great interest and determination in land and land values. Their views on these matters are quite different from the white Australian view. Many other needs are evident also, but I think the need to restore the dignity of black Australia is important. The Committee hopes that in its report it has done something towards making that easier and making the task-if the makaratta goes ahead-a success. Therefore, I hope the report will be read by Australians with a sympathetic eye to achieving that end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs was tabled yesterday afternoon. It took many months to collect the enormous amount of evidence on which the report is based. The Committee's reference was complex. The Committee learnt that the very title 'makarrata' was a most inappropriate expression of a compact of an agreement between Aboriginal people and white people. The Committee moved on to deal with the legalities which were evident in the case before Mr Justice Blackburn and other cases. They were complex matters. As Senator Austin Lewis has said, the lack of understanding between the Aboriginal people and the white people, the aspirations of the Aboriginals and the imposition of the view and the will of the white people were very complex matters. I will be sorry if this report is not debated at some length at some time in the future. Therefore, I seek leave to continue my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 September 1983, on motion by Senator Scott:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: — I continue my remarks addressed to the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence concerning the human rights and conditions of the people of East Timor. First of all, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Add to the motion that the Senate take note of the report the following words:
And expresses its agreement with the recommendations of the dissenting report.

It was with considerable regret that, for the first time in many years as a member of this Committee, I and my colleagues in Opposition found it necessary to bring down a dissenting report. It is a circumstance that has not occurred in a great number of references that have been put before us, accepted, examined and reported upon. It is interesting to recall that this reference was considered by the Committee prior to the reference being directed to the Committee by the Senate. When the Committee considered this as a reference, it decided that on balance there was no useful purpose that could be served either to the Timorese or Australian-Indonesian relations by pursuing this sort of matter in the circumstances and conditions in which we would have had to pursue it.

However, the reference was finally directed to the Committee by the Senate. It is enormously important to recall that, when the matter was directed to the Committee by the Senate, the then Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, made a distinct point that it should not concern itself with diving into history and with looking at a political investigation of rights and wrongs of the past. He stated that the Committee should try desperately to concern itself with the present situation in East Timor. Regrettably, very little evidence that we received was post-1981 evidence. A great deal of it related to a period significantly before that. The Committee seemed to query, a great deal, the few witnesses who had been to East Timor in relatively recent times, some as recently as March 1982. Yet there was a determination to accept the circumstance and the evidence of those Timorese who were refugees and were clearly emotionally very disturbed and rightly so. They were Timorese who, in many cases , had not seen their country for a significant number of years.

It seemed at least to the Opposition members of that Committee that, the Committee having finally failed to get permission to have a look at the East Timor situation on the ground, it was enormously important that in July-August of this year a parliamentary delegation was to be admitted to East Timor. As a current fact finding mission, it seemed that this would be of real significance to our final determination because the delegation was to have an opportunity to see for itself the sorts of circumstances that exist in East Timor today about which we needed to be aware.

The Standing Committee, in its report, virtually refused-I do not think that is too strong a word-to take much, if any, cognisance of the determinations of the delegation. The delegation comprised three members of the Government and two members of the Opposition. I think it is important to recall also that the Standing Committee's report was basically a long record of the disasters of colonial rule over several hundred years, of civil war and finally of invasion. Indeed, it was the story of a people who were, after all those experiences, still 90 per cent illiterate and suffering from disease and famine to a very high degree compared with other places around the world.

The question that we saw as being uppermost was the need to try desperately to find out whether the Timorese were better off or worse off today than they were before. One would be less than honest if one were to say that it was possible to be other than emotionally disturbed by some of the evidence that we received in the course of this investigation. On balance, we had to decide whether, in fact, in light of sometimes cold reality the present and future circumstances of the Timorese was likely to be better from the point of view of living standards, health, communications and, in fact, of family reunion than it had been in the past. There was no question that, in the past, it had not been good. For the Timorese and for Australian-Indonesian relations, we believed that it was better that investigations should come to the conclusions that we, as a minority in that Committee, came to.

It should be recalled, in fairness, that Indonesia at no stage attempted to invade Timor during the several hundred years of Portugese dominance. I believe that it was only when the Portugese stepped aside from their responsibility that the Indonesians became really concerned. They were concerned because they were unsure of the attitude of the Fretilin people. They were unsure whether they had an unfriendly presence in their immediate vicinity. Perhaps their reaction was not totally unpredictable.

Let me recall the dissenting report basically from a point of view of how its conclusions were reached. The information we believed was based directly or indirectly on the accounts of refugees whose unfortunate colonial experience- violent civil war and consequent invasion which had taken place over eight years -must have put some measure of doubt on its absolute accuracy. Indeed, despite our direction, the mass of the report dealt with the past. We found that, too, was contrary and certainly not helpful to the Timorese situation. There was sparse evidence, indeed, of the situation as it exists today. Indeed, the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Indonesia after its visit suggested, in the words of its leader, that there was no serious food shortage, that food production, health and education were improving faster than in most areas and that most Timorese consider they are comparitively well off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to this report as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence which inquired into the situation in East Timor. One factor remains outstanding despite the rhetoric of the Opposition in this matter. Despite eight years of history, the situation in East Timor is not quiet and it will not go away. During the last week in this Parliament two reports have been tabled, one from this Committee and the other from the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Indonesia. There is some conflict in those reports, but there are a number of aspects of the reports about which there is no conflict. There is no conflict about the fact that the East Timorese still do not enjoy the freedom to engage in political activities, they still do not enjoy freedom of speech, they still do not enjoy freedom of movement whether internally or externally and they do not enjoy the right to property. There is no organised structure of law and order which is acceptable. Reports as late as this morning indicate that there are summary executions and killings on East Timor.

SPEECH.PARA: Our report indicates-it is not disputed by the parliamentary delegation-that there is still no total freedom of religious practice and that cultural life on East Timor has changed and is changing under the orchestration of the foreign dominators. The most basic thing that cannot be disputed because it is not a matter of subjective judgment, it is a matter of international law, is that no matter how long the situation on East Timor is continued, the East Timorese have not exercised a right to self-determination. They have had imposed on them a puppet local representative body, and the Indonesian Government maintains that there has been an exercise of the right of self-determination. That has not been accepted by international forums and nor should it be because, as I said earlier , it is not a subjective judgment, it is a matter of international law. International law decrees that that right has not, in fact, been exercised.

There is no dispute also, although there may be some dispute about the degree, about the fact that there is still continuing resistance on East Timor. The resistance is evidenced by the fact that, to quote the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in answer to a question in yesterday's Hansard, there are 2, 800 detainees on the prison island of Atauro. Those detainees are fed by the Red Cross. If it was not for the Red Cross they would not be fed. There are no schools on the island even though 1,400 children live there. The families on the island are still barred from access to and communicaton with other relatives. The selection of people for Atauro is basically done on the premise that anyone with relatives still part of the resistance will find himself on the prison island.

That leads me to talk about the resistance. There are conflicting reports as to the degree of resistance. Some Indonesian authority figures indicate that there could be 2,000 supporters of Fretilin still resisting, but those figures are under a cloud. However, what is not disputed is that it is taking 7,000 to 20, 000 Indonesian troops to control the inhabitants of East Timor. If there was no resistance why is there a need for such a great number of people to control the inhabitants? In the report of Mr Denis Richardson submitted to the Senate Commitee quite recently the situation of the people living on Atauro was detailed. What was also detailed was that even until about a year ago 200 people died because of the conflict there. Even in Press reports this morning emanating from Indonesia and East Timor there is an indication that, as a consequence of the death of 15 Indonesian soldiers in East Timor four or five weeks ago, 200 people in a nearby village were executed by Indonesian soldiers in reprisals. No matter how much Australia wants to forget the situation in East Timor, it will not go away.

There is also some dispute as to whether the East Timorese are better off under Indonesian rule than they would have been under Fretilin or whatever sort of government might have evolved after the end of Portuguese domination. That may very well be in dispute, but it is not in dispute for those hundreds and thousands of East Timorese who have died. It is also not in dispute that, despite the spending of money on the building of schools and roads by Indonesians on East Timor, the local people are losing their culture. In fact, as has been evidenced by submissions to the Senate Committee, a large degree of graft and ripping off is going on, especially in the coffee trade on East Timor.

I now turn very briefly to the report of the Parliamentary Delegation, because it needs to be addressed. The report was produced after a four-day visit to East Timor, yet if we look at the length of the report we find that it is full of copious information, information which was also available to the Senate Committee, which took two years to address itself to the vital issues. I submit that the report of the Delegation did not address itself adequately to vital issues as the Senate Committee did. Its priorities were based on the premise:
The Indonesians certainly regard the Timor question as a critical test of Australian-Indonesian relations, indicating that if differences persist the whole relationship will suffer.

Realpolitick was important in this regard. It was a matter of forgetting our moral values and our value systems and accepting that the Indonesian power represented the thinking that might is right. As a consequence, value systems have to be discarded in the interests of such a philosophy.

The dissenters to the Committee's report based their disagreement on four grounds. They claimed that the majority report was based on emotional evidence, evidence which was frequently inaccurate. In response to this charge, I say that the evidence we found came not only from refugees from East Timor but also from sources such as Amnesty International, the Red Cross, Tapol and others. It was corroborated. It was evidence that may not stand up beyond reasonable doubt in court but to the extent that the witnesses were able to corroborate their own evidence from all parts of Australia it should be listened to. The Opposition in this place often places total credence in reports from refugees from the Soviet Union. Why do we draw a distinction between such instances and those involving Indonesian refugees?

Another point made by the dissenters is that the report should have addressed itself solely to the current conditions in East Timor. But we cannot look at the rights and situation of East Timorese now without looking at the decimation of their system over the last eight years. The claim was also made that there was a lack of contemporary evidence. The dissenting members should know, as many or most of them were at most meetings of the Committee, that evidence was received up until a couple of months ago and was therefore as current as was possibly available. We received the evidence from all sorts of quarters, organisations and bodies within Australia and from outside. The information was current. The evidence, as distinct from that given to the Parliamentary Delegation, was evidence which was subject to the scrutiny of the whole Committee.

A number of concerns arise from this Committee report. It is of concern that over the years, with respect to the refugee family reunion policy, Australia has been in essence taken for a ride. For five years now we have been promised that an agreed list would be completed. Time and again that list has been suspended. If it had been completed as had been agreed by the Indonesian Government in 1978 , we would not have had that carrot dangling before us over the last 12 months.

There is also the matter of the Department of Foreign Affairs and its involvement with East Timor. I am not one of those who believe in the principle of agent of influence, but when one looks at the submission of the Department, analyses and assesses it in the light of the principles of agent of influence, as has been espoused by some people, it would not be an unfair assessment to say that in respect to the East Timorese question the appropriate desk in the Department is acting in such a way. Another concern is one that was expressed most recently-on 9 September in an editorial in the Australian. It states:
The seizure of East Timor has established an alarming precedent for Indonesian expansion.
It continues:

Recent Australian governments have been anxious to do nothing which might affront Indonesia and cause it to refuse to accept our aid. But one of the difficulties of foreign relations is that one cannot always please everyone at the same time.

However important Indonesia's good will may be, Australia will not be advantaged if, by accepting the fait accompli of East Timor, we place in jeopardy other nations in our region whose security is vital to our own.
My time is running out, but I wish to say one more thing. I express this with regret: Information coming from the United Nations--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats oppose the amendment as proposed by Senator Scott since we believe from our observation that a human rights problem of considerable dimensions has existed and continues to exist in East Timor. But we note with interest the division of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on this matter, which is one which is reflected in the community. The Australian Democrats certainly believe that the East Timor issue presents both a moral and a practical set of problems to all Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal first with the moral problems. The first basic point of importance is that Indonesia has at no time had any historical, cultural or ethnic rights to East Timor, a territory which she invaded and took purely by conquest. East Timor was never part of the Netherlands East Indies to which Indonesia had some sort of territorial claim, as indeed she did to West Irian. That situation remains. The second moral problem is that the Indonesian invasion has caused, according to United Nations figures, between 100,000 and 200,000 deaths of Timorese-people to whom the people of Australia owe a debt of honour since they or perhaps their parents sacrificed their lives in the interests of Australian soldiers who were escaping from the Japanese during World War II. The third moral point is that Indonesia does what it does in East Timor in secrecy. It does not allow the rest of the world to see whether justice or injustice is being done. The fourth moral problem for Australia-of course, this is the bottom line and the crunch one for us as a nation-is the question of whether one gives in to violence and injustice purely for the sake of expediency. Does one become an appeaser? Is it good enough for us as a nation to do that?

On the practical side the first problem concerns the implications for Papua New Guinea. This has been reflected, since I first raised this matter publicly some two months ago, by very many people, especially those from Papua New Guinea, who have spoken to me about it. I am now aware that there is a great degree of concern in Papua New Guinea about Indonesia's possible interest in that territory and some knowledge there of the historic perception of Papua New Guinea by Indonesia as its territory. The second practical consideration is that East Timor could be a good small neighbour. It could become a part of the comity of Pacific nations, prosperous and autonomous, as could places such as Vanuatu. I think it is quite wrong for people to say that that is not he case.

DEBATE.TITLE: LIVE-STOCK SLAUGHTER (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983GRAIN (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983EGGS (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983EDIBLE OILS (EXPORT INSPECTION CHARGE) AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -Mr Deputy President, before the suspension of the sitting I was concluding my remarks on the Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Amendment Bill and the associated Bills. In concluding my remarks now, I want to recall that I had indicated the very severe impost on the industry of a trebling of the export inspection charge as mirrored in the legislation. I had indicated the enormous toll of the drought, the intolerable design of imposing 50 per cent of the trebled charges at one blow-charges for an as yet imperfect and costly inspection system. I had also indicated the serious omission of proper consultation with industry prior to the establishment of this legislation and had emphasised the need for that sort of consultation in depth if the best result is to be achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: I had a phone call during the afternoon from an export abattoir in the Central Tablelands of New South Wales, explaining once again its concern at the matters to which I had referred. This particular abattoir indicated that, with an 80 per cent kill for the local market, it is hounded by an export charge that puts it at an extraordinary disadvantage with so many of its local competitors. Mr Deputy President, I commend to the Senate the amendment that I moved at the beginning of my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating four Bills-the Live- stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Amendment Bill 1983, the Grain ( Export Inspection Charge) Amendment Bill 1983, the Eggs (Export Inspection Charge) Amendment Bill 1983 and the Edible Oils (Export Inspection Charge) Amendment Bill 1983. These charges were first imposed as from 1 July 1979 in order for the Government to recoup 50 per cent of the cost of carrying out the inspection of these commodities where they are about to enter the export market. In 1975 the Industries Assistance Commission recommended that, with the exception of meat, inspection costs should be transferred from the Commonwealth to the relevant industries. In its recent report on the abattoir and meat processing industry, the IAC said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission can see no reason why inspection per se should be funded by the community as a whole.

Due to increased costs for these inspection services, the industries are failing by far to contribute 50 per cent of the costs involved. The figures are roughly 17 per cent only for inspections in the meat industry, 32 per cent for grain, 33 per cent for eggs and a miniscule 15 per cent contribution by producers for the inspection costs involved in the export of edible oil.

I certainly have always suspected that at least in part some of these increased charges will be passed back to the producers by way of a lower price for their commodity in the market place. However, one can cite the case of the meat industry where I believe much of the demand for more rigorous inspections came about as the result of particularly America and Japan using these increased inspections as a mechanism to protect their own producers. Rigorous inspections on meat have been followed by more rigorous inspections as a result of the findings of the royal commission into that industry. Of course, the need for that royal commission arose because crooks, con men or perhaps just smart-Alicks in the trade were out to make a fast buck, having absolutely no concern at all for the industry or for the thousands of honest people within that industry. On Monday, before Senate Estimates Committee C, Mr Miller, the Deputy Secretary to the Department of Primary Industry, had this to say in response to a question from Senator Archer:

We could certainly concede that the Export Inspection Service has quite a lot of change yet to be brought about in it. Costs have been contained, only contained, at present. Most of the reasons for the increase this year is the taking over of the State Inspection Service in New South Wales. This has resulted in substantial savings and will result in more savings as we fully integrate those two services. A string of further changes are to be made in the organisation of the Export Inspection Service which are all under development and which will all be brought into a compact five-year corporate plan for the development of the Export Inspection Service. We expect that to be complete within the next month or so.

Costs of all services are continually on the increase, for a variety of reasons, but I can only hope that those involved-I speak particularly of the meat industry-from the producers up will take more interest in these things so that we can never again get into the mess that occurred under previous Ministers for primary industry, which did enormous damage to our meat trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Senate has before it a package of four Bills dealing with export inspection charges. Under the Live-stock Slaughter ( Export Inspection Charge) Amendment Bill, additional charges have been imposed for the export inspection services, the intention of which is to recoup some of the money being expended in providing those services. The Fraser Government made an announcement that it would seek to recover 50 per cent of those costs and I presume that that is still the policy of the Liberal and National parties. The Government in these Bills has moved towards the same position. I do not think that there can be much disagreement on the basis that there ought to be a recovery of costs in the area. I think the difficulty that a number of honourable senators are having and certainly the one that I have is that these costs should come on at such a high rate so rapidly at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: I think a general phasing in of costs on any industry is vital for the stability of that industry and for its ability to adapt to those costs. Nowhere, of course, is it more apparent than in the cattle industry, which has gone through extremely bad times. At the moment, the average inspection cost per head of cattle would be about $1.80. The difficulty, of course, is that there are differentiating charges in relation to whether there are fewer than 100 cattle, but on average we are looking at $1.80. The current legislation provides for $2. 40 as a maximum levy. The Government proposes to raise this levy to $10.80 per beast. As a maximum levy, that would be an extraordinary jump, but in his second reading speech, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Walsh), makes clear that what the Government is looking at in this financial year is an increase to $5.40 per adult cattle. That would represent basically a recoupment of approximately 39 per cent of the cost of operating the meat inspection service.

I do not intend tonight to dwell too long on the meat inspection service. It has been a matter of debate in this place for quite some time. But I do return again to the report of the Kelly Committee of Inquiry to Examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems. Indeed, if that Committee's report had been taken up by the Government at the time, we might not now be facing the type of problems we are facing in the industry. I thought the report contained eminently sensible and reasonable suggestions, and it is gratifying to note that at least some movement is being made to unify the meat inspection service.

The problems involved with this matter, of course, are not all on the part of the Commonwealth. The States have not been as co-operative as I think they ought to have been in this regard and hence it has been very difficult even to move towards the pace that has taken place to date. Nevertheless, what is happening now is that the costs involved in the industry from the meat inspection service are being visited on the producers at a time not only of depressed prices on the international market but also when the beef industry is coming out of an extremely severe drought. It seems to me, therefore, that one ought not look at the industry apart from the economic climate that now occurs here and the economic climate that our beef exporters have to compete with.

Most of our major trading opponents in this area have the full cost of meat inspection met by the Government. This is not a problem which is unique to beef. It is a problem that bedevils all of our primary products on the export market. But I think we have to pay some attention to the fact that we are attempting to compete in an international market in which our opponents have an enormous advantage. Indeed, a reliable estimate by the Cattle Council of Australia has suggested that in the ensuing 12 months our particular industry will have a $40m disadvantage compared with competitors in relation to international meat sales. That is an extremely difficult leeway to pick up. Our own producers start behind scratch in trying to compete in the international market and it seems to me that it is reasonable to expect at this particular time that any increase in costs that the Government places on the meat inspection charges ought to be of a moderate kind, and not excessive.

The proposal of $10.80 as a maximum charge obviously gives the Government a reasonable amount of leeway in terms of what it might propose to do in ensuing financial years with recovery costs. I believe that it is probably appropriate that that type of level that is being struck ought not be available in the legislation. I give notice that in the Committee stages of the debate on the Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Amendment Bill I will seek to move a request that the amount be not $10.80 but rather $5.40. That will have the result of requiring the Government to return to the Parliament to debate the next increase. It will not, however, affect the revenue raising in the current financial year.

I believe it is important that each of those charges be debated separately at this time because the industry is not one which has an endless possibility of recovery. It is in extremely difficult circumstances. We know that the cyclical legislation in the United States will probably suggest in the next year that the United States market for our beef will be decreasing. We know that the European Economic Community intends to lower its import of Australian beef and that the development of new markets, particularly in Asia, has not been as successful as we would have liked. It is an extremely competitive and difficult area in which to deal, and I think we have done reasonably well to date. But the only way we will be able to compete in the future is simply to have a keenly priced product in those markets. I think with these suggested maximum levels of $10.80 that such a possibility may very well elude our producers in Australia.

The comments that I have made in relation to beef might well apply to the other Bills. However, there are specific problems in relation to edible oils and eggs in terms of inspection which I think make them less appropriate for the propositions that I intend to move in relation to beef. There are some peculiar problems that we do not have time really to debate here, particularly in relation to egg production in Australia. I hope that we get from the Minister, in his response, particularly in relation to beef charges, some more clarification as to the ultimate intention of the Government. Indeed, on one reading of the Minister's second reading speech, one might imagine that we were to move beyond the 50 per cent recovery. This may be the intention of the Government, or it may be something that the Government wishes to flag for future years. I think it would be of very keen interest to the producers to know what the program looks like in terms of these charges in the next two or three years. I think it would also be very interesting, and here I think there is support from all parties, to know of the Government's success in moving to retain costs in the inspection area and whether the Government has the possbility of closure in relation to a single meat inspection service in Australia-

TALK.START.PARA: —Has what?

—Has the ability to tell us when we might actually get there. I know we have moved a fair way. I know that the problems in some of the States, my own State of Queensland included, have been fairly difficult. I think it would be useful if we and the producers knew that relief will be forthcoming in the near future from the total costs of the ultimate inefficiencies which now exist in the system not only because of the duplication of meat inspection services but also because of some of the other aspects of the meat inspection services which were revealed by the Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I point to the problems that have raised by other speakers in relation to the differentiated charges that we discover when we look across the various States. We should be told why there should be such a disparity in charges between the States, particularly when we look at the volume of inspections in which the States are engaging. We can readily accept that an irreducible level of costs is necessary to maintain the service. But, if we make a comparison of cost between Queensland and New South Wales, I think it is very difficult to understand why that cost differential exists particularly when we look at the number of beasts slaughtered in those States. To my mind, there seems to be very little reason why the costs in New South Wales seemingly should be so much higher than the costs in Queensland. It may be that there is a reasonable explanation why the unit cost apparently should be so much higher in New South Wales than it is in Queensland.

I think that these are the sorts of items which really ought to have been ventilated to some degree in the Minister's second reading speech. I believe that, when we increase costs significantly in not only the primary industry area but also in any industry it is useful for the Government to indicate its general plans for that area so that we can then respond in a reasonable way to the representations of producers and others in that industry as to what will be the final outcome of the escalating costs. Producers are often much more ready to accept a reasonable increase in charges if one can point to constructive action to be taken, if one can point to a containment of costs in the near future and if one can point to increased efficiencies which are likely in the area in the short and medium term. However, escalating costs are met with opposition in any industry and the amount of information that is then provided is generally pretty scanty. I would hope that the new Government might do something in this regard. I have seen some recent Press reports that something along these lines will be adopted. It is a pity that this practice was not applied to the legislation before us. I believe that all Bills that seek to increase costs should be accompanied by a general overview of the industry so that producers can more readily accept the increased charges. While in one sense it is certainly very easy to raise charges, in another sense it is easy to collect them. I think it is far better if a person knows why he has to pay. He should know that in meeting government charges he is not paying into a bottomless pit but that he is getting a return for every dollar that he has to pay to the Government by way of inspection charges and the like.

I therefore indicate that the Australian Democrats will support the amendment which has been moved by Senator Scott to the second reading stage of this legislation. I think that the sentiments expressed in the amendment are moderate and should be accepted. I think it would probably have been preferable if the Government proceded along the lines set out in the amendment. I also indicate that, at the Committee stage, I will move an amendment to the Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charges) Amendment Bill to request the House of Representatives to lower the amount which the Government proposes to charge during this financial year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that, before we start to consider the implications of the legislation, we need to remember that Australia is one of the freer trading countries of the world and that it depends very heavily on its exports. Secondary industry contributes very little to our export trade but our resource and primary products are very significant. As such, we need to consider how our competitors operate, particularly in the primary area.

SPEECH.PARA: As we know, bulk food is very heavily traded throughout the world not only between the northern hemisphere and the southern hemisphere and between the developed countries but also between the developed and undeveloped countries. If necessary, some forms of assistance are regularly provided in these trading countries. One has only to consider the situation that exists with our trans- Tasman colleagues, the European Economic Community or Northern America to see the importance that other countries and other groups of countries place on keeping their primary products moving. We are all tied into the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade system which Australia endeavours scrupulously to observe as do some other countries. But we should not overlook the importance of our export industries to the national economy. We should remember that the health and strength of these national industries really reflect the health and strength of the whole economy.

Like most new charges, export inspection charges were imposed at a time of high prosperity in November 1973. There has never since been a similar occasion when the industry has been as prosperous. Of course, I note that in May 1979 the then Treasurer had another bite on the basis that the industry was doing quite well and could stand increased charges. However, the reverse position never seems to apply, that is, when the industry cannot stand these imposts the level of charges is wound back.

I wish to quote a few passages from the Industries Assistance Commission interim report of 12 December 1975 entitled 'Financing Promotion of Rural Products (Export Inspection of Rural Products)'. The remarks in this report are as relevant today as they were at that time.
The following comment is made at page 17 of the report:

The figures in Table 4 show that the incidence of the Meat Export Charge on beef and mutton has increased significantly from November 1973 when the charge was introduced. The table illustrates the point that if the levy is retained as a long run policy, then whenever meat prices are low, the levy will impose a significant reduction in the gross incomes of meat producers, and an even larger percentage reduction in their net incomes.

This charge was regarded as cream off the top when the scheme was started. It has become a major impost in times of low return. One of the results of that impost was set out on page 18 of the same report. The report states:

In other words, because the payment of the export levy by the exporter rather than the Government results in lower returns from exports and thus lower domestic prices, local consumers benefit at the expense of local producers.

The illustration also indicates that the burden on primary producers, if they were to meet the cost of export inspections by an export levy, would be about double this cost. That is what transpired in 1975, and I assure honourable senators that it is just as true today as it has been every year since then. As a direct charge against export productivity, governments have to decide whether the loss in productivity and the reduction of taxable income are reasonable offsets to the recovery of the dues. I will now read the first part of the conclusion of that same report because, as I have said, it is just as relevant today. We have ignored the advice that was given to us by the IAC in those days. It states:

The levy was introduced at a time when the industry was enjoying buoyant market conditions and it was claimed that, in any case, a considerable part of the levy could be passed on to overseas consumers under those market conditions.

However, the export charge results in the long run in a substantial loss in income to meat producers, the loss being much more than the cost of export inspections recouped by the Government. If the cost of export inspections were borne by the Government there would be a transfer of income from taxpayers and from domestic consumers to producers. Because meat production would become more profitable resources would be attracted to this activity. Since the transferred resources would come mainly from activities which are relatively higher cost than meat production, there would be a net economic gain to the whole community.

That was what the IAC said in 1975. We are now in 1983 and we still have not learned that lesson. As the report states, as from the day of commencement of this system the costs have just climbed and climbed. Now that we have reached this ridiculous $10.80 per head, I think it is about time that we had a good look at the whole reason behind it, the value of charging it and what we are getting for it. While we have a system where the major contributors to it have no say in how it is run, there is no encouragement for any form of economy in how it is run.

I believe that there should be no charge for export inspection. I am prepared to live with one provided that it is on an agreed and efficient system. Personally, I do not think there should be one, and I never have thought so. It has to be a reasonable charge in the export industry, if there is to be one. At present we have legislation before us when there is no finalised scheme, no established pattern and no evidence that we have tightened the efficiency in any way. Two days ago I asked questions on the Estimates Committee C. Senator Primmer has quoted a portion of the transcript. It clearly indicated that there is considerable hope that we will see an improvement in a program that may extend for five years. Even though there has been a considerable increase in the number of officers, I was somewhat horrified to find that most of them were employed on a permanent employee basis. We hoped that the employment of these officers would be on a temporary basis until we were able to tidy up and tighten up some of the ridiculous expenditure that is currently being charged to the producers.

While this system prevails, the producers are paying. Clearly, the Government should be paying while it is tinkering with the scheme. It is a period of development and I do not believe that it is reasonable in any way, while this is going on, for the producer to have to pay as much as he will be asked to pay. To bring in these charges at a time that coincides with the drought conditions is most unfortunate and badly thought out. It is a most vicious increase, and we all feel sorry for the people who will suffer a 300 per cent increase in charges of this nature, with no undertaking that the system will be improved. The increase attacks the export earnings of all Australians as well as the producer and everyone down the production line. I do not think there can be any support for the method of arriving at the cost to be recovered because I cannot find that it represents the cost.

I will seek approval to incorporate in Hansard a schedule which demonstrates the method of calculation. I would like the Minister for Veterans' Affairs ( Senator Gietzelt) in due course to explain whether this is still the method that is used in arriving at the cost of meat inspection. The document I wish to incorporate is a table that was provided in a letter dated 5 May 1982 from the Department of Primary Industry to the Australian Fishing Industry Council concerning fish export charges. Besides listing all the costs involved, it includes an item of on-cost provision based on 50 per cent of the salary component. I have never heard of any industry in the world that could add a 50 per cent on-cost component and reasonably charge it to the users. If this is the system, I would like to know. If it is not, I would like to know when we changed it and in what areas. When I read the Bill, nothing in it states that we are charging people a 50 per cent on-cost. When I read through the estimates for the Department of Primary Industry for 1983-84 there is nothing that states that we are charging a 50 per cent on-cost; nor does it state what that on-cost is meant to include. However, I understand that 27 per cent of it represents superannuation. For superannuation charges to be paid by casual users of a service of this sort is certainly a bit rich. Any organisation which believes that it can get away with a 50 per cent on-cost needs to be investigated very thoroughly. What an indictment of any government operation if it has to add 50 per cent.

I believe that any of those who participate in the scheme, any of the users who are paying, should have a far greater say in how the system is run. In spite of the fact that in answers to questions we were advised that most of the suggestions for improvement had come from within the Department and not from the exporters, processors or producers, I am sure that not many of those people could run a business which showed the degree of laxity that has shown up in the meat inspection service in the last year or so and yet still charge a 50 per cent overrider on the costs.

I believe that there are alternatives for far simpler and far better systems. I see no reason why we cannot work towards a system whereby there are enormous penalties for misdemeanours, where the packers are responsible for quality and where any misdemeanour should include not only an enormous fine but also a total loss of licence. We could clean up and speed up the system in many ways. While it is in the process of being tidied up, the Government should pay. It is not reasonable to have this expensive system at the expense of the producer who has no say in the running of it. It is not the processor who pays; it is the producer. In times like this when we are trying to struggle out of a drought, that is just too much to bear. Not enough action is being taken. While the producer is paying, the Government is not hastening its efforts to get the job through.

I believe in the export inspection service. I believe it is absolutely and vitally important to Australia. I certainly give it my support. I expect that it should be more cost efficient and that it should be tidied up. I believe that it can be an excellent service. I ask the Government to reconsider the charges in line with the comments I have made.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the table which I mentioned earlier.
