SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating four Bills relating to export inspection charges. Tonight I propose to speak only to one of those Bills , the Live-stock Slaughter (Export Inspection Charge) Amendment Bill 1983. The purpose of this Bill is to increase the maximum charge on the slaughter of livestock in export establishments. I emphasise the words 'export establishments '. Honourable senators will appreciate that all stock which passes through such an export slaughter house, whether for export or not, must incur the high new charges imposed under this Bill. I agree with Senator Archer; there is a need for an explanation as to how these costs are arrived at, because those honourable senators who have been through slaughter houses and have seen what goes on will realise that a charge of $10.80 a beast is far too high.

SPEECH.PARA: Primary industry in Australia is emerging from one of the worst droughts in its history. What has the Budget done to stimulate the competitiveness of Australian primary industry? It has done very little. Despite this, the Government expects this particular sector of the economy, the primary industry sector, to be one of its saviours and to provide that stimulus to economic growth on which much of the Budget strategy depends. In fact, in the Budget Papers is the statement that there is expected to be a strong rise in livestock prices. I wonder what attitude lamb producers take at the present time towards that forecast, because anybody who reads the newspapers at the moment will have seen that depressed prices are being paid for lamb and will know just how farcical this move is. In effect, I suggest this statement is very much a pipe dream.

I believe that this measure, along with others, must really be examined not only in the light of the August 1983 Budget but also in relation to the May mini -Budget, which was very harsh on the primary producing sector of the economy. I think that those two documents have singled out primary industry for special treatment. In other words, primary industry has had to bear the brunt of a lot of the hard decisions that the Government believed were necessary. I believe it is quite unfair. Some of these charges will mean, in percentage terms, fairly astronomical increases in cost. For example, the increase in the livestock slaughter levy since 1978 approximates 600 per cent. Under this Bill meat inspection charges rise by about 200 per cent. Although we are talking about maximum figures, they are gigantic figures. The Government's policy to recoup 50 per cent of the cost of inspection services from the industry will mean that the charge for a cattle carcass will rise by $1.80 to $5.40. That is the cost to the industry itself. It is a 50 per cent recovery rate.

The conclusion that we must reach from all this is that farmers themselves are being asked to pay for the mismanagement of the meat inspection service. Therefore, there is a need for a complete review, standardisation and a full explanation of how these costs are arrived at. Again, we find that decisions have been taken without consultation with the industry. That reflects another of the Government's broken promises. The tragedy of it all is that it is another broken promise. Honourable senators should be aware that practically all of Australia's major competitors have meat inspection services that are totally funded by their governments. The industry in Australia, therefore, is operating at a cost disadvantage to this extent.

I believe this situation reaches the height of absurdity when we examine the pig industry. The amount spent in export inspection changes is more than the pig export market is worth. It is the height of absurdity when we reach that stage. There is something like a 300 per cent increase. The charges amount to $5.9m compared with an export value of the pig market of $4.9m. The pig industry, of course, is not an export orientated industry. With these sorts of costs and with the sort of inefficiency that is foist upon it, how can the Government ever expect it to emerge as an export industry?

Producers believe that there is a need for a restructuring of the meat inspection service to ensure that the service is very much more efficient and cost effective. Therefore, I support the amendment moved by Senator Scott, which indicates that rural industries are struggling to emerge from one of our worst droughts. Firstly, it states that this is not the time for this sector of our economy to bear the burden of such massive increases in charges. Secondly, it states that the industry should not be expected to contribute 50 per cent of the costs of Commonwealth inspection until the export service restructuring is completed and the service is as efficient and cost effective as possible. Thirdly, it states that there is inadequate industry participation in inspection procedures. Fourthly, it states that we should recognise that regrettably there has not been full consultation with industry on all aspects of the development of the Export Inspection Service and export charges.

This Bill reflects an attack on primary industry. Many in the industry-I think it is a forlorn hope-are trying to persuade the Government to include the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr John Kerin, in the Cabinet. They believe that if he were a member of Cabinet maybe the primary producers' voice could be heard much more effectively in the inner sanctums. The Minister for Primary Industry in the Labor Government, who we believe is one of the most important Ministers, is outside Cabinet. I ask honourable senators to contrast that situation with what occured when the Liberal and National parties were in government. The Minister for Primary Industry in that Government was a member of the inner Ministry. That was of benefit to primary industry. Primary industry is facing difficulties at the present time. I believe its hope is a forlorn hope, because whilst the Minister for Primary Industry is not a member of Cabinet he can sympathise with primary producers but cannot achieve their high expectations. At the same time, the Government is expecting export primary industries to lead the economic recovery of Australia. It will be difficult because, as I will mention later, there is a great deal of fragility in the structure of the 1982 Budget. I support the amendment proposed by Senator Scott.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has a contribution to make to this debate. Having listened to a number of honourable senators who have spoken in this debate, one can only come to the conclusion that they are involved in a tactic of humbug and hypocrisy. Honourable senators opposite should bear in mind that the Government's propositions before the Senate are in fact a continuation of the policies begun by the previous Government and continued every year since 1979. The basis of those policies was that industry should pay some contribution towards the orderly marketing and processing arrangements that occur in rural industries. The Government, of course, is very supportive and very conscious of the need to have a virile and active rural sector. Consequently we have taken steps-contrary to what the amendment seeks to do-to consult with the various sectors of the rural industries about this legislation. It is true that consultation does not mean that the Government is abdicating its position, but I can assure honourable senators that, as Mr Kerin indicated in the House of Representatives debate, there has been adequate consultation from the Government's point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition does not seem to know where it is going in respect of a whole variety of policy issues. On the one hand we have representatives of the National Party of Australia criticising the Government for being a big spender in respect of the Budget. In this legislation, where we are seeking to recover 50 per cent of the costs involved in these industries-livestock, grain and edible oils-we are accused of imposing some levy on the industry which is now, as distinct from last year, in a position to carry that levy. Of course, if the levy is not carried by the rural sector it will have to be met from the Budget. That fact seems to escape the logic and understanding of those who want to make some cheap political capital out of this issue. We recognise that the rural sector has been through a very difficult time but surely no one can argue logically, in the current situation, that we are not anticipating, as all the economists associated with the rural sector have done, that there will be a big increase in the rural sector component of the gross national product. Consequently, in view of that upturn it is only properly and logically, as it has been in every Budget debate in recent years, the responsibility of the industry to bear some part of the cost in respect of the various matters that form part of these four Bills.

As both the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) in the other place and his representative in this place, the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh have pointed out the Government is still heavily subsidising each of these sectors. For example, we will collect only 17 per cent of the costs involved in the livestock inspection industry. We will collect only 32 per cent of the costs involved in the grain industry and only 15 per cent in the edible oils industry. So already Budget, taxation revenue and the community generally are making more than a generous contribution towards these important industries. We recognise, of course, that that is a responsibility the Government must bear and is prepared to bear. In those circumstances one can say only that there has been a great deal of debate of very little substance that ought not to enjoy the support of the Senate.

I think Senator Archer asked what the cost component was for 50 per cent of the meat inspection charge. I am advised that there is an accurate costing of all of the charges in the meat inspection industry. I appreciate that it is very important to have the meat inspection charges because they help us to meet our obligations to the export industry. There is no arbitrary addition to that cost structure except for the superannuation component which has been included as 20 per cent of wages and 25 per cent of long service leave. They are legitimate charges in carrying out these activities which, I remind honourable senators, protect the rural sector. They protect the producers who honourable senators have been speaking about at some length.

The Government has no quarrel with the approach that we must accept our responsibilities to protect the producers. But surely they have some responsibility in this matter. That is to pay the levy which, I remind Senator Watson, was part of his Government's legislation. As he well recognises, the drought did not start on 4 February of this year. It has been with us in recent years. The legislation which was carried by the Senate last year was the former Government's legislation. It was of almost exactly the same content as the legislation that the Opposition is criticising tonight. When honourable senators read the debates that took place in the House of Representatives they will see the absolute cant and humbug of the National Party members. They did precious little in the seven years in which they had the capacity to do something as the long arm of the coalition Government. They were always twisting the arm of the Liberal Party and they told us they could get whatever concessions they wanted in these matters. But the plain facts are that we have had the same type of legislation since 1979.

I am also advised that the staffing arrangements have remained static during the first half of this year and that the central office staff has increased from 94 to 117. Twenty-five of those persons are on short term transfer for developmental work and will return to regional offices when their current projects have been completed. The Public Service that has been providing these services has carried on without interference by the new Government the same sort of support policies which were characteristic of the previous Government. One can only repeat what Mr Kerin said in reply to the debate in the House of Representatives: It is about time the Opposition got its act together on a whole variety of issues, including those in the rural sector. Consequently, the Government opposes the amendment moved by Senator Scott. In regard to paragraph (A), we believe that the drought is over and that the rural sector is on the upturn. In paragraph (B) he said that industries should not be expected to contri- bute 50 per cent of the costs of Commonwealth inspection, but that has been his Party's policy since 1979. There has been consultation in respect of paragraphs (C) and (D) of his amendment. Accordingly, the Government opposes the amendment.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Scott's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -I must indicate that the Opposition regards this as a Budget Bill and thus cannot support the proposed amendments. We have already indicated our extreme concern at the severity of applying a 50 per cent impost for an inspection service which, as has been made abundantly clear, is an incomplete and at this stage relatively inefficient service. But over and above these considerations, the $5.40 charge to which it is proposed that the $10.80 charge should be reduced, will in no way affect the charge on the industry in the current year. On that ground, as well as on other matters referable to the Budget context, the Opposition must oppose the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will oppose the amendments on the grounds that they seek to set in money terms the levy which will actually be operative in this year and therefore , if costs in total should subsequently rise, would preclude the policy of 50 per cent cost recovery operating without further amendment of the Act. Unless we believe that inflation will be held at zero it is almost inevitable that there will be increased costs. Probably there is significant scope for improving the efficiency of the service and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) has in hand proposals to that end. But it would not be realistic to believe that, for an indefinite period, the 50 per cent cost recovery policy could be put into effect and the money charge held at the level operative this year. Given that fact, at some time in the future the Parliament would be cluttered with further amending legislation, when that could be avoided by rejecting the proposed amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I might add that the amendments proposed tonight break new ground in the sense that in all comparable pieces of legislation, which I can recall, it has been customary to set in the legislation a maximum charge which is higher than that which is actually applied at that time. This has occurred for many years under both Labor and non-Labor governments. I cannot think of any piece of legislation in which that has not been the case. Senator Macklin's amendments propose to break new ground in that way. For all those reasons, the Government will oppose the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy ( Senator Walsh) made a point about maximum charges. I would like him to explain why that has been the practice. I am interested why that procedure is carried out and why Senator Macklin's amendments are perhaps not as satisfactory because they do not do that.

—The basic reason why this is so is that for the last decade we have had an average rate of inflation of around 10 per cent. I would not like to be held rigidly to that figure. Even prior to that we had had inflation rates which in some years went as high as 4 per cent or 5 per cent and which were habitually at 2 per cent to 3 per cent. The procedure had been adopted that, in order to avoid amending legislation every year to maintain the real level of charges and levies, some scope was given in the legislation. A ceiling was imposed by the legislation but it was not immediately applied by way of a levy and could subsequently be varied to take account of inflation without entailing further amending legislation. That is the reason for the practice which has been followed in the past. The Government believes there is not a sufficiently valid case for departing from that policy.

—I ask the Minister to incorporate in Hansard the breakdown of the costings of how the export inspection charges are made up and the various items that are included. One of the biggest problems that I have encountered is-
—Do you mean the table you showed me an hour ago?
—No, it is a similar table. It is based on the Bills about which we are talking now and how the charges are made up.

—The Australian Democrats are interested that the Opposition-the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia-will not support our amendments. Notwithstanding the strong speeches made in the House of Representatives by the honourable member for Darling Downs, Mr McVeigh, and the strong speech made here by Senator Scott, they will not support our amendments because they will not interfere with or vote against a Budget measure. I just note that with interest. I pose the question that it puzzles me how they can adopt that stand on this Bill and yet give notice that they are resolutely opposed to other Budget Bills such as the Dividend Recoupment Tax Bill. I make that statement in a state of puzzlement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose the Loan Bill (No. 2) 1983 which has been introduced by the Government for the purpose of making provision for the financing of the prospective 1983-84 deficit . It is the normal process to introduce a Bill of this kind. Of course, the Budget deficit in prospect for this year is $8.4 billion. The Bill will enable the funding of the deficit and authorise payments from the Loan Fund to meet defence and certain non-defence expenditures. As I said, it is a normal process of the Budget procedure to introduce a Bill of this kind. The Opposition does not oppose it.

SPEECH.PARA: I take the opportunity to make one or two comments on the Budget which this Bill proposes to fund. Many remarks were made the morning after the Budget along the lines that it was a mild-mannered Budget. It was described by many commentators immediately following its release as one that gave some relief to those who might have expected, because of statements that had been made, a Budget that was predicted to be more harsh. I think it is fair to say now that there has been some change to that attitude. The Budget is seen more for what it is than what people had feared it might be. Rather than it being described as a mild-mannered Budget it has, on occasions, been described as a broken promises Budget. I think it is fair to observe that any Budget is a political document. It has political objectives. This Budget carries the political objectives of the new Government.

In considering some of the broken promises-perhaps they are past history-one recalls that there were promises of tax cuts for about six million Australians, but there have been tax increases; there were to be changes to the tax scales, but there have been no changes in the tax scales; there were to be changes in the tax thresholds but that did not occur; there were to be increases for pensioners, tax thresholds, but that did not occur; and there were to be increases in spouse rebates. One could go through the whole catalogue of things that people were expecting from the policies that had been enunciated in the time leading up to the March election.

There were promises of cheaper petrol whereas the Budget provides for dearer petrol. There were to be no devaluations whereas there was an almost immediate devaluation of the currency. There were no proposed changes to superannuation, whereas we have had the continuing saga of the increased tax on lump sum superannuation payments. There were to be increases in pensions as a proportion of average weekly earnings. We have found that that promise has not been put into effect. There were to be increases in fringe benefits; we find that pensions are now to be subject to a means test. All these promises were made. Benefits that one would have expected in the first Budget of a new government have not been introduced. In fact, I think we could sum up the Budget by saying that it is based on a theme of an inflation mentality. It has, as one of its primary objectives, a shift to the public sector wherever that is possible.

Those who share the Government's philosophies would acknowledge that the Budget makes strong and immediate steps towards socialist objectives. One needs only to look very speedily at some aspects of the Budget to find the objective in relation to health insurance. The health program introduced by the Government should have been expected from the Government because of its policy. That policy , over the coming months and years, will need to be subjected to an analysis of the philosophy upon which it is based because it is based on a social system rather than on a health care system. It will be seen to be just that as the people of Australia experience the proposals contained in it.

Earlier today we talked about housing. Here again we see the objective is to shift to the public sector the housing needs wherever that is possible. Despite all the promises for improvements to the unemployment situation, it could be said that the only real growth in jobs immediately evident in the Budget is in the public sector. It was pointed out by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) in a speech a short time ago that there is a retreat from the full employment commitment to the people of Australia.

We have had discussions in this place today with regard to the shifts, however slight at this stage, that have been made to public sector funding of education. The Government's education policy threatens the right of parents to choose the system of education they would like for their children. The Budget also shows the usual socialist approach of Labor and its hangup on capital held by Australians, however modest. We find that expressed in the proposals that have come forward since the Government was elected in respect of the tax on lump sum superannuation payments and the list of assets which now may be held by a pensioner without suffering a means test. In just those personal service areas of housing, health, education and social security, we find immediately an intrusion by government. It has come about in some instances by a shift into the public sector of things which were being properly handled by people themselves; in others through a threat to the right to choose.

As I said earlier, such a policy is based on an inflation mentality. I think that is so because, if we look at the approach to the revenue side of the Budget , we will find that now enshrined in the Budget are indexed increases each six months in traditional excise rates. It has been found necessary to enshrine in the Budget a mechanism to account for the inflation that obviously is expected to occur. Yet on the other side we find no recognition of inflation and its effect on personal taxes. It is all right to index up excise but there is no recognition of the effect of inflation on personal taxes and the indexing of threshold levels so that people on even average weekly earnings will move quite quickly and sharply into higher tax brackets. There are to be increases of about $44m in a full year in sales taxes. They have been styled by the Government as just increases to adjust anomalies. Nevertheless, they are increases in indirect taxes.

In the Budget as a whole we find an increase in outlays of 15.8 per cent and an increase in receipts of 8.6 per cent. What is more important is that the deficit of $8.4 billion represents 4.7 per cent of gross domestic product. This should be contrasted with last year's Budget deficit, which represented 2.8 per cent of gross domestic product. In that sense, this year's Budget is right on target for a big spending government because this is the largest deficit since 1975 in terms of percentage of gross domestic product.

The other significant factor about the Budget which we will fund under this Loan Bill is that it is based precariously on the wages policy arising from the prices and incomes accord. The accord has been the subject of discussion and it will need continuing discussion. It is recognised by the Government, and certainly by those who are affected by it, that our inflation rate is dangerously above the average rate of the industrialised world. Australia is extremely uncompetitive in those areas where we may be able to assist in employment opportunities. It is fair to say that not many options were available to the Government, which promised an early return to a private sector recovery, because there are economic difficulties and the problem of rising unemployment. At best, a strategy which maximised the benefits that might have flowed from the United States recovery was something that we should have been looking for in this Budget. We should have been laying the ground work for the opportunity for private sector investment and employment to improve as a result of the recovery in the United States economy and the opportunities that would have given us. Instead, I believe that the Government in the Budget has chosen the wrong course . As I said earlier, the Budget was styled as being mild mannered, but doubts and concern are now being expressed about its economic integrity.

This Budget needs to be looked at against a background of the wages policy because it has been said again and again that that is the linchpin on which the Budget has been devised. If the prices and incomes accord does not work, not only would the Budget's economic integrity be at risk, but also it would be seen as the wrong Budget for Australia in the present economic climate. I think it was fascinating that the deficit figure was decided on months before the Budget had been framed and the income and expenditure of the Budget had been subjected to the tests that need be made in looking at a government's responsibilities. It seemed that some figure had been agreed upon by groups of people in conjunction with Government presentation of the figure of approximately $8.5 billion as the right figure. But taking into account present economic circumstances and the growth that has occurred, the figure of $8.5 billion was quite the wrong sort of figure to have suggested. With the stimulus that will come if the growth that the Government predicts eventuates, we will find that the deficit figure to be funded by this Loan Bill is too high in such circumstances. As I said, the Budget is very strongly predicated upon the success of the prices and incomes accord. That accord must be subjected to the scrutiny that we would all require for the basis of such an important aspect of Government policy.

I was interested in the answers of the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Senator Button) today to questions in this place with regard to the Government's intervention in and approach to sectoral claims that are being made and the way in which it will intervene in such claims. His response gave us the impression that the Government opposed them, but he is not able to say in what way it will deal with them until such time as a decision has been made by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission as to whether it will uphold the 4.3 per cent increase in wage levels which the Government has supported. I do not think many people would suggest that it is sound economic judgment to have a Budget deficit of $8.4 billion and full indexation of wages in the present economic climate. I think that if there are to be the sorts of sectional wage adjustments that we have seen in the building, the food processing and oil industries, and the demands that seem to be heard from other industries the prices and incomes accord will not survive. If that is to be the outcome of the basis on which this Budget is constructed, I can foresee only that there will be many economic difficulties ahead of us in our endeavour to catch the wave of recovery that may come to us through the United States recovery. We need to be ready to set the climate for business confidence and investment to provide the real jobs.

As I said earlier, the real growth in employment that can be firmly predicted is in the public sector. In some cases the jobs will be temporary; in others they will perhaps be jobs that are created by State governments as a result of the increased funding allotted to them. In yet other instances they will be recycled opportunities that do not lead to productive employment. If we are to have the stimulus necessary for industrial recovery and investment, we will need to see a very firm policy by the Government with regard to wages. I do not think there is any contention that the difficulties with employment relate to the level of profitability, the return on investment and the opportunity there is for increased business confidence to improve real opportunities for employment.

These are the things which are of concern to us. I hope that, as we continue through the Budget debate and have the opportunity to discuss the economy and its prospects for the future, we deal seriously with opportunities for employment and consider our responsibility to work together in this difficult economic climate. I would like to think that the Government itself, in the submissions and interventions that it makes with regard to wages and its prices and incomes accord, will do its utmost to see that any increase in wages is not to the detriment of those in employment and not to the disadvantage of those who will be seeking employment in the future. It is with these comments on the Budget, which is to be funded by Loan Bill (No. 2), that I have tonight drawn attention to the concerns we have with regard to it, although I do indicate that the Loan Bill itself is not opposed by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Loan Bill (No. 2) 1983 I take the opportunity to mention some aspects of the Budget that has just come before us. Initially, however, I would like to remind honourable senators that at this time 12 months ago we had just had presented in this place what was to become the last Fraser Budget. At about this time last year there was much speculation about whether there would be an early election. Early election speculation is probably one of the most useless exercises, but it occurs nonetheless. It occurred a number of times last year. Shortly after the Budget was introduced last year there was speculation that we might have an election in September. September passed, and then there was speculation about whether we would have an election in December. Some people said that we would have had an election in September, but the Prime Minister's nerve failed. Before the December option could be exercised, the Prime Minister's back failed; so we did not have an election then.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of us expected to be back here about mid-February to start the 1983 year but before we could come back we were all told that the Parliament had been dissolved. On that occasion the only thing that failed was the Prime Minister's judgment because when the election finally came in March, the Fraser Government was defeated. The Hawke Government came into power and its job eventually was to bring down this Budget in August of this year. This Hawke Budget will be the first of many Labor Budgets brought down in this place, and it has put Australia on the road to recovery.

I take this opportunity to mention some of the more specific aspects of the recent Budget. I would first like to congratulate the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, the Treasurer, Mr Keating, the Minister for Finance, Mr Dawkins, and all of the Labor Ministry for the work they did in bringing this Budget before the Parliament. Like many members of the Australian Labor Party, both elected members and even those who at that stage had not been elected, I was present at Bob Hawke's opening of the election campaign in the Sydney Opera House. At that time we in the Labor Party felt confident about what was before us and what we could do if elected. We were elected to government but we found that the cupboard was bare. In fact, the country was heading for a $9 billion to $10 billion deficit. In these circumstances, bringing together a Budget to get Australia working again was a magnificent effort on the part of the Prime Minister and all of his Ministers. It required great application and severe discipline. The Budget, brought down a few weeks ago, has been widely accepted.

I was somewhat surprised by some of the remarks made by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, but I suppose that an opposition is bound to oppose the Budget. Many things in this Budget will be excellent for the country in the situation that it is in, and in my opinion this Budget will bring Australia around again, back to the situation that such a resource rich country like ours should be in.

I would like to mention some specific matters in the Budget which pleased me and, probably more significantly, are of importance to thousands of Queenslanders. What I shall mention may be of importance even to those beyond the boundaries of Queensland. I mention firstly two specific social security matters which were brought in with this Budget. These measures are very important for those who are involved. Like many other senators and members of the House of Representatives, from time to time I have been approached by men who have opted out of the work force so that they can care for permanently ill wives. If the roles were reversed and a woman cared for an ill or invalid husband, a pension or benefit would be payable to the couple. For instance, they would be able to receive a sickness benefit, payable both to the husband and the wife, or an invalid pension payable in the same way. However, when a man steps down from his working life to attend to an ill or invalid wife, he is not entitled to the same sort of benefit. All he is entitled to is a special benefit . We all know that a special benefit attracts a stringent means test and it does not carry any entitlement to fringe benefits. So quite often when a man realises that his wife is ill and needs constant care he cannot actually step down from his work because of the financial disadvantages attendant upon both the husband and the wife.

However, to the Government's credit and especially to the credit of the Minister for Social Security, Senator Grimes, a spouse carer's pension has been introduced in this Budget. This spouse carer's pension will allow the husband of an age, service or invalid pensioner wife to receive assistance on the same basis as the wife would receive a pension. This will be available where the husband provides care and attention for an extended period on account of his wife's severe physical or mental disability. This will be of great benefit to many men in the community who want to stand down from the work force and look after their spouses. Although the total cost for a full year will be only about $10m-a small amount in the total budgetary context-this humane initiative will provide much needed relief to many men who otherwise would have received little, if any, benefit. Of course it will provide relief to a wife who will realise that under such circumstances she will be able to have her husband look after her.

A further initiative which will assist many of my constituents is the assistance which will be given to pensioners who are living in remote areas. As I travel around Queensland-I am sure this happens not only to my fellow Queensland senators but also to senators in other States as well-I am often amazed at how high the cost of living is in remote areas. Those people who live in remote areas probably become used to the high cost of living but when one is moving from, say, a capital city or from a provincial city on the coast into a remote area, one realises the high cost of living in these out of the way places . This has severe implications for many people. It has severe implications for the wage earners in those places but, to some extent, the wage earners are buffered by the fact that they can receive a tax concession for being in a certain tax zone. It has severe implications for pensioners as well. In most cases, they cannot take advantage of the tax concessions or the zone allowances. They find it difficult to make the pension go as far as it should or go as far as it would in other places in the State in which they live. Many pensioners in this situation contemplate moving away from what are familiar surroundings for them and going to a place where the cost of living is lower. It is not fair that pensioners should have to do so. If they have worked and lived in an area for a long time they ought to be able to retire there and have a similar standard of living to their fellow pensioners in other parts of the State. They should not have to move away from their familiar surroundings and from the friends that they have had for 40 or 50 years.

From May next year a special allowance will be payable to pensioners in taxation zone A to help buffer the high cost of living in those areas. A single pensioner living in taxation zone A will receive $7 per week extra. Married couples will receive an extra $12 per week. For those pensioners who are sickness beneficiaries or people such as those who have children, an extra $3.50 per week will be payable for each dependent child. Again, in the total context of the Budget, the cost is relatively small. The cost of this initiative will be about $16m in a full year. However, the benefits to those people in taxation zone A will be considerable. Taxation zone A, of course, exists in places other than Queensland, but much of western Queensland, almost all of Cape York Peninsula and the Torres Strait Islands are in taxation zone A. Pensioners in those areas will benefit from this initiative and have a pension which is more in line in purchasing power with the pension of, say, a person who lives in a capital city.

I should like now to mention briefly some of the special parts of the Budget or some initiatives which were taken even before the Budget which will be of benefit to Queensland, to the State that I represent. Queensland will receive $ 41m for employment creation projects under the community employment program. This is of special importance to Queensland. Unfortunately, at the moment the unemployment rate in Queensland is at a rate higher than the national average. While this sum will not bring down the employment rate to a rate that we would like, it will certainly make a dent in the numbers of unemployed that we have at the moment. When fully operational, the amount that Queensland will receive under the community employment program will create 11,200 new jobs. This will be of great benefit to Queensland which now has an unemployment rate of over 10 per cent.

Queensland will receive an extra $63m in public housing funds. In bald figures, an extra $63m probably does not mean too much. But it is a 52 per cent increase over what Queensland received last year and an indication of the amount of money that will be available for housing. More housing contracts will be concluded now that interest rates are declining; the more housing that is undertaken in Queensland, the better it will be for our economy. Housing has a great spin-off in the economy because of the other things which are associated with it.

In the Budget there is an extra $2m for the 1983-84 financial year to subsidise Trans Australia Airlines F27 scheduled airline services to western Queensland communities. This is subject to a dollar for dollar matching contribution by the Queensland Government. I would outline that this is not a new initiative. This was something that was being carried out by the previous Government. I can remember going out into western Queensland with the then Minister for Transport who was a member of another political party. Because of his intervention, a subsidy along these lines was introduced. This subsidy will continue to be used for airline services in western Queensland. People who do not travel in that area would not realise the problems that people in those areas have. I notice Senator Collard on the other side of the chamber. He would be well aware of the transport problems that people in those areas have and the great reliance that there is on air transport in that general area. Unless we have a subsidy such as this, people in those areas will not receive the air transport services that they require.

I should like to mention now especially something about north Queensland in relation to the Budget. I could mention many things in the Budget but I will choose just some of them and point out how Queensland will benefit from this Budget. In the Budget, over $500,000 has been set aside to begin setting up a second regional radio network of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. As many as four million Australians in the north and in other places in the Commonwealth are now receiving only one ABC radio program. They will benefit from a second network. Some people in north Queensland and north-western Queensland receive only the one ABC radio program. They do not receive any commercial program. A similar problem exists in relation to television in some of the remote areas of Queensland.

I can well remember going into one of the western Queensland towns and speaking with people about problems with television in those areas. One person indicated to me quite clearly that it was one of the few entertainments they had but they saw so many repeat programs because they had only one channel that they could almost recite the programs themselves without having to watch them. In addition to the money to be made available for radio, an amount of $7.5m has been set aside in this Budget for the upgrading and extension of the ABC network in country areas. This includes $1m for the commencement of work to convert certain national transmitting stations from dependence on terrestrial links to use of the national communications satellite system for the distribution of ABC radio and television programs in the future. An amount of $500,000 will be available for a scheme to provide ABC radio and television programs to remote and under- served communities which do not currently receive these services, due either to rugged terrain or because they are outside the present service areas. We will see a strong boost to road funding in Queensland because of the Budget; a total of $262m will be provided in the next financial year, a 40 per cent increase. Queensland will have the fastest growth in funding for national roads in the forthcoming financial year, a 39.5 per cent increase compared with 34.8 per cent for Australia as a whole.

Two matters of a capital nature which I should like to mention which are of interest to the people of Queensland are Commonwealth office buildings which will be constructed in the north. A Commonwealth building will be constructed at Cairns at a cost of $5.5m. Another project that is of interest to me and many Queenslanders who go to the north of our State quite often is the Commonwealth building that is going to be built on Thursday Island. This undertaking will be of considerable benefit for all of the Commonwealth agencies that are on Thursday Island. I should imagine that my colleague the honourable member for Leichhardt, Mr John Gayler, will probably have an office in the new Commonwealth building on Thursday Island. The building will not be large because, after all, Thursday Island is not a large community. However, the building will service not only Thursday Island but all of the islands in Torres Strait. The total cost of the building will be $700,000.

One of the major industries in Queensland-I usually regard it as the fourth biggest industry in Queensland although some people have quarrelled with me and said it is much more important than that-is the tourist industry. Tourism is a fast growing industry. It is an industry which provides a great deal of employment in Queensland. Any further boost to this industry will help pick up the unemployment problem. This year money has not been allocated especially to Queensland for the purpose of tourism. However, the Australian Tourist Commission itself will receive $17.5m in this financial year which is an increase of 75 per cent over the previous year's allocation. I am hopeful that the Commission will use a great deal of the extra money that has been provided to it to feature Queensland overseas so that when visitors come to Australia they will not just go to the Melbourne-Canberra-Sydney triangle but they will come into Queensland as well. People from overseas have no difficulty in travelling to Queensland because we have international airports in Brisbane and Townsville and an international airport facility will soon be available in Cairns. Of course, Queensland relies heavily on tourists from within the Commonwealth itself. However, the more tourists we can get from overseas the better it will be for the economy of Queensland.

A special grant of $1m is being made available in one area. It will result in some significant benefits in tourism. An amount of $1m does not sound much. However, this special grant will be made available in the current financial year to subsidise diesel fuel costs to Great Barrier Reef island tourist resorts. Many of the resorts rely very heavily on water transport and this grant will help provide tourist facilities on the islands at a reasonable cost and as a result we will be able to keep attracting tourists to north Queensland. As I say , although $1m does not sound much, it will be of significant benefit to these islands.

Finally, I wish to say something about the Burdekin Dam. Bert Kelly, the ' modest farmer' and a former member of the House of Representatives, used to tell the story that he could feel an election coming on when a dam project was in the wind. Bert Kelly told this story in a much more poetic way than I am able to tell it this evening. For years in Queensland we have been able to tell when an election was about to be called as the proposed Burdekin Dam was mentioned. The Burdekin Dam is to become a reality. I suppose there have been many driving forces behind the dam. In one way it is unfair to single out any special person. However, a member of the House of Representatives who was elected at the last election has been a driving force behind getting funding for the dam. That person is Mr Eamon Lindsay, the honourable member for Herbert. Eamon Lindsay, of course, was an alderman in the Townsville City Council. His special area of interest was water. For a long time he agitated to get funding for the Burdekin Dam. In the Budget the Federal Government will be providing to Queensland $13m in the current financial year 1983-84 for the full cost of the construction of the Burdekin Dam head works. The dam is not longer a pipe dream; it is going to be a reality.

In speaking on the Loan Bill (No. 2) 1983 this evening, I have mentioned some broad aspects of the current Budget introduced a few weeks ago which are particularly pleasing to me. I have mentioned some aspects which will be very helpful to Queensland. It is pleasing to note that this is the first Labor Budget for some time. This is the first Labor Budget that has been brought down since I entered this Parliament in 1975. What is probably more pleasing is the fact that this Budget will get Australia moving again. As well as that, it is the first of many Labor Budgets that we are going to see in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to use the debate on Loan Bill (No. 2) 1983 to point out many of the weaknesses of the Australian Labor Party's 1983 Federal Budget. The Government has used the constitutionality of this Loan Bill- its basic purpose is defence-as a means of circumventing the approval of the Australian Loan Council on the basis that some of the Budget measures apply to defence commitments. I think it is time that governments tidied up such an unsatisfactory approach to financing deficits in Australia. I think there is need for some innovative thinking so that we can get some up to date, efficient and streamlined procedures to finance appropriately our Federal Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: In many respects the 1983 Federal Budget was a smart document because it aimed to direct attention away from annual federal Budgets. In the future I believe there will be less significance attached to Budgets because a lot of the effects will take place during the financial year rather than at Budget time itself. The Budget is directed at trying to solve immediate problems. I think we must also read this Budget in the context of the economic statement or the mini-Budget that was presented earlier because it is part of a strategy. I was amazed to see in the Budget an agreement by Australian Labor Party people to index indirect taxes by way of excise duties. I thought that the Labor Party had been pathologically opposed to suggestions of an increased reliance on indirect taxes . But what do we find? We find that a range of excise taxes has been indexed. What is the effect of this action? By indexing the excise taxes, costs are fed into the cost of living and they flow on ultimately into the price of labour. This is a further destabilising influence on the prices and incomes accord which is supposed to be the foundation of the 1983 Budget strategy. This leads me to suggest that there is a very high fragility in the whole of this Labor Party strategy. The high reliance on the prices and incomes accord is beginning to crumble.

Let us look at some of the other features. Australia's inflation rate is still above the average of other countries of the industrialised world. This means that Australian industry is increasingly uncompetitive in world terms. A lot of credit has been claimed by the Government for bringing down certain interest rates. Interest rates have not fallen at the same rate as inflation has fallen; there is a significant gap. The fragility is further emphasised when we look as some of the statements accompanying the Budget. I refer to page 70 of the Budget Statements 1983-84 Budget Paper No. 1-which admits to certain problems which are not manifested in the Budget Speech. That document states that any upturn in the world economy stronger than what is currently foreseen by this Government would adversely damage the Australian economy. This is interesting when compared with statements by the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. He has constantly asserted that Australia will share in the tremendous upturn which is currently taking place in the United States of America. In Budget Paper No. 2 we have a statement contradictory to that general assertion.

In this Budget a lot of money is being spent on the unemployed as a means of solving what we all recognise as a tragic social problem. The Budget outlook acknowledges that there will still be higher levels of unemployment. I suggest that means the Labor Government is applying the wrong solutions to solve this social problem. The fact that the Government is applying the wrong sorts of remedies, or more precisely is not understanding the problems, is manifested in a number of areas. My colleague Senator Messner from South Australia pointed out the difficulties in relation to the excise on brandies, ports, et cetera. The tax is effectively to be pre-paid 5, 10 or 15 years before the product is sold. This reflects the complete lack of understanding of how this sector of industry works. It is a good example.

We have seen a number of backdowns since Budget night. I suppose the most notorious related to the diesel fuels. The Government showed a complete failure to understand the full implications and ramifications of the taxes proposed in the Budget. In other words, it failed to analyse them and to do its homework. It said: 'Yes, this will do. It will raise so much revenue'. When the Government realised the full implications-the extra revenue above the Budget predictions and the fact that the taxes would have wiped out certain sectors of the transport industry and of the power industry-it wisely backed down. Despite that backdown, the cost to the transport industry will be horrendous. We are dependent on cheap economic transport. The nail has been put into the coffin of many operators. Many competing industries face major problems. There was a backdown on-I suppose, to be more polite there was an explanation of-sales tax on certain items which when one read the Schedule to the Budget were clearly intended to be taxable. I refer to sunburn creams. There was a backdown by way of an explanation. Again, that illustrates the lack of attention to detail in the Budget. I also refer to plumbing supplies. Last year the Labor Party attacked the Liberal-National Party coalition for its 2 1/2 per cent tax. What did it do in its Schedule? It put on an horrendous tax. After Budget night it said 'Oh no, that will not apply to all sorts of categories' which took the heat off. Again it demonstrates a lack of attention to detail and to the full implications. It could have been accused of hypocrisy.

I now return to the prices and incomes accord. The Labor Party believes that the prices and incomes accord is an alternative to tighter monetary and fiscal policy. Those countries that have had a successful wage pause have used that wage pause in conjunction with tighter monetary and fiscal policy. This Government ignores the success of those governments which have applied wage pauses and says: 'No, we can do it as an alternative to the others'. How can Australia succeed when other countries have proved that this approach is wrong? Regrettably, we are seeing instance after instance of the wages accord breaking down. We have seen it in the building industry where the domination of strong unions has assured wage increases. We have seen it in the food industry particularly, for example, in the Heinz case. The oil industry is another example.

The cost to the nation of the deficit is horrendous. I wish to point out that the cost in interest on money borrowed will be as much as the costs in the areas of health and education. We are putting a tremendous burden on future generations. It is easy to borrow money. It is a lot harder to pay it back. We are putting additional burdens on to our children. If we look at our cost burden , our indebtedness, compared with that of some of the Latin American countries, we do not come out particularly well. The only thing in our favour is that we have a greater ability at present to service that debt. For how long will that ability continue if the Government does not apply the right sorts of policies at the right time? The Government has indicated that this money will not be borrowed overseas. This means that in six to nine month's time there will be an increase in interest rates. It is this hesitancy which is frightening people away.

Let us look at some of the broken promises. We were told that Tasmania would be adequately compensated for the loss of the dam. We are to be given a mere $30m, and there are haggles over that at present. We had promises of income tax cuts for six million workers. What is the reality? There have been no tax cuts but progressive hikes as incomes rise. I said that the Budget was a smart Budget. Most of the journalists in Australia were deceived. It took the Secretary of the Australian Taxpayers Association, Mr Eric Risstrom, nearly four hours to discover that the majority of average wage earners would be significantly worse off as a result of this Budget. What happened about petrol? We had a promise of cheaper petrol, but we have dearer petrol.

A fundamental feature of this Budget is Medicare. Medicare will do nothing to improve health care delivery costs. The measures contained in the Medicare legislation threaten good health provision in the future. Medicare is a major act of nationalisation, changing the face of Australia. It adds $1.7 billion in taxes in a full year. It adds 2,500 expensive staff members to the public sector . On the other hand, what does it do to the private sector? It will have to sack 5,000 of its lower paid staff. Medicare obscures the real cost of health care. The one per cent levy which is talked about so much covers only $1 billion whereas Federal and State governments spend $8 billion on health costs. What is the significance of this fact? The one per cent levy is no more than a political levy which is completely unrelated to costs. Medicare will cause great problems for consumers. Pensioners with pensioner health benefit cards will pay no more under Medicare but the consumer price index reduction of 2.6 per cent in 1984 will cost single pensioners $2.30 a week and married couples $3.90 a week. I think the pensioners of Australia should be aware of this situation.

What about local government, the third tier of government, which is democracy at its grass roots? The Australian Labor Party in its policy speech stated that it would allocate at least 2 per cent of Federal personal income tax as a general revenue grant to local government. That amount was set by the Liberal and National parties. The Labor Party went even further. It promised, as part of its policy, that the allocation in any year would not be less than the real value of the previous year's allocation. But what happened? Local government failed to get the full amount. In 1982-83 the consumer price index rose by 11.2 per cent and the local government share of personal income taxes rose by only 8. 2 per cent. This shortfall means that local government has been underpaid to the extend of $13m. What will the 839 local councils in Australia say in relation to this broken promise? What will the 10,500 elected councillors and their millions of constituents say about it?

There is talk of an economic recovery. It will not be an investment recovery and it will not be a consumer-led recovery; it will be a Government-led recovery . This means that the Government will say to all of us: 'We know how to spend your taxes better than you do. We will spend more money but it will cost you more in taxes-both direct taxes and indirect taxes'. This is the situation, despite the fact that we all believed that the Australian Labor Party was pathologically against indirect increases in taxes.

The Government indicated in the Budget Papers that there will be a 5 per cent rise in non-farm product. We all ask ourselves: Where will this come from? The Government even acknowledges that there will be a fall in private sector investment. What will all this extra spending achieve? How will it stimulate demand? The Budget has done very little for private sector growth and virtually nothing for small business. It is unfortunate that only at election time does small business seem to get any acknowledgement at all. It has not been granted anything in this Budget.

Let us look at some of the problems that the Government will face. Currently the money supply is over the Budget target. What do we find, therefore? There is plenty of money but the only demand for it is from government. That does not augur well for the future. In relation to defence matters-I know you have a particular interest in such matters, Mr Deputy President-there must be a large fall in the number of trainees and apprentices to be recruited. What the Government is really doing is replacing the men in uniform with civilians. It has done nothing to enhance Australia's preparedness for defence. The morale of the reserve forces is quite low. What has the Budget done in this respect? The present exemption from income tax of the pay and allowances of part time members of the reserve defence forces is to be phased out over a certain time interval. The Government then said that it would conduct an investigation into the pay and allowances in the forces. I suggest that the appropriate course of action for the Government is to conduct an investigation and make changes later. This is another example of what this Government is doing. It acts first and conducts investigations later. This is another manifestation of the fact that the Government acts first and carries out investigations later.

I turn now to the rural sector of Australia. The primary producers of Australia have been treated very shabbily in the May mini-Budget and in this Budget. This sector has been asked to pay more than its fair share of the burden in trying to get this country going again, despite the fact that it is emerging from one of the worst droughts on record and despite the fact that many primary producers are deeper in debt than they have ever been. This particular sector has been let down greatly. What else is contained in the Budget Speech? We find that off-road diesel excise will become payable for the first time. What effect will this have not only on farm costs-running tractors, headers and that sort of equipment-but also in getting the produce to and from the farm. The costs involved will be quite significant because of the long distances between places in Australia. What effect will it have on my island State of Tasmania? It will considerably increase the price of air travel and sea transport.

There is no offsetting cost or increase in the freight equalisation scheme. What has the Government done in this respect? It has reduced the amount allocated to the freight equalisation scheme despite the fact that documents accompanying the Budget indicate that the Government has budgeted for an increase in volume. The Budget documents state that we have just had one of the worst years on record; yet the Government spends only $27m on freight equalisation. Although it is acknowledged that it was probably one of the worst years for business and transport and that an increased figure was sought, the amount allocated was only $23m. Again, that indicates the failure of the Government to come to grips with reality and its failure to recognise the real problems that people are having to face.

What has this Budget done to increase Australia's international competitiveness in the primary industry sector? Earlier tonight I spoke about some of the problems and the increased costs associated with the new livestock slaughter levies. Let us look at some of the broken promises of this Government in relation to primary industry. The Government promised that it would allocate $ 28m for wool promotion. What did it allocate in the Budget? It allocated $20m. It broke a promise it had made to one of our major industries and reduced the promised amount by $8m. That is a significant amount. What about soil conservation? The Government promised that it would allocate $4m for soil conservation. It granted a mere $1m, despite widespread acknowledgement that soil conservation is vital in Australia.

As I mentioned, the Budget does nothing to stimulate the rural sector. Between the economic statement or mini-Budget and this Budget the primary industries of Australia have lost a great deal. At the same time, the Labor Government expects primary industry to contribute significantly to economic recovery in Australia. Primary industry has lost another major tax deduction as a result of changes to section 75A of the Income Tax Assessment Act. This provision enabled primary producers involved in land clearing and preparation for pasture of previously virgin land to have a tax deductibility over a 10-year period. With one stroke of the pen on Budget night the Government wiped out completely the deductibility in relation to land clearing. I believe a positive approach would have been to offer an incentive to plant new trees.

What did the Democrats have to offer when they attacked the Budget? They believe that there should have been extra spending; admittedly, they said it should have been selective. But this would have added substantially to the deficit. Despite their acknowledgement of the importance of small business, they are actually advocating a wealth tax and they chastise the Labor Government for not imposing a wealth tax. The Democrats-they call themselves the saviours of small business-are advocating a wealth tax which imposes a tax on many sectors that just have not the cash resources or the income to pay it. It is therefore an iniquitous tax. Those taxes which are most favoured in the community are related to a person's ability to pay from an income. I believe this Budget will prove to be an absolute disaster for Australia. It is certainly going to prove those journalists who felt that it was a good Budget entirely wrong. It has sought to do nothing with Australia's long term problems. I believe that history will show it as one of the worst Budgets that has ever been brought down in Australia's history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Loan Bill (No. 2) 1983. It is designed to supplement the Consolidated Revenue Fund if necessary and it is one means of financing the Budget for 1983-84. I draw the attention of honourable senators to this week's issue of the Bulletin which indicates that the 1983 Budget has been particularly well received and that only a relatively small group in the community, perhaps including the Opposition, thinks that it is not satisfactory.

SPEECH.PARA: Among the features of the Budget this year are the historically high social security payments. Almost 30 per cent of outlays are devoted to social security. There is a very large increase in outlays for housing, a much needed increase. There is also a very big increase in spending on health. Unlike the two previous Budgets in 1981 and 1982, there is no significant increase in sales taxes. The trend towards higher sales taxes which was set in train in the 1981 Budget has been broken this year.

The Budget has the lowest aggregate income tax collection rise for five years. The total increase nationally in income tax collections this financial year is expected to be less than 8 per cent. That is a very low post-war figure in Australia and a major departure from previous Budgets. That 8 per cent lift really does overstate the impact because there is an offsetting saving to many members of the community through the savings in respect of health care. That 8 per cent includes the Medicare levy. There are certainly excise increases in the Budget but the Government has made the decision that this is the area most appropriate to pay for its program. There is a large increase in the deficit. This financial year the Budget deficit is forecast to be 4.7 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product, compared with 2.8 per cent last financial year. I must say that the increase in the deficit this year is very much a planned increase, not the situation last financial year when we had a massive unplanned increase in the Budget deficit.

I remind honourable senators that when the former Treasurer, Mr Howard, brought down his budget in August last year he planned a deficit of $1,600m. That was the amount he said would be the excess of government outlays over revenues for the financial year. When the year ended the community discovered that in fact the deficit was $4,400m. So this tremendous unplanned increase in the Budget deficit contrasted with a planned increase this financial year. I think the Government and the community should take with a grain of salt criticisms by the Opposition of this Budget, given its track record last financial year in particular when we saw the largest unplanned increase in government outlays in the history of this country.

The Budget is part of a group of fiscal measures taken by the Government to try to turn the economy around. It started earlier this year, immediately upon election, by devaluing the Australian dollar to give some added protection to Australian manufacturing industry. It convened the National Economic Summit Conference. As honourable senators know, one of the key proposals to come from that Summit was the proposition that unemployment and inflation should be tackled simultaneously and the previous dogma-the so-called fighting inflation first-was dispensed with. The May economic statement was a housekeeping exercise designed to clean out a range of tax expenditures, which were concealed in the Budget, to provide scope for new initiatives by this Government this financial year. The incomes policy has been commenced. The prices and incomes accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions was the first major element of that policy. Since then the Economic Planning Advisory Council has been appointed to provide more information and a means of consultation with the community about economic matters in this country. The prices surveillance authority is to be set up to monitor the prices charged by large corporations and some statutory authorities. Legislation concerning it is still to come. Work is proceeding on the advisory committee on professional incomes.

The economic context of this Budget should be repeated here because it really gives a perspective of what is happening and what is needed to turn the economy around. In the last financial year we saw tremendous falls in employment and an increase of 270,000 in the unemployment figure-perhaps the biggest increase in unemployment in Australia in any one year under the Government which campaigned year after year on the basis that it was the Government of competent economic management and that all other parties were incompetent to manage the economy. The legacy was a 270,000 increase in the unemployment level in one financial year. Inflation was well into the double digit range-11 1/2 per cent. Even worse , it was double the average of the countries with which we trade; so our competitiveness was being eroded. We had very high interest rates indeed.

The strategy of this Budget is to give a fiscal policy stimulus to boost activity, to give the maximum stimulus consistent with the Government's anti- inflation objectives. As I indicated earlier, the objectives are to fight inflation and unemployment simultaneously. It is the first Budget to begin turning the economy around. It will take time, but this is the first step. It is a Budget promoting fairness and equity in the community in order to begin the process of redistribution in the community.

Some of the major features of the Budget should be examined tonight. I think the most important area of activity is housing. There is tremendous scope to boost activity in the economy by stimulating housing. I welcome the 50 per cent increase in funds allocated in this Budget for public housing. The important aspect about public housing is that the people who tend to be housed through the State housing commissions are among the neediest people in the community. This is a very equitable measure.

There is also the very imaginative first home owners scheme which is designed to overcome the deposit gap which we all know is the biggest single obstacle to home ownership in Australia. The scheme provides for grants of up to $7,000 for eligible couples as a subsidy against repayments on home loans. The impact of that scheme will be to enable many people to borrow more in respect of a given income towards the price of a dwelling and so overcome the very difficult problem of trying to save a deposit out of restricted incomes. We estimate that the total impact on the housing sector of the public housing boost and the first home owners scheme will be the commencement of something like 22,000 extra dwellings this financial year. That is a significant increase in dwelling construction in Australia.

The community employment program is designed to boost employment, particularly in areas where high unemployment rates prevail-those areas which will be left out as the economy picks up, those areas in which employment creation will not proceed as fast as the average for the country as a whole. The scheme involves outlays of $300m this financial year. I am pleased that in my own State of South Australia some 3,000 extra jobs will be created in this financial year as a result of the community employment scheme. Unemployment benefits have been increased for single people aged 18 years and over and people under the age of 18. Also, a liberalised income test is to be applied to encourage the unemployed to seek jobs. Very importantly, there are to be increased benefits for the children of pensioners and for persons receiving a family income supplement. This will enable families to enjoy more disposable income and represent important ways of tackling poverty, so much of which in Australia is family oriented. For country people there is to be a major boost as a result of the planning for the second Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio network, which will supplement existing ABC services in country areas. I am very pleased to note that Port Pirie in South Australia will be a major centre in the ABC radio network.

Very large road grants are to be made to the States, the provision representing an increase of some 45 per cent this year. Also, the Australian Tourist Commission is to receive a boost. In regard to education, more funds are to be provided for needy schools. The first ever computer education program at a national level is to be instituted. The Government is budgeting some $18m over a period of three years to improve computer education in schools. In the area of data processing Australia is being left behind by so many countries that it is important our children should have access to computer education. I particularly welcome the scheme. Also, the participation and equity scheme is designed to help more children finish their secondary education. Australia has an appalling record in terms of the number of children who fail to finish their secondary education. This scheme represents an important beginning in encouraging more children to stay on at school.

Provision is made for the introduction of Medicare, which is to begin on 1 February. It represents a major reform of Australia's health system and will be of tremendous benefit to lower income families. I am very pleased to note that in this Budget, for the first time, real resources have been provided to begin the crackdown on medical fraud. I believe that that practice represents a blight on the community and I am very pleased that resources are being budgeted for the provision of more Federal police and Health Department inspectors in order to begin cleaning up this area of abuse-medical fraud and medical overservicing- which, it is estimated by the parliamentary Public Accounts Committee, costs the nation $120m a year. I welcome this initiative and believe that a very large amount of money can be recovered for the taxpayers by cracking down in this field.

The Budget also provides for very large increases in allocations for employment and training schemes to ensure that workers who have been retrenched can be retrained and participate more fully in the work force as the economy improves. Various schemes in the Budget devoted to employment training involve expenditure for increases of up to 35 per cent in trade and non-trade training. A specific scheme provides for those steel producing regions in which at the moment there is very serious unemployment. I trust that in the steel centre of Whyalla in my own State many people will be able to benefit from these steel industry retraining schemes. Overall, the employment that is generated in the economy by the Budget should be quite significant. In the housing area alone it can be estimated that some 20,000 to 30,000 extra jobs will be created as a result of the Government's housing initiatives. Steel industry assistance involving bounties of up to $30m annually to the Broken Hill Propriety Co. Ltd should save jobs in the steel industry. In addition, the Government's capital works program, which is designed to overcome years of neglect in regard to Commonwealth public works, should involve a significant expansion in employment. I am particularly pleased about the increase of 22 per cent in the funds budgeted for capital works expansion this financial year. That will certainly give a major boost to Australia's ailing construction industry and ensure that additional jobs are created there. I also welcome the Commonwealth's announcement of an office space program to ensure that more of its offices are located in its own premises. By building additional offices the Commonwealth will stimulate economic activity.

Budget outlays are to increase by 15.8 per cent across the board, the areas of priority being those of health, housing and social security. Health outlays will increase by 25.4 per cent, which is well above the overall average of 15.8 per cent, indicating that it is seen as a high priority area. Housing outlays are to increase by 23.1 per cent and expenditure on social security and welfare by 19.3 per cent. As I indicated earlier, this Budget is characterised by very low growth in total income tax collections nationally. Indeed, it is one of the lowest rates of increase for many years. No change in income tax rates is to take place and the sales tax increases of previous years have been halted. Over the last two financial years we saw a 66 per cent boost in revenue derived from sales tax. In 1980-81, $2,100m was collected. By 1982-83 the figure had soared to $3,500m, representing an enormous increase in collections. That increase has now been halted.

Excise has been increased in order to finance the Government's program, but its impact I am sure can be borne by the community. It amounts to only approximately 2c a litre of petrol, 3c a packet of cigarettes and 3c a bottle of beer. They are the sacrifices that the commuity is making to pay for the Government program . Elsewhere in the revenue program the Government has indicated that it will be cracking down further in respect of the application of section 26A of the Income Tax Assessment Act to ensure that tax now being avoided will be recovered. I am particularly pleased that for the first time profits derived from the sale of bonus shares and rights issues will be taxed. This area has been long neglected and it is timely that those who benefit in this way should be required to pay tax. I am also pleased to see that the bottom of the harbour legislation is being resubmitted to Parliament.

Overall, total Budget outlays are up by 15.8 per cent, while revenues are to grow by barely half of that figure, or 8.6 per cent. As a matter of interest, under this particular Budget the proportion of receipts in relation to the level of gross domestic product is to decline. It is to be reduced from last year's figure of 27.7 per cent under the Fraser Government to 27 per cent this year-the lowest figure for several years. As is on record the overall deficit will be a record $8.4 billion, compared with the $4.4 billion unplanned deficit of last year.
