In analysing the impact of the Budget on the economy we should look at the domestic deficit because that is the one which actually affects the flow of income and expenditure in the local economy. As compared with an overall deficit of $8.4 billion, the domestic deficit this year is about $5.7 billion. That should involve quite significant stimulation of the Australian economy.

I am very pleased that the Budget incorporates a number of redistributive items . The Budget begins the process of redistributing income and wealth in Australia and provides more assistance to needy schools. I am sure that the participation and equity scheme in education will help lower income families in particular. The Budget foreshadowed an assets test for wealthy pensioners. It increases the unemployment benefit. The Budget provides increased sickness and unemployment benefits payments to certain families with children. It provides a very large increase in public housing outlays. Quite significantly, the home ownership schemes provided by the Commonwealth Government are to be means tested. I am sure that will enable the funds to be focused more on the neediest families. The community employment program will focus on the longer term unemployed and also on areas of high unemployment. The Medicare package will ensure that more lower income families pay nothing for health care in Australia. On the revenue side, the share dividend rebate has been abolished. As I have indicated, bonus shares and rights issues will be taxed. That will certainly assist in redistributing income towards lower income people.

Of course, one of the keys to redistribution in the modern economy is to get inflation down, because inflation is the greatest cause of maldistribution of resources. Because low income households tend to hold their savings in bank and building society deposits, they tend to be less protected against inflation than those who are more well-to-do who purchase property and other assets which tend to appreciate in price, thereby allowing them to benefit from inflation. It is very important in the modern community to have measures which wind down inflation, because that is the way one brings about a lasting redistribution.

The impact of the Budget on the economy can be best examined by looking at the structural Budget deficit. This is the actual impact of the Budget on the economy as such rather than the reverse where we get feedback from the economy on the Budget which clouds the financial figures and makes it difficult to assess the impacts. Compared with 1982-83, the structural Budget deficit-that is , the actual impact of the Budget on the economy-is enormously more expansionary . It can be calculated that, compared with the last financial year, this Budget is adding something like $2,600m extra to the Australian economy. Therefore, it is much more expansionary. It is important to note that the structural deficit this year is actually adding to expenditure in the community. Last financial year it was actually detracting from economic activity. Between 1981-82 and 1982 -83 it was only $800m more expansionary, but this financial year the figure is some $2,600m, which is an enormously more expansionary Budget. It is important to observe that at page 56 of Budget Paper No. 1 the Department of the Treasury stated:
There is no doubt that . . . the Budget for 1983-84 is very highly expansionary indeed.
I would agree with that statement. It is a very highly expansionary Budget and one which is really needed at this time.

The Budget forecast a growth of 5 per cent in real terms in non-farm domestic product from June 1983 to June 1984. That could be higher, of course, with improving farm conditions. I will be interested, as will most honourable senators, in the forthcoming revisions of the value of rural production by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics which, I am sure, will add significantly to the value of farm production. That in turn will add to the estimate for the gross domestic product. The Budget forecasts an increase in employment of 1.5 per cent from June this year to June next year. That is a contrast with the sharp decline which occurred last financial year. From June 1982 to June 1983, employment actually fell by 1.9 per cent in Australia. The Budget not only creates positive employment growth but also will probably result in employment growing by 1 1/2 per cent over the year.

On the prices front, it can be estimated that the rate of inflation will be at the most 7 1/2 per cent this financial year. That is quite a departure from the double digit inflation which we experienced last financial year when we saw prices rise by an average of 11.2 per cent over the course of 1982-83. The fall in inflation this financial year will mean that prices in Australia will increase at a rate more in line with prices in the countries with which we compete. That should give some respite to Australia's manufacturing industries. I have been looking at Labor's first Budget in eight years. The Budget is our first step to boost employment in the community. It is the first instalment of the creation of 500,000 jobs which we promised over a three-year period. It is the first move to begin winding back unemployment in the community and it is the beginning of moves to increase fairness and equity in the community. I am sure that this is the first of many Budgets to be brought down by the Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Loan Bill (No. 2) is the traditional mechanism which is used each year for raising a loan to bridge the deficit. The deficit is the bottom line of the Budget, the result arising from the total expenditure and the total revenue. It is an indication of the nature of the Budget. Looking at the bottom line, one sees the whole Budget. This year the Budget has been in three instalments. I want to examine those three instalments.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all, there was the National Economic Summit Conference. It has been said that the Summit was a consensus. The fact is that the Summit was no consensus at all. The Summit, in terms of its budgetary concept, was a determination by the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions that option A of the various options put forward by the Government would be adopted. Once the decision was made to use option A, even though the business and community leaders had recommended against it-they wanted to adopt option C or option D-a course was set in terms of the economics and the economy of this country which was quite different from any promise and anything that people believed. The Summit papers said quite clearly that, if a government were to embark upon option A, unemployment, far from falling over three years, would, at the end of three years, be significantly higher. I make that important point. Despite all of the rhetoric of the Budget and the rhetoric over the course of this year the fact is that the Government flew its flag from the mast of option A. Quite apart from the rhetoric, the Summit's own paper said that adopting option A would result in no fall in unemployment over the three years but, in fact, at the end of the three years unemployment would probably rise above the levels which exist now.

The Summit was the start of the Budget. I go one step further and say that the next step was the mini-Budget. Those who today say that the latest Budget was a mild and mellow thing have very short memories, because their rhetoric is defeated by the nature of the mini-Budget.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Teacher Promotion Procedure: Australian Capital Territory

PROCTEXT.PARA: Teacher Promotion Procedure: Australian Capital Territory

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under sessional order, I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I raise, fairly briefly, a matter concerning a teacher in the Australian Capital Territory who may have been subjected to a little unfairness in an assessment made recently for promotional purposes. I raise the matter tonight, not for any political reasons. There are political matters which I might argue at some other time. Tonight I ask the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), through the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) who is in the chamber, to look at the case and determine whether this government school teacher has received completely fair treatment. The teacher applied for promotion from what is called band one to band two within the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority. For that promotion to take place an assessment procedure exists whereby the teacher is assessed by a panel of four colleagues. That panel makes its report. That report is required before the teacher can be available for promotion to band two.

SPEECH.PARA: The difficulty is that this teacher has been active in his opposition to some of the policies of the Australian Teachers Federation. As I said, I could argue some other time the merit or otherwise of these matters. They are relevant tonight only insofar as they reflect upon this teacher's position. He has opposed some of the industrial actions proposed in the Australian Capital Territory. He has been vocal in that opposition and has been public and apparent . He was opposed to the picketing of Radford College; he was opposed to several stop work activities. Everyone in the Australian Capital Territory knows that he has taken this role. It was unfortunate that, when the peer assessment occurred, the panel of four appointed to review him included a person who was a President of the Australian Teachers Federation in the Australian Capital Territory and who is presently the Regional Moderator. That created a difficulty. I do not believe, for one moment, that anyone should automatically be expected to approve someone for promotion. On the other hand, given the background of this teacher's opposition to some of the activities of the Federation, to have this person assessing him immediately created a difficulty.

The teacher was assessed. Of the four people who assessed him, three recommended him for promotion to band two; one did not recommend him. The person who did not recommend him for promotion to band two was the former President of the Australian Teachers Federation. He recommended that the teacher be not promoted. It is interesting to look at the promotional eligibility assessment report and see what they had to say about this teacher. The report comes under eight headings: Professional competence; teaching ability; professional relationships with students; professional relationships with staff-I will come back to that; professional relationships with parents and community; specialist contributions in education; organisation and administration; and leadership skills. That looks like a very thorough and proper assessment. I will not weary the Senate except to say that one should read those eight sections and look at the kinds of adjectives used about this teacher and his performance. There are words such as 'outstanding performance', 'active contribution', 'a major contribution to ideas', 'extensive publications', including an outstanding thesis which is used as a reference work, 'a capable teacher', 'an exceptional record of community involvement', 'outstanding in promotion of professional development of teachers' and 'highly suitable for promotion'. These are the kinds of remarks that appear in the assessment. At the end of the assessment three of the panel have recommended to the Chief Education Officer that the teacher be given eligibility to apply for promotion to positions requiring band two eligibility from 1 January 1984. One person does not so recommend. I will not name the teacher, but the person who did not recommend appointment, in giving his reasons, stated:

Although Mr . . . possesses many of the qualities required of a Band two officer, questions have been raised during his assessment about his professional relationships with staff, and, as a consequence, his possession of leadership qualities at an acceptable level.
I believe Mr . . . should not be granted Band two eligibility at this time.

My decision is based on the evidence that has been provided by a significant number of Mr . . . colleagues of perceived inappropriate professional behaviour (referred to in Section 4 of the Promotional Eligibility Assessment), and from my consideration of that evidence alongside the level of performance in staff professional relations demanded of the other 1983 applicants for Band 2 eligibility across the Service who have been recommended for that eligibility.

In view of that comment I went back to section 4 and read what the panel said. Was there any evidence there that would lead me to say that this person was not suitable for promotion? Under that part of the assessment a number of very positive things were said. I will not take the time of the Senate. I will make this document available to the Minister if she wishes. The only part that I wish to read states:

It is in pursuing his interest in educational matters that Mr . . . at times, displays a degree of enthusiasm that is not always shared by some of his peers. In accordance with his open education philosophy he speaks on issues and presents information, often with a frequency and determination which some colleagues find irritating. They perceive his behaviour in these situations as inappropriate. Mr . . . has made a genuine effort to alter his actions in this regard. There has been a major improvement in this area, particularly in 1983, although some staff still maintain their past reservations.

I find myself in some difficulty. A person has come to me because he is concerned that he may have been treated inappropriately during an assessment procedure. There are some features about the case that would give one cause for concern. One would not like to think that disagreements or bad blood which may have developed in the past between a union member and union officials could be carried over into an assessment procedure. On the surface, the assessment document seems to be that of an outstanding teacher. I know that if this were an application I received from someone seeking employment, I would have been highly impressed. It was written by members of the assessment panel, and each page was initialled by each one of them. So it was an agreed statement.

I would not like to think that this teacher had been inappropriately treated, that a veto by one of the panel might affect his professional advancement or might cause him, as he goes through a review procedure, to lose the satisfaction of promotion for nine to 12 months and that he would have on his record this adverse assessment which may remain for all time. The difficulty is that I do not like ex parte judgments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was he promoted?
—He now has to go through a procedure to review this decision. No, he has not been promoted.
—So there was a three to one decision and he was not promoted.

—There was a three to one decision in favour of his promotion and, as I understand it, he was not able to apply for eligibility. I say to the Minister that it is an ex parte situation. I have not heard the other side. There may be another side to the story. One has to be just. As I said, we could argue in another debate about his role qua the Australian Teachers Federation. That is not really important tonight. I am concerned that the Minister look carefully to this matter and determine for herself whether there seem to be sufficient grounds for this person to have had one adverse report or whether the circumstances might warrant the Minister taking a personal interest in the matter and perhaps seeing whether this teacher has had all the justice which every teacher in the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority should have on a matter as important to them as eligibility to apply for a promotion. If the Minister for Social Security will undertake to have Senator Ryan look at this matter, I will be grateful to lend any assistance that I can.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Peter Baume said, this is a matter which should be referred to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan). In many cases like this one cannot make a judgment on hearing only one side of the case. I will certainly refer the matter to the Minister and ensure that a reply is given to Senator Baume as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.10 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 21 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Commissioner of Taxation in the United Kingdom recently been given power to:
(a) enter and search premises where there are reasonable grounds for suspecting an offence involving tax fraud;
(b) call for books, accounts and other documents either from the taxpayer or from certain other persons; and
(c) require any tax accountant, who is convicted of certain tax offences after 30 July 1976, to produce documents which relate to any of his clients' affairs.
(2) Will the Government investigate the need for such power to be given to the Australian Taxation Commissioner.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(a), (b) and (c). Yes. the powers were given to the Inland Revenue Commissioners in 1976.

(2) The Commissioner of Taxation in Australia has corresponding powers and, indeed, revenue officials of the United Kingdom are known to have taken the Australian provisions into consideration in formulating laws and what would be appropriate in their country. In relation to the power described in (1)(a), section 263 of the Income Tax Assessment Act empowers the Commissioner or an authorised officer to have at all times full and free access to all buildings, places, books, documents and other papers for any of the purposes of the Act and , for that purpose, to make extracts from, or copies of, any such books, documents or papers.

In addition to section 263, recourse may be had to section 10 of the Commonwealth Crimes Act which provides that a Justice of the Peace, upon being satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that there is in any place anything that will afford evidence as to the commission of any offence against the laws of the Commonwealth, may grant a search warrant authorising a constable of police to enter a place and search and seize any such thing. Section 10 is not limited to tax fraud but extends to all offences against the Commonwealth.

In relation to the powers described in (1)(b) and (c), section 264 of the Income Tax Assessment Act empowers the Commissioner to require by notice in writing, any person, whether a taxpayer or not, inter alia, to attend and give evidence concerning his or any other person's income or assessment and to produce all books, documents and other papers relating thereto of which the person has custody or control.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 4 May 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Are full-time students eligible for sickness benefit in lieu of TEAS allowance if they suffer an extended illness during their course of study but return to, and complete, their studies in the same academic year; if not, what other means of support are available to students when illness causes temporary interruption to their studies.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Students who suffer illness during a year of study may continue to receive TEAS allowance provided that they are not obliged to discontinue their courses because of the length and severity of their illness. This is in keeping with the provisions of the Student Assistance Act which permits the payment of TEAS benefits only to full-time students.

Sickness benefit is an income support payment which is essentially designed to assist members of the workforce who become too sick to work and thereby suffer a loss of wages or other earned income. Under the present provisions of the law it is not payable to a student who temporarily loses an education allowance because he or she becomes too sick to study.

I am aware that as a result of these arrangements some people may find themselves without support from either scheme. The provision of appropriate support for people in these circumstances is currently being considered by my Department in conjunction with the Department of Social Security.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Are any plans or arrangements being made to facilitate the landing of the USA B52 aeroplanes at Woomera in South Australia, if so, what are such plans and arrangements.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No plans or arrangements are being made for US B52 aircraft to land at Woomera.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 23 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Will payroll deductions remain available for hospital and medical benefits funds when Medicare is introduced; if so, will consideration be given at that stage to provide similar facilities for payments made to the Queensland Ambulance Transport Brigade (QATB).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No change is contemplated in the arrangements under which Commonwealth employees can have their contributions to health insurance organisations deducted from their pay. The introduction of Medicare has no bearing on the policy of payroll deductions.

Under existing arrangements the groups or categories of groups granted access to Commonwealth Departmental Pay Systems for payroll deductions are limited. Health insurance organisations is a group which has traditionally enjoyed access while Ambulance Funds, such as the QATB, are excluded.

The access policy has its origins, primarily, in the inability of manual and the initial ADP systems to acommodate a comprehensive range of groups. There have been significant developments in ADP technology in the intervening years and the Department of Finance is now undertaking a comprehensive review of the policy relating to payroll deductions. At this stage, it is too early to predict the outcome of that review and whether an expanded range of organisations ( including organisations such as QATB) might be permitted acess to payroll deductions from Commonwealth payrolls. If modification of the policy along such lines proves to be feasible, an appropriate circular would be issued to departments and authorities to advise them of the change.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 May 1983 (Hansard page 522) Senator Harradine asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, without notice:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it not a fact that the Bank Account Debits Tax Administration Act exempts debits made to accounts in the name of non-profit schools but this exemption does not extend to support bodies associated with the schools? Is this not a tax on the efforts of such organisations as parents and friends organisations which are designed to provide educational aids for the schools which are exempt under the Act? If so, what does the Government intend to do about it?
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Legislation governing the bank account debits tax provides exemptions for debits to accounts of certain organisations, including non-profit schools, colleges and universities. A debit to a cheque account operated by these bodies is exempt from the tax provided the debit relates to a transaction carried out wholly and exclusively in furtherance of the objects of the body.

Debits made to a cheque account operated in the name of a support body of a school or college, such as a parents and citizens association or other parent body, do not come within the ambit of the exemption which the law currently provides.

The Government has undertaken to review the operation of this tax, including the appropriateness or otherwise of the exemptions contained in the law, after it has been in operation for approximately 6 months. Many representations have been received from school support organisations and other non-profit bodies in the community seeking exemption from the tax and these will be carefully considered in the course of the review.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 August 1983 (Hansard page 132) Senator Mason asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

QUESTION.PARA: I ask: Will the Government make an immediate approach to the Indonesian Government for an absolute guarantee that no items included in Australian military aid to Indonesia will be used against the people of East Timor? Will the Government, while still pressing for an act of self-determination in East Timor, seek as an interim measure a full and permanent amnesty for those Timorese who have opposed the Indonesian invasion? Will the Government seek, through the good offices of the United Nations and with the concurrence of the Indonesian and other interested governments, an open door for a comprehensive pattern of aid for East Timor in the form of both money and expertise that would enable it to become a prosperous and viable society? If that last objective could be achieved, and I believe it could, can that be on the basis of normal disclosure of events in East Timor being permitted by the Indonesian Government so that world opinon can be satisfied as to the intentions of Indonesia in regard to East Timor?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to those parts of the honourable senator's question which fall within his area of responsibility:

The Indonesian Government has been offering amnesty to Fretilin guerillas and their supporters since December 1977. The most recent offer was made in July of this year. The Indonesian authorities have emphasised that reprisals will not be taken against those who accept the amnesty offer. While precise information on the number of people who have availed themselves of the amnesty is not available , the policy has had some success in encouraging people to leave the mountains and return to a more normal way of life.

The reduction in the number of Fretilin sympathisers detained on Atauro Island is similarly to be welcomed. At the end of April 1983, 2,800 detainees were still on Atauro-against an initial population of around 5,000. The bulk of these detainees have been resettled in their former villages or in other villages on the mainland.
It is hoped that the remaining detainees on Atauro will be transferred to the mainland by the end of the year.

The Australian Government welcomes the efforts at reconciliation that have been made in East Timor by Governor Mario Carrascalao. It is therefore with regret that the Government learned of the attack on 8 April on an Indonesian garrison near Dilor in which 12-15 Indonesian solders were killed.

The Government believes that a resumption of military hostilities in East Timor would represent a step backwards in the search for a lasting peace. The Government therefore urges restraint so that the process of peaceful contact can be given a chance to succeed.

As regards the establishment of an 'open door' policy for the provision of international aid to East Timor, it should be noted that the International Committee of the Red Cross, UNICEF, The U.S. Catholic Relief Services and the Australian Government have been providing aid to East Timor for many years. For example, Australian Government assistance since September 1975 amounts to $7.7m. The most recent contribution, amounting to $1.5m, was announced by the Prime Minister in June.

While the Government sees advantages in Senator Mason's suggestion, the Indonesian authorities have to date preferred to initiate their own development budget of US$83m in 1982-83, and to limit outside assistance to support for humanitarian relief programs delivered through international relief agencies and some voluntary organisations. A number of recent visitors to East Timor, including an Australian Parliamentary Delegation, have attested to the considerable economic and social progress that has been achieved in recent years .

The Government has welcomed the fact that in recent years the Indonesian authorities have permitted an increasing number of visitors to East Timor. While wishing to see this continue, the Government recognises that the question of access is ultimately one for the Indonesian authorities to decide. In this context, the Government welcomes the recent visit to East Timor of an Australian Parliamentary Delegation and the exellent arrangements that were made for the delegation to enable it to travel so widely in East Timor.
